story:
Edinburgh University Footlights

Founded in 1989, Edinburgh University Footlights is a student-run musical theatre group that aims to annually present the largest scale production of the University's theatrical calendar. Over the years, Footlights has gone from strength to strength, with The Edinburgh Evening News dubbing the society "one of the most respected theatre groups in Britain" and recently forming an incredible Showchoir.

Footlights aims to give its entire cast and crew as professional an experience as possible while providing an accessible and affordable performance for the student body as well as the Edinburgh community at large. Each academic year, the society sets out to produce a musical of only the highest quality. In recent years, the society has continued to achieve striking levels of professionalism throughout all levels of these productions, reflected in hugely successful productions of hit musicals including 'Anything Goes', 'Fame', 'A Chorus Line', 'West Side Story', 'In The Heights' and most recently our 5-star performance of Johnathan Larson's 'Rent'.
EU Footlights is proud to announce its 2016 show, Guys and Dolls.
A high-rolling gambler attempts to woo a missionary for a bet and a showgirl dreaming of the honest life is engaged to the founder of “the oldest established permanent floating crap game in New York”.
This classic ‘musical fable of Broadway’, set in Damon Runyon’s 1930s New York, has been revived five times since its opening in 1951, winning countless awards along the way.

Why are we crowdfunding?


Every year the cast, crew and committee put in a huge amount of effort fundraising, hosting events, doing bakesales and singing Christmas Carols all over Edinburgh. Putting on a large scale production means paying for a venue, costumes, set and making sure everyone is heard and lit up! The money we raise here will be going directly towards the cost of the production and making sure that we continue to wow audiences across the city.

We hugely appreciate the help that friends, family and theatre lovers offer and whether you can donate or not we look forwards to seeing you in February at the show!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're interested in supporting us as a business we also have a wide range of sponsorship options available and would love to chat to you. You can get in touch with us at sponsorship@edfootlights.com

story:
1. My production of “Skin,” will be a performance incorporating art of all genres to help raise awareness of eating disorders during The National Eating Disorder Association’s Eating Disorder Awareness Week, the last week of February. Artists from all over the country are contributing original works with the intention of raising awareness of these diseases and expressing their views on contemporary notions of beauty and related social pressures. The goal of “Skin” is to bring eating disorders into public awareness and prevent these illnesses through the power of art and artistic expression. This show will be donation-based, and all proceeds will be donated to The National Eating Disorder Association.  We hope to have a wide range of audience members join us for this celebration of healthy minds and bodies.  In order to raise funds for the production of “Skin,” I am using Indie gogo.  The money donated to this site will go to theater rental, rehearsal rental, promotion costs, costuming and compensation for the artists involved with helping me create this performance.

  1. As a teenager I  was diagnosed with  bulimia nervosa.  I spent years suffering while my loved ones watched my body, as well and my personal self, deteriorate. As my weight diminished my entire persona changed as I became increasingly obsessive about and addicted to  my eating disorder. I spent months in recovery and will forever be grateful that I had such a strong support system among my friends and family.  However,  I  realized there was a huge lack of understanding of and education for eating disorders.  Often I would hear “just stop” or “if you really wanted to you could.” I found that my loved ones did not understand the severity of what I was going through. I felt powerless over my disorders, as though I couldn’t stop even if it would save my life.  Eating disorders are not a choice but a severe psychological and physical disorder. Eating disorders affect almost 3 million people in the US alone. Social pressures and ideas of beauty alongside psychological factors and genetics can all play a role in the development of eating disorders.  It is my dream in life to have eating disorders be erased forever. I want so badly for people to be acknowledged for who they are on the inside as opposed to the outside and for women and men to be recognized for inner beauty.  My goal for this show is not only to educate others on eating disorders but also promote healthy body images and self love.

  1. I am very moved by the amount of artists who have agreed to  contribute their work to this project.  It was an eye-opening experience just to see how many people are truly affected by eating disorders and how many of my friends have been through or have had loved ones suffer from these diseases. This show will be a collaborative process which will include dance, visual art, video, and musical performances.  While every artist is expressing themselves in their own way the piece I am personally choreographing is titled “Skin.”  As humans, I feel as though we are all trying to find our places in the world and figure out who we are and who we were meant to be. As children, our parents dressed us and chose how they thought we should act and dress.  As we grow older and gain more freedom and independence we start to make these decisions on our own and we learn how to express ourselves.  We are constantly changing our outer appearance to match who we think we are on the inside. Some of us do this with ease, and some of us struggle to fit comfortably in our own skin.  We can become obsessed with the outside because we aren’t satisfied with who we are on the inside.  We try to match others because we admire who they are and not who we are ourselves. This piece will be about the journey of self acceptance and self love, and it will be focused around the idea of figuring out who we are. When we learn to appreciate the person we are on the inside, we can then learn to appreciate our body and our appearance, and we can learn to let go of the idea that appearance is what makes us the person we are. We become comfortable with ourselves and comfortable in our skin.

  1. By contributing to "Skin" you will be helping a number of artists express their views on body image in Western culture, and you will be helping in the promotion of self love and self care. I will not be able to do this show without your support, and I truly believe these are topics that everyone should be educated on so that they may recognize these behaviors in their loved ones and they can help prevent and understand these disorders.  Not only will artists be showcasing their works inspired by body image, educational information and community resources by which people can find help will be provided at the show. By contributing to "Skin" you will help me gain the funding I need to truly make this show a success. All donations are greatly appreciated and valued, no matter how big or small. Even if donating is not available to you at this time, please help by sharing this event with your friends and family. Lets change the world together with art.

story:
Hello! My name is Kris Noteboom and this is my Indiegogo campaign.


The Project

My project is a one man show called ...and then I woke up. It's a comedic look at my very real trouble with sleeping and dreaming throughout my life, and my very existential trouble with the collective American Dream. Don't worry, though. I stay away from heavy handed stuff and instead focus on a series of humorous anecdotes from my life that cover my nightmare dominated childhood, my disastrous first audition, a strange sex dream, sexy vampires, and my forays into the odd world of performance art. It's a romp of an hour, using only my bed as my prop in which I give the audience a very, and often embarrassing, intimate look into my life in a way that everyone can identify with. 

Who am I?

Now my brief bio: As a performer, I've been on stages since before I knew I was on them. I had no idea what I was doing in my first audition for the talent show in 2nd grade. I just knew I wanted to be up there on stage. As I got older, I got a little more formal in my pursuits, taking part in theater from junior high through college. After a brief foray into the corporate world, I decided to go back to school and get my masters in Performance Studies. And, if you're wondering what that is, so was I when I started. But, in that program I learned performance art. Theaters strange cousin. I admit to this day that I could never quite figure it out, but I loved it. Now, I'm working on my PhD, also in performance art, at UT Dallas. This is where I developed this show. Beyond that, I've worked as a writer and critic for a prominent local arts site in Dallas/Ft. Worth called Theater Jones for the last five years. In pretty much every  way, theater and performance is my life...now. 

The show chronicles my circuitous journey to this point, when I often tried to be the person other people said I should be. That's kind of the point, though I never hammer it too much in the show. I find it's much more fun to writhe on my bed and run from Tom Cruise.

Why the campaign?

This summer, I'm embarking on a tour of theater festivals across the country. Tentatively, I'm calling it my Compass Tour, as I'm hitting north (Chicago), south (Dallas), east (Washington D.C.) and west (Hollywood).

Dallas Solo Fest - June 4-7

Hollywood Fringe Festival - June 12-20

Capital Fringe Festival - July 10-18

Chicago Fringe Festival - September TBA

Festivals are a great way for a performer to establish themselves, and I've been incredibly fortunate to be accepted to four different festivals.

However, there are costs associated with this. Costs that I can't full cover by myself. That's why I'm asking for your support.

What am I asking for and what does it go to?

I've set my campaign for a $6,000 flexible funding goal. 

The costs of doing this tour involve the following

  • Venue Fees - This is the cost of renting the venue, and includes paying vital staff like a Stage Manager and Technical Director. It's great to be accepted to these festivals, but they're facilitators more than anything. I'm still producing the show myself. And that means paying for the venue and staff, without who the show would be impossible.
  • Insurance - The show has to be insured.
  • Travel - Plane tickets, transportation when I'm in each city, etc.
  • Lodging - I pride myself on being frugal and will sleep on as many couches as possible, but there will be a few night when AirBNB will be my friend.
  • Food - I'll be in each of these locations (minus Dallas, where I live) for two weeks at a time. And despite my ampleness, I do have to eat.
  • Publicity/Advertising - Getting people to come to the show takes a lot of work, and a lot of postcards and flyers.
I do earn a percentage of ticket sales at these events, but this income is somewhat unreliable and doesn't arrive until well after the festival is over. Though, I have factored it into my calculations of what I can contribute to this project.
I'm not asking for the full cost of this odyssey. In fact, I've already paid a lot of money out of pocket, and will continue to do so as much as possible. 
I'm asking for about a third of the total cost. My parents raised me to work for what I get, and I'm doing as much of that as possible. 
But, patronage has always been an important part of the arts, and sites like Indigogo help less established artists, who don't have as much access to funds, get their work off the ground and seen. And in the arts world, it takes being seen to get momentum and become self-sustaining. I'm asking for a supportive nudge in that direction.
Check out this video about the 1,000 true fans theory of artistic careers these days:

And, it doesn't go unrewarded!
Incentives!
I've done my best to come up with a few interesting incentives for your investment. As a young performer, I don't have a brand to fall back on. I doubt many people would be too excited by a random t-shirt or coffee mug, so I really pushed myself to figure out some interesting and unique rewards, as well as the most conventional reward, a ticket to a future show.
About that. I can't use tickets for the festivals in this campaign. These performances are part of festivals and I can't walk in and say, "Hey, I've sold like 50 tickets through my crowdsourcing campaign." That's won't fly. 
So, what I'm going to do is host a series of intimate performance of 30-40 people late this year, after the tour. I have a cool venue for this here in Ft. Worth, and drinks, snacks and fellowship will be provided for a fun evening.
If you're not in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area and are still interested in seeing the show, it will work one of two ways. If enough people buy the show ticket from a specific town, I can get a space in that town and get the show produced. The demand makes that easy. Or, I'm putting a traveling show option where a group of people can band together and purchase it, offsetting individual costs and making it easier for me to travel and see you. 
Look through the incentives/rewards for more details...
Like and Share!
Whether you can afford to contribute or not, the one thing you can do that would help immensely is to share the campaign with your friends. Indiegogo has easy buttons to share on your social media. Or, e-mail the page to friends. A lot of contributions come from family and friends, but campaigns are made by getting the word out and getting people to discover and engage with the campaign who don't know me. 
So please, hit "like" and "share"
And follow me on social media. I'm on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
Facebook
Twitter
Thank you!
I'm eternally grateful for your support, and I promise I'm working hard and will continue to work hard to achieve my goals and justify your endorsement. 
Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

story:
The Pitch - TüManz 2k17

The year is 2071. In a totalitarian dictatorship not too far away, ‘The Ideas Man’ (a slovenly television personality turned despot) has enslaved humanity with subliminal messages.

But this phantasmic dictator has run outta spark. He's looking to rebrand, anxious that his particular method of hypnotism isn't manipulating quite as well as it used to. He needs a new means of control over his increasingly conspiratorial public. The solution? Mind control through film! 

He’s summoned Tü Manz to a bunker. Armed with a top-secret library of every film ever produced, the Manz are tasked with determining which genre-combinations will prove the most effective for subconsciously weaponising an increasingly canny public.

Cue the riotous combination of self-aggrandising genius Saul Boyer and dyspraxic pedant Sam Rayner. The pair desperately squabble over their favourite genres in an attempt to secure their fate: lionisation over liquidation!

The show is part narrative double-act - in which our TüManz play themselves - and part sketch extravaganza. The ultimate hybrid – and the vehicle for The Ideas Man’s new brand of world domination.

This is sketch comedy like you've never seen it before. Double the daring. Triple the titters, quadruple the quadrangles! It's a bloody bonanza that will have you laughing like ...drains! Expect S&M musketeers; Jewish mafiosi; a courtroom Telenovela; and a piratical zero gravity space opera! 

TüManz 2k17: You'll have to see it to believe it.

What We Need & What You Get

(Imagine us pitching this to you a la 'Dragons' Den'. We're dripping with sweat; you're reclining aggressively into a leather armchair)

We are looking for £1600. This will cover the upfront cost of venue hire (approx. £1300). £300 will be put towards publicity and/or fringe registration fees.  If we exceed our target we will invest in production costs: costumes, props, set, video production and projector hire.

We've gathered a melange of perks to tempt you into supporting us (emotionally, spiritually, but primarily financially). We hope that they excite you as much as they excite us. Should you want to suggest your own, unique perk, we'd love to hear from you. Ooooh perky!

Previous Work

Saul Boyer is an actor, comedian and award-winning playwright. Recently he toured Austria and Italy for six-months in a one-act farce for Vienna's English Theatre. He is represented by Savages Personal Management.

Sam Rayner is a comic director and choreographer. Recently he choreographed Jack Whitehall's UK and EIRE arena tour 'At Large' for Chambers' Mangement.

James Hansen is responsible for the production of stellar hits including Welcome Break (2014), Nougat for Kings (2014), COOL (2016), Crazy Science Stupid Magic (ongoing) and this short paragraph. He is also co-writing a culinary book. What a guy.

Together, Saul and Sam founded Unleash the Llama. A production company responsible for the hit Underbelly show 'Nougat for Kings' (2014) and, most recently, a music video in collaboration with Loco Ironico (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r9ESPmowm-U).

Praise for our previous work:

'hard to take your eyes off' - The Scotsman

'snappy, full of fun and very, very cool' - TCS

'Tarantino's balls' - Broadway Baby

'innovative, insane, must-see' - The Tab

'nonsense' - The Scotsman

Praise for Saul Boyer:

'Boyer was a triumph [...] a solid mountain of character' - CTR

'‘[Saul Boyer is] the kind of performer who doesn’t hesitate but forges ahead, bringing his audience and fellow comics along with him to new heights.’ - The Tab

'Boyer's creation [...] is astounding. He is a man for whom we feel pride, shame and pity all at once.' - Varsity

Praise for Sam Rayner:

'directed by Sam Rayner' - Varsity

Risks & Challenges

From Saul:

Being too Big.

Being too Massive. 

Getting it all Right.

HUBRIS.

From Sam:

1. Coordinating the multimedia aspects of the show with the live performance. 

2. Communicating the distinct moods and atmospheres of a variety of film genres in each sketch and distinguishing these from the double-act setting.

3. Marketing the show effectively via social media and in person to achieve the best attendance possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's no problem if you're not in a position to contribute financially. We'd love you to catch the TüManz in action or call up your wee chums and tell them all about our show.

Cue the riotous combination of self-aggrandising genius Saul Boyer and dyspraxic pedant Sam Rayner. The pair desperately squabble over their favourite genres in an attempt to secure their fate: lionisation over liquidation!
The show is part narrative double-act - in which our TüManz play themselves - and part sketch extravaganza. The ultimate hybrid – and the vehicle for The Ideas Man’s new brand of world domination.
This is sketch comedy like you've never seen it before. Double the daring. Triple the titters, quadruple the quadrangles! It's a bloody bonanza that will have you laughing like ...drains! Expect S&M musketeers; Jewish mafiosi; a courtroom Telenovela; and a piratical zero gravity space opera! 
TüManz 2k17: You'll have to see it to believe it.

What We Need & What You Get
(Imagine us pitching this to you a la 'Dragons' Den'. We're dripping with sweat; you're reclining aggressively into a leather armchair)
We are looking for £1600. This will cover the upfront cost of venue hire (approx. £1300). £300 will be put towards publicity and/or fringe registration fees.  If we exceed our target we will invest in production costs: costumes, props, set, video production and projector hire.
We've gathered a melange of perks to tempt you into supporting us (emotionally, spiritually, but primarily financially). We hope that they excite you as much as they excite us. Should you want to suggest your own, unique perk, we'd love to hear from you. Ooooh perky!

Previous Work
Saul Boyer is an actor, comedian and award-winning playwright. Recently he toured Austria and Italy for six-months in a one-act farce for Vienna's English Theatre. He is represented by Savages Personal Management.
Sam Rayner is a comic director and choreographer. Recently he choreographed Jack Whitehall's UK and EIRE arena tour 'At Large' for Chambers' Mangement.
James Hansen is responsible for the production of stellar hits including Welcome Break (2014), Nougat for Kings (2014), COOL (2016), Crazy Science Stupid Magic (ongoing) and this short paragraph. He is also co-writing a culinary book. What a guy.
Together, Saul and Sam founded Unleash the Llama. A production company responsible for the hit Underbelly show 'Nougat for Kings' (2014) and, most recently, a music video in collaboration with Loco Ironico (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r9ESPmowm-U).
Praise for our previous work:
'hard to take your eyes off' - The Scotsman
'snappy, full of fun and very, very cool' - TCS
'Tarantino's balls' - Broadway Baby
'innovative, insane, must-see' - The Tab
'nonsense' - The Scotsman
Praise for Saul Boyer:
'Boyer was a triumph [...] a solid mountain of character' - CTR
'‘[Saul Boyer is] the kind of performer who doesn’t hesitate but forges ahead, bringing his audience and fellow comics along with him to new heights.’ - The Tab
'Boyer's creation [...] is astounding. He is a man for whom we feel pride, shame and pity all at once.' - Varsity
Praise for Sam Rayner:
'directed by Sam Rayner' - Varsity

Risks & Challenges
From Saul:
Being too Big.
Being too Massive. 
Getting it all Right.
HUBRIS.
From Sam:
1. Coordinating the multimedia aspects of the show with the live performance. 
2. Communicating the distinct moods and atmospheres of a variety of film genres in each sketch and distinguishing these from the double-act setting.
3. Marketing the show effectively via social media and in person to achieve the best attendance possible.

Other Ways You Can Help
It's no problem if you're not in a position to contribute financially. We'd love you to catch the TüManz in action or call up your wee chums and tell them all about our show.

story:
Who We Are

Live Girls! is one of the longest running fringe theater companies in Seattle. We have been dedicated to producing and developing new plays by womxn since 1999.  We have fostered the creation of more than 300 theatrical works by womxn in our 18-year history and have also supported hundreds of female performers in multiple disciplines, including music, dance, comedy and improv, through our cabaret and performance series.  

What We Are Making

Our upcoming collaboration, The Secret and Impossible League of the Noösphere in The Baltimore Plot, is the result of a decade of conversations between Artistic Director Meghan Arnette and local playwright Darian Lindle about theatre, science fiction, identity, the female voice, and the power of serial storytelling. From those conversations came the idea of creating a series of stories that incorporated the concept of the NoöSphere, an adjacent reality where the world is literally formed and destroyed through the power of Ideas.

How Cool Is It?

In Part I of this series The Secret and Impossible League are caught out of time in the literal Noösphere where Ada Lovelace, Nicola Tesla, and Lord Byron discover that a dark force is dismantling human history. With the help of their sentient ship, The Mary-Celeste, and a unique engine built by Charles Babbage, they locate the source of the new disturbance in 1850’s America. Once there, they must partner with the Pinkerton Detective Agency and Kate, the world’s first female detective, to save Abraham Lincoln and possibly the world

What we have in place now-

A whip smart script, amazing actors, powerhouse production team and funds secured for space, rehearsal basics, and a portion of production expenses. And the whole thing is produced in Association with Theatre Off Jackson! But we still have a little way to go.

To make this production the success we know it can be we need help from patrons like you!

We have chosen flexible funding, so whatever we raise will go to the artists on the following schedule:

  • $2500 All baseline artist fees are covered!
  • $4500 All materials for theatrical magic secured!
  • $5000 and we can give our marketing team the funds they need to really fill our houses!
  • $5500 and we get to throw an open party worthy of these amazing artists!


Anything over $5500?  ALL of it goes to boost artist stipends!

We are an Associated Program of Shunpike, a 501(c)(3) non- profit, which makes all donations to us tax-deductible!

 

FULL SHOW INFO INCLUDING DATES AT TICKETS AT- lgtheater.org

story:
It Starts With Us

       Did you watch the Tony's this year? Ever wonder where those brilliant artists and entertainers come from? Most of them began their careers in healthy theatre communitites with local organizations that allowed them to not only find their passion for performing, writing or designing, but also gave them a chance to actually practice it. Here at Off-Strip Productions, we belive talent is cultivated through diverse experience and that's what we offer to artists in Las Vegas.

       Off-Strip Productions is a non-profit (501(c)(3)) organization that makes its home inside the charmingly intimate Onyx Theatre. Our mission is to encourage cultural accessibility and growth by collaborating with our arts community to provide first class, affordable entertainment with an innovative, in-your-face style taht you cannot get anywhere else in the Valley. From classic Broadway musicals to original, home-grown, works, we actively support opportunities for local artists through a teamwork approach to the creation of live theatre.

       Your contributions are essential to making this mission possible, thereby granting opportunities to local actors, directors, designers, musicians and more to exercise their crafts and gain the necessary experience not found in books or classrooms.

       Also by suporting us you are strengthening an entire community. In addition to the individual artists, we have and continue to partner with many local organizations that are similar to Off-Strip, but who have no home of their own companies like Poor Richard's Players, Table 8 Productions, Huntsman Entertainment, Rag Tag Entertainment, Sin City Opera and more.

       These are just a handful of the groups that share our vision for the Vegas tehatre scene. We work with them, providing a venue and whatever resources we can to promote their goals and objectives through quality productions that locals can actually afford to come and see.

       In the last year we have produced or co-produced some of the most exciting local theatre in the Valley with our own entertainingly innovative approach. Titles have included Sweeney Todd, Next to Normal, A Clockwork Orange, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, The Glass Menagerie, Godspell, as well as a number of original and avantegarde pieces for a fraction of what others charge. With your help, we will continue this tradition.

 

Where It's Going

       In the long run, your contributions will have a butterfly effect on the Vegas theatre community- they will help in more way than we can foresee or than you have time to read about. Nut the immediate benefits can be broken down into three categories:

  1. Overall Production Value
  2. Venue Improvements
  3. Artist Incentives

Overall Production Value:

       Producing a play or musical can get expensive. The rights alone can be thousands of dollars. This doesn't include the costs of acutally putting a show on stage. A portion of the money collected will go to acquiring stock resources, such as microphones, monitors, costume and set pieces, which can be altered and used for various productions. This eliminates some of the unnecessary expences of renting or purchasing items for each title in our season. As a result, we can keep ticket prices at an affordable rate.

Venue Improvements:

       The Onyx Theatre is such a unique space, in part, because it was built by hand in a building that was never inteded to be a theatre. This is what gives it the indie art house charm, reminiscent of those in Northeast theatre districts like New York and Philadelphia. But its location also presents some challenges. We have already begun making improvements including expanding wing space on one side, adding a larger second dressing room, upgradingsome lighting and sound equipment and creating a more welcoming lobby (complete with concessions). However, there are always improvements that can be made to enhance the theatre experience for both our patrons an dour artists. For starters, we will be replacing or repairing seats, creating more options for handicap access, expanding wing space on the other side, and continuing to keep our technical resources up to date. A portion of your contributions assist us in all of these efforts.

Artist Incentives:

        Las Vegas is incredibly rich with talented artists. Because of the quality and originality of our productions, we are often able to entice highly skilled performers and designers to join our team. But no one expects to make a living doing community theatre; thus, a majority of these exceptional folks earn their income through full-time employment. They make sacrifices for their art and for the sake of lacal theatre goers by taking time off of work or turning down higher paying gigs to be a part of a project that they believe in.

        At Off-Strip Productions, we want to be able to reward them for their sacrifices and for lending us their talents. A stipend, no matter how small, is always appreciated becuse it shows that we appreciate them. Your generous gifts will allow us to continue drawing these remarkable artists to projects like ours, thereby raising the bar for local theatre thoughout the Valley.

 

It's Not Really Altruism

        No, we don't expect you to give for nothing. In addition to good Karma and a fuzzy feeling of benevolence, you will recieve a variety of valuable perks. These will include tickets or season passes, concession, memorabilia or even having your name enshrined on our "Wall of Thanks" in the theatre lobby.

 

It Always Comes Back

        The bottom line is everything you donate will come back to benefit you- our loyal patrons and fellow community members. By supporting what we do at Off-Strip Productions you are supporting the idea of local theatre everywhere. We want to work with you to set the standards for artistic opportunity and affordable entertainment. And who knows...on day in the not-so-distant future, one of our own may get up on that stage to accept their Tony and thank those that made it possible for them right here in Las Vegas- proving to the world once and for all that we do, in fact, have culture. But even if they don't, it'll still be true, thanks to you!

 

Other Ways To Help

        We know as well as anyone that times are tough. Financial donations are the most useful to us right now, but some folks just don't have it to spare. Well fear not! There are several ways you can still support our cause.

  1. Let people know about his campaign!
  2. Come see our shows: There's no better way to show your support than to be there clapping when the curtain closes. So come experience first hand why what we do is so important. (Buy tickets and get show info at www.onyxtheatre.com OR call the Box Office at (702) 732-7225.)
  3. Audition: Our directors are always looking for "just the right person" to fill that role. Think you've got what it takes? (Like our Facebook page or e-mail info@onyxtheatre.com for audition updates.)
  4. Volunteer: We can always use a helping hand, wheather building sets, working backstage, distributing flyers or just getting the word out. Wanna help? Contacts us at info@onyxtheatre.com
  5. Donate Goods or Services: One man's junk might be another man's set piece (or costume). You never know what your local theatre can use in tis next project or how your talents might be valuable. Let us know what you've got. We may even be able to offer you a tax write off for your donations. Contact info@onyxtheatre.com with donation inquiries.

story:
ATTENTION INDIE THEATRE LOVERS!

WE'VE GOT A GREAT BARGAIN FOR YOU!

safeword's upcoming production of Donors is in need of a few donors in order to help us purchase our theatre space, buy set pieces and props, build risers and complete the finishing touches to our show so that we can open to the public boldly and successfully and bring YOU some thrilling entertainment.

SO, we've set up a campaign that is specifically designed to help YOU reap the benefits! Here we are offering any number of tickets to go see Donors at the least expensive rates possible. Nowhere else except for Indiegogo will you be able to purchase tickets up to 30% off. And if you donate even a little more, we've also got some fun, one-of-a-kind perks that you won't want to miss out on. 

So buy your tickets now and save while also helping us raise the remaining money for our show. It's win-win!

ABOUT THE SHOW:

safeword presents the World Premiere of Donors, a new, original Canadian play that boldly and chillingly examines the ambiguous world of sperm donors, the repercussions of letting strangers enter your home and the fearful things we inherit deep within our blood. 

Gray, a sperm donor, meets his 18 year old son for the first time. But as more children get added to the roster, a dream becomes a nightmare with disastrous consequences. This thrilling, suspenseful drama/horror from the same creative team that brought you Turtleneck earlier this year, is guaranteed to leave audiences breathless.

It runs from November 7th to 17th, 2013 at hub14 (14 Markham St., just west of Queen and Bathurst). Tickets are only $18 and are available for purchase at secureaseat.com/donors or at the door of each performance (cash-only).

Recommended for ages 18 and up for mature themes, coarse language and violence.

safeword presents

donors

Written and Directed by Brandon Crone

Starring Thomas Gough, Jakob Ehman and Karen Slater

Designer: Claire Hill

Stage Manager: Cristina Hernandez

Fight Director: Jeremy Hutton

Opens November 7th and runs until November 17th, 2013

hub14, 14 Markham St., Toronto ON

Thurs, Fri, Sat evenings at 8pm and Sat and Sun matinees at 2pm

Tickets $18, available at secureaseat.com/donors

ABOUT SAFEWORD

safeword is a new, independent theatre company based in Toronto focused on developing and producing original Canadian works of theatre that explore controversial and socially relevant subject matter through raw, high-octane performance. In role-playing fantasies, participants are often obliged to create a 'safe word' which is used only when the actions in the scene border too far into reality. Our company is interested in pushing our limits into these untrodden territories and challenging our audiences to ask themselves which words are 'safe' and which ones are still out of bounds. safeword’s mandate has two specific objectives. The first: to create, cultivate and contribute an exciting and assertive dramatic canon to our country’s national literature. The second: facilitate the independent production of new, Canadian work with our unique brand of raw and hyper-realistic performance. For more info visit our website at www.safeword.ca or ‘Like’ our facebook page to stay informed: www.facebook.com/safewordtheatre

Praise for safeword’s Turtleneck (February 2013)

“I loved the play. I’m feeling pretty tempted to position Turtleneck among my top three favorite plays I’ve seen in Toronto. It is something very special. I recommend Turtleneck to anyone into theatre that grips you and doesn’t let you loose.”

–Mooney on Theatre

“This is an experience that I will not forget for a long time to come. If Turtleneck is not busting at the seams that’s because it’s seamless, in the best way possible.”

-My Entertainment World


WWW.SAFEWORD.CA

story:
THE SHOW
                                      “ Is Thrill Seeking Wise?”
 
When you have woken up, one too many times, devastated from last nights self-sabotaging orgy of sex, drugs and alcohol, with a looming voice in your head screaming “GET YOUR SHIT TOGETHER”- only to be interrupted by a louder, restless, more appealing voice, encouraging you to do it all again- you might ask yourself if you have been exercising choice, or something else?
 
 
Buddha and the Rock Star is a high energy, original multi-media performance incorporating the raw elements of physical theatre, dance and film. Experience the erotic, provoking struggle of a thrill seeking woman becoming acquainted with wisdom.
 
OUR STORY AND MISSION

Hi!  We are Red Rose Productions, a brand new Physical Theatre Production Company in Montreal. 

We are dedicated to bringing exciting and evocative multi-media physical theatre in Canada and Abroad.


WE NEED 200 PEOPLE TO GIVE $10 SO WE CAN DO THESE 3 EXCITING THINGS:


#1 Premier Buddha & the Rock Star  at:

The Montreal St. Ambroise 2011 FRINGE Festival June 1st- 19th



#2 Travel to Upstate New York to perform the show for:

 NACL’s 2011 DEEP SPACE PERFORMANCE RESIDENCY  July 11th -17th

(www.nacl.org)

 
#3 Not get deep into debt and compensate the amazing cast and crew:

As it stands the artistic director Rosaruby Kagan is the funding source for the project. She does not want to make any personal profit from this production but would very much like to be able to compensate her collaborators for their hard work. This is very important to her personal values.

 
THE IMPACT

When Independent Theatre is given a helping hand, the vision comes to completion as a huge success and those independent theatre artists get a foot up in the community! They can then apply for larger grants from big funding organizations!! YAY!!!


THE WORLD IS CHANGING

Independent artists through out history have had to struggle to make a living and produce their art. The internet has birthed exciting fundraising opportunities to reach a broader fundraising base. Thus allowing artists to create amazing works of art, funded solely by small contributions from hundreds of people.


SPEND THE PRICE OF A DRINK TO FUND AN AMAZING PROJECT!! 


GIVE SMALL AND SPREAD THE WORD!!

 

WHAT WE NEED


Low estimate of costs to date:


$400- Off Fringe Application Fee
$700- Rehearsal Space Rental Fee
$375- Performance Venue Rental Fee
$500- lighting and sound equipment
$300- props and costumes
$250- promotional material (posters and flyers and program)
________________________________________________________ 

2,175 – Round that down to 2,000 (trying to be realistic)

If we make 2,000 on this fundraising campaign.  We will use the profit from ticket sales (14 shows at 10 a max audience of 40 = a max profit of $5,600) to:

BUY 12 round trip bus tickets to New York (estimated $1200) and divide whatever money is left over ($4,400) amongst my cast of 8 and crew of 6 (only 4 will come to NY) = $314 each!!

 
 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP



TELL YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY AND TELL THEM TO TELL THEIR FRIENDS AND FAMILY!!!!!
story_txt:
THE SHOW                                      “ Is Thrill Seeking Wise?” When you have woken up, one too many times, devastated from last nights self-sabotaging orgy of sex, drugs and alcohol, with a looming voice in your head screaming “GET YOUR SHIT TOGETHER”- only to be interrupted by a louder, restless, more appealing voice, encouraging you to do it all again- you might ask yourself if you have been exercising choice, or something else?  Buddha and the Rock Star is a high energy, original multi-media performance incorporating the raw elements of physical theatre, dance and film. Experience the erotic, provoking struggle of a thrill seeking woman becoming acquainted with wisdom. OUR STORY AND MISSIONHi!  We are Red Rose Productions, a brand new Physical Theatre Production Company in Montreal. We are dedicated to bringing exciting and evocative multi-media physical theatre in Canada and Abroad.WE NEED 200 PEOPLE TO GIVE $10 SO WE CAN DO THESE 3 EXCITING THINGS:
#1 Premier Buddha & the Rock Star  at:The Montreal St. Ambroise 2011 FRINGE Festival June 1st- 19th#2 Travel to Upstate New York to perform the show for: NACL’s 2011 DEEP SPACE PERFORMANCE RESIDENCY  July 11th -17th(www.nacl.org) #3 Not get deep into debt and compensate the amazing cast and crew:As it stands the artistic director Rosaruby Kagan is the funding source for the project. She does not want to make any personal profit from this production but would very much like to be able to compensate her collaborators for their hard work. This is very important to her personal values. THE IMPACTWhen Independent Theatre is given a helping hand, the vision comes to completion as a huge success and those independent theatre artists get a foot up in the community! They can then apply for larger grants from big funding organizations!! YAY!!!
THE WORLD IS CHANGINGIndependent artists through out history have had to struggle to make a living and produce their art. The internet has birthed exciting fundraising opportunities to reach a broader fundraising base. Thus allowing artists to create amazing works of art, funded solely by small contributions from hundreds of people.SPEND THE PRICE OF A DRINK TO FUND AN AMAZING PROJECT!! 

GIVE SMALL AND SPREAD THE WORD!! 
WHAT WE NEED

Low estimate of costs to date:
$400- Off Fringe Application Fee$700- Rehearsal Space Rental Fee$375- Performance Venue Rental Fee$500- lighting and sound equipment$300- props and costumes$250- promotional material (posters and flyers and program)________________________________________________________ 2,175 – Round that down to 2,000 (trying to be realistic)If we make 2,000 on this fundraising campaign.  We will use the profit from ticket sales (14 shows at 10 a max audience of 40 = a max profit of $5,600) to:BUY 12 round trip bus tickets to New York (estimated $1200) and divide whatever money is left over ($4,400) amongst my cast of 8 and crew of 6 (only 4 will come to NY) = $314 each!!  OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPTELL YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY AND TELL THEM TO TELL THEIR FRIENDS AND FAMILY!!!!!

story:
“Give the Geeks $5"


(or more if you’re able)

How we Roll. Why we Play. Who we Love.


 Of Dice and Men — is a play about a group of 30-something Dungeons & Dragons players and what happens when one of them enlists to go to Iraq.

At the 2010 PAX gaming convention, 550 people waited in line for hours to see the World Premiere of "Of Dice and Men" by Cameron McNary.  The convention staff stopped counting after they turned away 250 people who got there too late.  Help us bring "Of Dice and Men" to a Regional Theater near you with your donation.

Of Dice and Men is a celebration of Geek Culture and gamers in particular, about D&D and the friendships formed through gaming. Playwright Cameron McNary says, “I wanted to write about the kinds of gamers I knew, not the cheeto-stained, overweight, mom’s-basement-living stereotype, but the highly-functional, attractive, fun-to-be-around folks I game with.”

"It takes some fucking balls to put on a show anywhere, let alone in a converted convention room.  Something special must have happened in there, though, because people wanted to talk about it for the remainder of the show."-- Tycho, Penny Arcade 

“Of Dice and Men” made PAX for me. For laughter and tears, nothing else compared...They deserved the packed house and the standing ovation they got.  You must see and become involved with this play if you ever have a chance."-- Chris Sims, Critical-Hits.com

"It is a play for our tribe, as McNary puts it. And yet this simple two act play could be a window through which mainstream, “normal” people could see us for what we are… just as emotional, complex and hopeful as anyone else."-- M, Geek's Dream Girl

It’s a blisteringly funny and deeply affecting story about friendship, what it means to be a grown-up, and why gaming matters.

Great Plays. About Geeks.
Donations to Critical Threat Theatre will support great plays about geek culture and the geek experience.

Thank you for making a secure contribution to this project via Indie GoGo and FRACTURED ATLAS. Critical Threat Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions in behalf of Critical Threat Theatre may be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
 

Contributions will be used to bring Of Dice and Men to a full production and to support readings and future productions of classic and contemporary Great Plays About Geeks.

story:
Our Story

 

Daniel O'Shea is a prolific actor who has been gracing stages and screens for over two decades. Danny is the guy that other actors watch and think, 'Why the hell have I not heard of this guy before?' If you know him, you know what we're talking about, and if you don't, you'll soon find out.

Sometimes a great actor has a great notion. Eugene O'Neill's "Hughie," a portrait of a man named Erie Smith struggling to survive his run of bad luck, has been whispering to Danny for years. Six months ago, he finally secured the rights to produce "Hughie" for three weeks in New York City. To complement O'Neill's one act play, Danny chose Susan Glaspell's "Trifles." Glaspell, a Pulitzer Prize-winner in her own right, helped launch O’Neill’s career in the summer of 1916 when he visited the Provincetown Players in Provincetown, Massachusetts. It was an auspicious summer for Glaspell, during which she both wrote and performed in “Trifles” and organized the very first reading of a Eugene O’Neill play. Their close personal and professional relationship over the ensuing years led to some of the greatest writing in the history of the American theatre.

With two great plays in hand, Danny assembled a group of actors, a director, and designers to bring O'Neill's and Glaspell's characters off the page and into living, breathing life. 

 

The Impact

 

Danny had the good fortune to be visited by an angel, Mary C Healey, with whose support we secured a theatre space (the biggest expense in NYC!). Now our task turns to building the world of these two plays.

 

By donating any amount of money today, you will help us transform our small stage into the two lonely worlds these plays inhabit: a seedy New York City hotel, and a dilapidated mid-west farmhouse. Theatre is a collaborative art, created by a community of artists and audience members together. We're asking you to join that community today--help us build the world you'll be able to see when we open on November 3rd!

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need to raise the final $4,000 to bring these plays to life. Any amount you can give helps us reach that goal.  

  • For $20 you get a ticket to a performance of your choice and a thank you in our program!  If you are unable to make the show, your ticket will be donated in your name to a starving theatre-lover.
  • For $50 you get two tickets to a performance of your choice, a program mention, and a program signed by the cast!  We're not famous ... yet.

  • For $100 you get two reserved seats to a performance of your choice (we’re saving you the best seats in the house), a program mention, a program signed by the cast, and a complimentary drink for you and a guest during our intermission.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you're not able to help with a donation today, please consider passing this campaign along to friends or family.  Word of mouth (or email, or facebook, or twitter) is a great way to help us reach our goal.

 

And, of course, we invite you to come see the show!  Theatres are so much livelier when there's living people in the seats.

story:
About GraveYard Shift Productions

GraveYard Shift Productions was founded in the Spring of 2011 to highlight the skills of emerging young theatre artists in St. John's. Our mandate has been to showcase new talent and provide a learning experience by pairing emerging artists with established professionals in the field. In August we will be presenting our third show "Boyfriends" at the Rabbittown Theatre, expanding the size of our cast and crew from previous productions, and continuing to set a standard for high quality productions from a group of hard working and dedicated artists.

 

About the Play

"Boyfriends" is a comedy about three best friends living in the heart of New York City during the 1950s. When Peter, a perpetually high strung actor, gets his heart broken by his ex-girlfriend, his friends Ben and John set a plan in action to get him back on the horse.

Shirley, a high class call girl, is called upon and a challenge is issued to the best friends - Whoever can get Shirley to fall in love with him, wins the game.

Deception, trickery, and two faced double dealing pit each friend against each other in the battle for her heart. But only one man can end up the winner.

Featuring: Sarah Browne, Darren Ivany, David Feehan, and Dylan Brenton

Directed by: Ciarán Dyke

 

Showtimes & Tickets

"Boyfriends" plays at the Rabbittown Theatre, August 1-4th.

Showtime starts at 8pm, with a Pay-what-you-can matinee at 2pm on August 4th.

Tickets are available online at www.rca.nf.ca or you can call the Hall at 753-4531.

Tickets will also be available at the door.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of theatre is not cheap, and the people who do it work countless hours on end for little to no pay. By contributing to our campaign you will help fund the cost of our venue rental, artist fees, set construction, costume design, and general costs. GraveYard Shift was founded from the ground up and runs out of the pockets of the individuals involved, we strive to create a quality product and put our faith in the community for their continued support. Donations of any size, from $5 to $500, help keep us going and assure that we can continue to create work for the growing theatre community, as well as providing entertainment for our captive audiences.

By supporting our show you will show that you care about the local theatre community, and that you have helped foster the development of emerging artists who strive endlessly to make a career in the arts. GraveYard Shift hopes to continue creating local theatre, but can not do it without the support of the community it is creating shows for.

The Impact

With two successful shows already under our belt we feel confident in the support of the local community. GraveYard Shift grew out of the artist training programs offered locally at Memorial and Grenfell, and continues to maintain a great relationship with them both. The development of the community and the skillsets of our emerging artists is crucial to our mandate and beliefs, and we would not be asking for the support of our community if we did not fully believe we were doing something for their benefit. Your support will help gain training and experience for a whole new generation of artists who seek to give back to the community that helped them grow.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show! Buy a ticket, bring a friend! Tell your parents, tell your cat! Follow us on facebook and twitter, and help us grow through the wonders of social media!

story:
What's this all about?

We are the CNY Shakespeare Festival. A few friends who met at Le Moyne College in Syracuse, New York decided to start a pay-what-you-can theatre company so that everyone could afford to see the art form they love so much. We began last summer and received wonderful acclaim for our production of Henry Vx7.

This economy is tough on a lot of people.  We believe that the theatre should enlighten and change audiences. We also believe theatre should be available to all, not just a privileged few. Your contribution will provide theatre to everyone around you.

What We Need & What You Get

For our summer season we need to raise $2,000 more. That money goes to hire actors, directors, and designers, and to pay for props, costumes, and space rentals, lawyers, accountants, and advertising legal fees to obtain our not-for-profit status. Designers alone will cost about $1100 for both shows. Sets will cost $600. The 501c3 filing fee is $800.00 plus a lawyer fee which will be just under $1000. Royalties will cost us $600.00 dollars. You may noticed that we haven't listed everything and we have already hit our $2,000 mark. Collaboration is key in the theatre. Writers, directors, designer, actors, the stage crew and many others are required for a great production. Your donation will help to instill that greatness!

 We have some great perks for different levels of donations - check out the buttons to the right!

Should we not reach our goal of $2,000, the monies gathered will still help offset our overhead costs. 

 What’s the Catch?  

There's really no catch. We're entirely pay-what-you-can. We want to compensate all of our artists for their hard work and dedication. For nine months we search for funding to put on the best show possible. Then for thee months, we get to do what we love!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for in-kind donations for our fundraising events. Silent auction items are a huge help.

As we continue to grow we're looking for a permanent place to call our home. We hope to host another Indiegogo capital campaign for our own building.

story:
Who are we?!

Boo Radley Productions is a collaboration of Colleen Murphy and RJ Lewis.  Fate brought them back together after years of being apart.  We are a New York City based production company, focusing on the exploration of truth and the meaning of life through theatre and film.  Our goal is to take the audience on a journey of understanding through the media of theatre and film.  Our desire is to create characters and relationships that all people can relate to and learn from.  

"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view...until you climb into his skin and walk around in it."  --Harper Lee, "To Kill a Mockingbird"

THE ANGER OF ERNEST AND ERNESTINE

Director: Bryan Radtke

Assistant Director: Fenton Li

Ernest: RJ Lewis 

Ernestine: Colleen Murphy

We have chosen "The Anger of Ernest and Ernestine" as our first production!  It is a story about Ernest and Ernestine, two newly weds that are dealing with the challenges of learning how to live with each other.  We've all been there, the point in time when something that seemed so sweet in the beginning of a relationship starts to grate on your last nerve and you're not sure if you or your partner will survive.  That fantasy of a picture perfect world really is scary when it's not as great as you thought it would be, will love prevail?  Is love worth fighting for?

What are we asking for?

With your contribution, you will help us make our dream a reality!  We are asking for $3,000 in total, and any donation will help!  

This money will go towards many things, our biggest expense is our venue (without it we'd be performing in the streets!), followed by rehearsal space (we need a lot of rehearsing!!), programs and propaganda (we've got to let the world know!), and the rest of the money goes towards the set (furniture, props, and costumes!).

Even if we don't reach our goal, all of your donations and support will be used to pay for as much as we can stretch!

What kind of impact are you making?

You know what kind of impact you are making!!  We are hard working, dedicated, and talented artists that need love and support from all of those around us to make do what we're meant to do, CREATE!  We're testing out our own production company, and we know we can do it.  Sadly we'd be happier if we could do it without money, but it's not possible!

story:
(DÉVOILÉ)

English version follows

Pour la petite histoire, nous nous sommes rencontrés Marc-André Bourgault et moi, Sharon Ibgui, à l’Option théâtre du Cégep Lionel-Groulx. Ce qui nous a toujours intéressé au théâtre c’est le non-dit, le bouillonnement intérieur qui transparaît au travers d’un souffle, toutes ces catastrophes miniatures qui nous habitent et dont nous sommes seul témoin. Quelques années plus tard, Marc-André m' a approché pour fonder une compagnie de théâtre avec lui. Sommes-nous fait pour créer ensemble? Est-ce que j ai envie de m'embarquer dans toutes ces paperasseries? D'assumer tous les risques financiers inhérents à un tel projet? Eh bien oui! L'envie de créer est plus forte que la peur. Et je trouve en Marc-André un accolyte aux convictions communes. Les Défricheurs Théâtre voit le jour en mai 2011.

Marc-André décide alors d'orchestrer le premier projet. Un projet qui a pour prémisse les blocages que nous ressentons dans notre corps suite à des évènements marquants, des blessures de la vie. S'en suive quelques laboratoires où l'histoire de Marc-André s'impose comme une évidence. Marc-André a été violé à l'âge de 5 ans par son père et a paralysé pendant plusieurs mois à l'âge de 13 ans... Les échos dans son corps sont évidents. Ayant entrepris un travail sur lui depuis déjà quelques années, (Dévoilé) se présente comme une oeuvre salvatrice lui permettant à chaque étape de la création de se libérer de ce lourd passé.

Je vous rassure, nous ne sommes pas dans le théâtre de l'apitoiement mais dans celui de la résilience. Comment devient-on un homme libre suite à ce genre d'évènement? C'est ce que mon ami Marc-André réussit quotidiennement et c'est avec un immense plaisir que je le vois créer après l'horreur. Marc-André dit souvent que l'art lui a sauvé la vie. Et bien maintenant, c'est à son tour de créer. (Dévoilé) est une ode à la lumière, à la liberté, un lieu où le cynisme n'a pas sa place. Le pardon, l'Amour, la foi en quelque chose de plus grand que l'hommerie, voilà où (Dévoilé) nous mène.

Nous savons qu'il y a des tonnes de causes, mais nous pensons fermement que l 'art peut faire une différence. Le viol est ici un prétexte. Notre but est de chercher avec vous comment nous pouvons fleurir malgré l'horreur? Comment devenir les héros de nos vies ?

Nous sommes une nouvelle compagnie qui a la chance de pouvoir se produire à La Chapelle du 5 au 16 mars 2013. Notre propos a su les interpeller et nous en sommes très fiers! Maintenant comment financer un tel projet? Aurons-nous des subventions gouvernementales et autres ? Nous n'en savons rien mais nous savons que tout ceci représente bien des sous! C'est là où nous espérons avoir votre support! Peu importe le montant, si notre propos peut vous toucher. En espérant que vous serez nombreux! Merci d'avance, chers amis ! Et n’hésitez pas à partager cette page parmi vos réseaux!

_____________________________________________________________

 

  • (UNVEILED)

To make a long story short, Marc-André Bourgault and I, Sharon Ibgui, met at Cegep Lionel-Groulx, Theater option. What has always made theater interesting to us is the unspoken, the inside bubbling that shines through in one breath, these miniature disasters that live in each of us and for which we are the only witness. A few years later, Marc-André approached me with the idea of starting a theater company together. Do we have what it takes to create together? Is all the required paperwork what I really want to get into? To assume all the financial risks inherent to such a project? Well, yes! The desire to create is stronger than fear. And I found in Marc-André a partner that shares common beliefs. Les Défricheurs Théâtre was founded in May 2011.

Marc-André decides to orchestrate the first project. A project based on the premise that significant events, injuries of life leave blockages in our body. Ensues a few laboratories where the story of Marc-André becomes self-evident. Marc-André was raped by his father at the age of 5 and paralyzed for several months at the age of 13 ... Echoes in his body are evident. Having started to work on himself a few years ago (Unveiled) is presented as a liberation act allowing him, with every step of the creation, to free himself from the heavy weight of his past.

Rest assured, we are not in theater of pity but in one of resilience. How do you become a free man after this kind of event? This is what my friend Marc-André manages daily and it is with great pleasure that I see him create after the horror. Marc-André often says that art saved his life. Well, now it is his turn to create. (Unveiled) is an ode to light, freedom, a place where cynicism has no place. Forgiveness, Love, faith in something bigger than baseness, that is where (Unveiled) leads.

We know there are tons of causes, but we firmly believe that art can make a difference. Rape here is a pretext. Our goal is to uncover with you how we can flourish despite the horror? How to become the heroes of our lives?

We are a new company that has the opportunity to perform at La Chapelle from March 5th to March 16th, 2013. Our discourse talked to them and we are very proud of it! Now, how to finance such a project? Will we obtain government subsidies or others? We do not know but we know that all of this represents a lot of money! This is where we hope to have your support! Regardless of the amount, we are hoping that many of you will be touched by our purpose! Thank you in advance, dear friends! And do not hesitate to share this page through your networks!

Marc-André Bourgault

Sharon Ibgui

Les Défricheurs Théâtre

 

(Dévoilé)-5 au 16 mars 2013, La Chapelle scènes contemporaines

Avec Enrica Boucher, Marc-André Bourgault, Ludger Côté, Catherine Dajczman, Patricia Larivière, Gabriel Paré et Audrey Talbot.

Mise en scène : Marc-André Bourgault / Assistance : Sharon Ibgui

Dramaturgie : Sara Fauteux / Éclairages : Anne-Marie Rodrigue-Lecours

 

Crédit photos: Carla Ramirez

(DÉVOILÉ) 
English version follows
Pour la petite histoire, nous nous sommes rencontrés Marc-André Bourgault et moi, Sharon Ibgui, à l’Option théâtre du Cégep Lionel-Groulx. Ce qui nous a toujours intéressé au théâtre c’est le non-dit, le bouillonnement intérieur qui transparaît au travers d’un souffle, toutes ces catastrophes miniatures qui nous habitent et dont nous sommes seul témoin. Quelques années plus tard, Marc-André m' a approché pour fonder une compagnie de théâtre avec lui. Sommes-nous fait pour créer ensemble? Est-ce que j ai envie de m'embarquer dans toutes ces paperasseries? D'assumer tous les risques financiers inhérents à un tel projet? Eh bien oui! L'envie de créer est plus forte que la peur. Et je trouve en Marc-André un accolyte aux convictions communes. Les Défricheurs Théâtre voit le jour en mai 2011. 
Marc-André décide alors d'orchestrer le premier projet. Un projet qui a pour prémisse les blocages que nous ressentons dans notre corps suite à des évènements marquants, des blessures de la vie. S'en suive quelques laboratoires où l'histoire de Marc-André s'impose comme une évidence. Marc-André a été violé à l'âge de 5 ans par son père et a paralysé pendant plusieurs mois à l'âge de 13 ans... Les échos dans son corps sont évidents. Ayant entrepris un travail sur lui depuis déjà quelques années, (Dévoilé) se présente comme une oeuvre salvatrice lui permettant à chaque étape de la création de se libérer de ce lourd passé. 
Je vous rassure, nous ne sommes pas dans le théâtre de l'apitoiement mais dans celui de la résilience. Comment devient-on un homme libre suite à ce genre d'évènement? Et n’hésitez pas à partager cette page parmi vos réseaux!

story:
Smithereen Productions has been producing T.I.M. (The Improvised Musical) over almost two years now! It has been a dream come true with the support that we've recieved from everyone. However, it's time for us to step outside of our box and into the script! 

 

We like to think that we produce theater people think is refreshing and something with a bold message. So why not have our first scripted musical be the cult-classic "Hedwig and the Angry Inch?" There is no reason for it not to be. This show is not only a show with a beautiful message and bold ideas, but also a show that is rarley produced in the Milwaukee area! 

 

A little about Hedwig and the Angry Inch: Text by John Cameron Mitchell and music by Stephen Trask, this show is an in-your-face power house all told by the "internationally-igonred," East Berlin-born, trans-woman Hedwig. 

From IMDB- "A transexual punk rock girl from East Berlin tours the US with her rock band as she tells her life story and follows the ex-boyfriend/bandmate who stole her songs." 

 

This project is nothing short of a dream. The Smithereen Productions message is one of tolerance, beauty, and innovative theater. Please help us with this message by donating to this project!

story:
The Project

“A Fierce Longing” rocked my world when I first saw it for a variety of reasons. A strong ensemble cast, mind-boggling visuals, a fascinating central character from an unfamiliar culture, and an exploration of themes of beauty, sexuality, and death all contributed to an unforgettable piece of theater. I’m reviving this play to pay tribute to one of the peak theatrical experiences of my life, and to honor the exceptionally rich history of work presented at Theatre Project over its 40-year history.

The play's seamless integration of biography and poetry, ensemble theater and projections felt groundbreaking/unique/surreal/sensuous at the time. I'm challenged and excited in the opportunity and freedom available through new technologies, as well as traditional techniques, to again explore the play's ever intriguing subject, Yukio Mishima.

WHO ARE “WE”?

“We” starts with me. I’m John Wilson, the producer/director of “A Fierce Longing.” When I was asked to direct something for Baltimore Theatre Project’s 40th anniversary season I immediately thought of this play, which I saw there in 1978. Milwaukee’s Theatre X brought a stunning multi-media production of their original play to Baltimore and New York (where it played at the Performance Garage and later won an Obie Award).

“We” holds Japanese novelist Yukio Mishima at the core of the project. “A Fierce Longing” chronicles his life, his work, and his turmoil. A complex man, Mishima struggled with family issues, wrestled with a St. Sebastian fetish and homosexual desires, sought fame and celebrity for his Nobel-nominated writing, and desired to honor the Emperor and the Samurai tradition through his ultra-conservative political views and formation of a militia. Ultimately, he committed seppuku, ritual suicide, in 1970.

“We” includes playwright John Schneider. He is thrilled that we are presenting a new production of his play.

The “We” continues with Anne Cantler Fulwiler, producing director of Theatre Project, and the theatre’s talented staff. And the “We” includes an amazing production team including a Japanese No theater scholar, the premiere sword and weapons coach in the region, a brilliant young lighting designer, a composer of national renown, and an awesome costumer who worked for many years at Arena Stage.

WHY DO WE NEED THE MONEY?

To paraphrase Sondheim, “Art isn’t easy” – nor is it cheap. To pull off all the technical aspects of the show, we need your support. To compensate the talented production team, we need your support. To secure the wisdom of our Japanese cultural consultant, we need your support. And to fly in and house the playwright to tap into his brilliant mind and depth of experience, we need your support.

In fall of 2011 I launched a traditional direct mail campaign to raise funds for this production. That campaign did very well and raised about $6000. Now, for phase II, I’m putting my faith in this online campaign with a goal of $3000. Help me prove that this can be successful.

I am passionate about this project and excited to begin rehearsals. Reaching our goal by April 30 will allow me to give my total attention to the cast and rehearsal process rather than fundraising. After all, this is about the art! 

Consider, please, an apple. The inside is invisible. There, at the heart, shut up within the flesh, the core trembles in darkness. It knows it exists, but the knowledge is not enough. It wants to see. For the core of the apple, the only sure proof of existence is to see itself. There is a solution. It's for a knife to come plunging into the apple, splitting it open, exposing the core to the same light as the surface. Thus...the core of the apple sacrifices existence for one perfect moment of sight. Oh, the fierce longing simply to see without words! Oh, for the knife to cut through my flesh and my shattered senses close that impossible gap!

                                                                        —Yukio Mishima

 

OKAY, YOU DONATED. NOW WHAT DO YOU DO?

You need to tell someone. You need to tell your friends, family, and neighbors – and encourage them to donate as well. Tell them in English! Tell them in Japanese! Just tell them!

story:
In Our Prime (IOP) formed with a single idea: improvise stories. The first time IOP met we did a scene start that went 40 minutes with a full story arc. In disbelief, we did another scene start which ended with a full story at 35 minutes.

And ever since that day, we tell stories. In Ryan’s living room, on campus at RLM or on stage at the Hideout, we tell improvised, grounded stories. In Our Prime is all about our four storytellers: Gloria Rabil Bankler, Jessica Arjet, Ryan Hill, and Paul Normandin. In July, IOP will head to the Improv Festival Oklahoma! After that, we are heading to the prestigious festival in Hawaii: Improvaganza.

I know what you are thinking, they have been playing just a few months and they have invites from OK and HI? All four of us are as flattered as we are excited. We are flattered that others like our art too. We are excited that we get to share our art with as many people as possible. Improvaganza is a great place for us to learn and share our stories. While in Hawaii we plan on performing, watching other troupes, taking classes, and you know Hawaii things. Then we plan on coming home and telling you stories of our experiences.

Hawaii is a big expense. And this is where you come in! We would like to travel to Hawaii for the Festival. We cannot do it without your help. We need about $4,400 total. Part of that is our rooms and food while we are there—about $1,400. We plan on covering all of the on island expenses. But the flights are the big cost. We estimated $750 round-trip per person or $3,000.

In trade for helping us with our storytelling art, we plan on providing you our time and skills. Some of them are silly and we would “give you” or “do them for you” for free (we will, just ask). Some are things we can do to be of service or benefit to you that you may find of real value.

We have some great items on our list: mothering, storytelling, slap and tickle, Volcano Gods, how about a nice meal with friends? We have a wide range so check them out. If you can, please buy some. (Ask about our items or things you would like on the list.)

If you can’t afford it, we understand. But do consider taking a minute and telling your other friends about your In Our Prime friends. The arts have always relied on patronage. We want to share our stories at this prestigious festival. Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word.

We appreciate you reading through our list. Thanks in advance for your help!

story:
The Artery Playwrights Project
is proud to announce the world premiere of: 

Linthead 

By Brian Forrester

Directed by Max Montel


May 11 - June 3
Santa Monica Playhouse
Main Stage, A Guest Production


During the chaos of the General Textile Strike of 1934, in a world of fire-and- brimstone sermons, front porch sing-alongs, hoochie- coochie girls, and lungs full of cotton dust, Linthead is the story of a South Carolina cotton mill worker who hurts everyone he loves when he stands up for his rights.  


With America in crisis, mounting economic disparity, and families losing their homes as jobs become obsolete and hard to find, the 1930's may be a distant shadow of history, but Linthead could not be a more immediate and necessary play. An intensely original and uniquely theatrical piece, it deals strongly with the mythology of heroes and the family stories we fiercely protect.



The Artists

The Artery Playwrights Project is a non-profit theatre arts collective dedicated to the production of new American plays. Playwright Brian Forrester is grateful to have Director Max Montel and Producer Candace Brekka leading a talented creative team that includes Designer Meg Cunningham, Music Director Tommy Bourgeois and Stage Manager Kelli Sinclair, along with our cast of brilliant actors and musicians: 

Amanda Jane Cooper

Patrick Dillon Curry 

Michael Dempsey

Tristan Farmer 

Kristi Israel 

Eddie King 

Sara Lindsey 

Nick Marcucci 

PJ Marshall 

Chelsea Vincent

 
 
We Need Your Help

Every one of these volunteer artists is thrilled to be part of bringing this powerful new play to the American stage, but they can't do it without your help. Creating theatre is a major undertaking that requires enormous skill and resources. 

With your support, we can cover many of the immense costs associated with a production of this magnitude.  For example:

Your $25 donation will cover the cost of painting one of our sets.
Your $50 donation will pay for constructing one costume.
Your $100 donation will get us a rehearsal room for one evening.
Your $500 donation will rent a theatre for one performance. 


Consider Making A Contribution

Please consider making a contribution in any amount to our Indie GoGo campaign. Donations are tax deductible and all proceeds go toward making this exciting production of a new American play possible.  We only have a limited amount of time to fund this production, so please don't wait to contribute. Every little bit counts.

Thank you very much. We hope to see you at the theatre.
