Thank you very much. We hope to see you at the theatre.

story:
Why fund a project that has “been funded”? All Contributions over our $1,250 goal will go towards a full production of Dirty Laundry, (Cycle 2) This fall. 

  • If we get $3000 ($1600 towards Cycle 2) we will be able to do Cycle 2 as a fully-produced, hour-long piece in a theatre space 
  • If we get $2,500 ($1100 towards Cycle 2) we will probably be able to a costume-free, lights-free, hour-long piece for Cycle 2
  • If we get $2,000 ($600 towards Cycle 2) we will be able to do an hour-long piece rehearsing at a free venue and performing somewhere cheap or free 
  • If we get $1,750 ($350 towards Cycle 2) we will be able to do an hour-long piece rehearsing and performing in a local park

ABOUT DIRTY LAUNDRY (CYCLE 1)

We need a place to do our Dirty Laundry!

The Collaboratory and Inkblot Ensemble need your help to bring the first phase of our collaboratively devised physical theatre piece, Dirty Laundry, to the EXIT Theatre in August 2012. Your generous contributions will help us pay for rehearsal space, a performance venue, and production materials ranging from postcards to costumes.

Dirty Laundry is a play about the things we wish we could hide; explored through text, song, movement, and laundry. Inspired by the laundress scene from Spanish playwright Federico García Lorca’s play, Yerma, the piece delves into the darkness and the dirtiness, but also the sexiness and sweetness that can be revealed when we think no one is looking.  Viewed through the lens of the intensely personal act of washing someone’s clothes, Dirty Laundry probes into the literal and metaphorical dirt of daily living.  How do we hide secrets and how are they revealed? What is said and what is left unsaid? Not everything will come out in the wash, but what does is shocking.

Six actresses: (Hannah Gaff, Emlyn Guiney, Maria Leigh, Marilet Martinez, Erin Maxon, and Liz Wand) and Director Amy Clare Tasker will work collaboratively to explore these themes, joining poetic language with rhythmic physicality and domestic work songs. In this short piece, the laundresses, only peripheral characters in Yerma, will take center stage and begin to speak - through Lorca’s words, through new text, through movement, and through song.  From what Lorca called “a tragic poem in three acts” springs a night filled with dirty secrets, coming clean, and some things that are wrecked beyond repair.  

Why this project is unique:

  • It is an all female production - both on and off stage.  In addition to the collaborators mentioned above we will be working with dramaturg Caroline Parsons and stage manager Diann Michele Leo.
  • It is a new work collaboratively devised by the ensemble and the director.
  • It will unite adventurous physicality with rigorous textwork and song.


Where your contributions will go:

  • Six weeks of rehearsal space
  • Two nights of performance rental at San Francisco’s EXIT Theatre.
  • Minimal props and costumes
  • Minimal publicity materials
  • Any additional funds will support the future development and production of Dirty Laundry

All of us working on the production of Dirty Laundry want to say thank you.  Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!  Yes, you the incredible people who have donated and those of you who are reading this and are considering donating.  We have been floored by your generosity, both in terms of your donations and in terms of your support of this work.  Thank you for telling us how much this piece means to you and how excited you are to see it in August.  Because of you, because of your support, because of your love,  because we want to share this first cycle with all of you, we’re adding a third night: Thursday August 9th.  And because it’s FREE - it’s our gift to you.  (We’ve been so excited along the way that we forgot to say that before, but yes, the show is free.)


But wait, there’s more, a lot more, a load more.  We’ve been amazed by you, our community, who clearly want to see this work made, made well, and made sooner rather than later.  We feel inspired by you, inspired by the creative team that has drawn together to make this work, inspired by the stories you are sharing, inspired by the research we are doing, and inspired by the hunger for this work to happen now. 

We knew that the August showing would be the start of a longer piece, that 25 minutes was not enough to explore everything we wanted to, but we thought we would have to wait at least a year to start working on a full production. We will make the first cycle in August and then we’re committing to making a full production right away.  We’re clearing our schedules starting in October, we’re looking for a venue, and we’re saying yes!

Dirty Laundry is something special.  It has an electric energy, a life of its own.  It went from a few of us sharing a copy of Yerma. Every dollar you give us from now until the end of the campaign will go directly into a full production of Dirty Laundry beginning rehearsals this fall.  We underestimated ourselves, we underestimated you - we won’t make that mistake again.  Your contributions will help determine the scope and scale of our full production and we know that it is going to be an incredible adventure.  Thank you for all you have given and thank you for what is yet to come.

-The Collaboratory

CLICK HERE FOR A VIDEO ABOUT THIS CHANGE!!



Thank you so much for your support!

ABOUT THE COLLABORATORY
Founded by Emlyn Guiney, Maria Leigh, and Erin Maxon, The Collaboratory is a collaborative laboratory for the exploration and creation of physical theatre. Using an iterative and playful process, we devise theater that celebrates connection, simplicity, wonder, and depth. Our process is dynamic, pairing adventurous physicality with rigorous text work. The Collaboratory’s first work, The Telling, was produced by Theater Pop and premiered at The Red Poppy Arthouse in October 2011. For more information on the Collaboratory, including video work samples, please visit our website at www.thecollaboratorygroup.org.

ABOUT INKBLOT ENSEMBLE DIRECTOR, AMY CLARE TASKER
Amy is a director, playwright, a founding member of Inkblot Ensemble, associate artist with Atmos Theatre and Cutting Ball Theater, and artist in residence at EXIT Theatre. As a founding member of Inkblot Ensemble, Amy has developed and directed All’s Fair and Satellites, new plays inspired by ancient mythology. For Cutting Ball, she has directed four plays for The Hidden Classics Reading Series, and assistant-directed Eugenie Chan’s Bone to Pick & Diadem (dir. Rob Melrose) and Madame Ho (dir. Rob Melrose – staged reading) as well as Will Eno’s Thom Pain (based on nothing) (dir. Marissa Wolf). This fall she will assistant direct Strindberg Cycle: The Chamber Plays in Rep under artistic director Rob Melrose. Elsewhere in the Bay Area, she has directed Alice in Wonderland for Atmos Theatre; Antigone for San Francisco Theater Pub’s Theban Chronicles, and Daniel Heath’s short play Nothing Works for the Bay One Acts Festival IX. She has directed for the San Francisco Olympians Festival, where she will premiere her new play Phoebe & Theia, or How to Get to Tartarus this December. She is currently collaborating with playwright Megan Cohen to create a transmedia online and live theater piece revisioning Helen of Troy. Amy holds a B.A in Drama with Honors from U.C. Irvine and has also studied playwriting and directing at the University of Manchester/Royal Exchange Theatre and recently participated in Directors Lab West in Los Angeles. More at www.amyclaretasker.com.

story:
The Pipeline Project:

Georgina grew up on a mountain, in a province rich with oil. Her ancestors spoke Norweigan. Jonathan was born by the Skeena River in the Tsimshian Nation to post-war immigrants from the Netherlands.

The proposed path for the Enbridge Northern Gateway Pipeline passes through many areas with endangered languages. We are interested in the language people use about pipelines, the languages which precede pipelines, and the language of progress. Architect Theatre, along with Siminovitch Protege award-winning director Anita Rochon and acoustic artist and researcher Jennifer Schine, are creating a play, currently titled The Pipeline Project, using recorded interviews and live theatre to address issues of communication, environment and economics.

What we are doing:

Between November 27 and December 17, 2012, we will travel in Northern BC and interview a cross section of people: those strongly against and for the pipeline, residents of First Nations communities, politicians, industry representatives, and activists. We will attend Joint Review Panel Hearings in Prince George and Prince Rupert. We will be running theatre workshops with local high schools to engage with the communities to which we travel. This period is dedicated to research, and we will be creating and developing the play through 2013, and plan to eventually tour The Pipeline Project across Canada to encourage national discussion. 

Who we are:

Architect Theatre is an indepedent company that produces entertaining and thought-provoking research-based plays that engages with the human stories behind contemporary issues.
 
Our first play, Highway 63: The Fort Mac Show, was about the community at the heart of the Oil Sands project, and has toured Canada over the last several years. For more information, visit http://architecttheatre.com.
 
Our second production, This Must Be The Place: The CN Tower Show played at Theatre Passe Muraille in Toronto, October 4 - 27, 2012. Created through interviews and research, this was an entertaining and surprising exploration of life in Canada's largest city. For more info, visit www.passemuraille.on.ca.
 

What we need:

The money we raise through Indiegogo will support our artists day-to-day as they're on the road, making this research phase possible! We have already raised enough to cover the bulk of our travel, and are staying with generous billets in the communities in which we travel. We are on a bare-bones budget at this stage and every bit of support means a great deal to us. 
 
Here's what your money will do:
 
$800    - A round-trip Greyhound bus ticket for Georgina Beaty,
            Anita Rochon and acoustic ecologist Jennifer Schine to  
            come to Prince George
 
$1,280 - $20 a day to each artist to help with food costs on the
             road
 
$500   - Gas. It's a complicated relationship, but we need it to 
           get from Prince George to Prince Rupert and back again. 
 
Our first development of Highway 63: The Fort Mac Show was similarly funded through a combination of generous personal donations and in-kind support, and that created a show that has toured the country from Vancouver to St. John's, fostering a dialogue about the personal stories behind a national issue.
 
With your support, we will research with integrity and honesty.
Please send us an email and start a conversation with us. We'd love to talk. That's kinda what we do. contact@architecttheatre.com

story:
Una producción de Ariana Sacristán

Women that love each other, seeking desperately for a child. Mothers with children, desperately seeking to assure their happiness.  Disoriented children, desperate to find their place. Stories of people finding their path in life. And love that permeates everything, that allows everything, the good and the bad.  

I first encountered “El Viento en un Violín”, written by the Argentinian playwright Claudio Tolcachir, at the Cervantino Festival in 2013 and it was love at first sight! I had just spent the last 90 minutes wishing I had brought a diaper so that I didn’t have to worry about peeing my pants from laughing so hard. However, I felt very conflicted. Why had I laughed so much? The stories that I had just witnessed had been dark, twisted and deeply moving and yet the comedy never left the play. How was it possible to feel so many opposing emotions at the same time? I spent hours with my friends after the show trying to unpack everything we had just experienced and we found ourselves in deep discussion over the issues of gender, sexuality and class that had been so beautifully embedded in the storytelling of the show. I couldn't believe that a play could create such a productive dialogue on these complex issues. 

Fast forward six years and I find myself wanting to produce a play. But not any play. I want a play that forces the audience to reflect because I believe that theatre should have value beyond entertainment. I want a comedy because I firmly believe that comedy has the power to penetrate the audience in a way that tragedy can’t. And finally, I want a Latin American play, because I am fed up of going to the theatre in Mexico City and seeing only translations of American plays that do not speak to the realities we face. In my search for a play that fit all these requirements, I think of “El Viento en un Violín” that in all these years has refused to leave my mind. It’s perfect! 

I immediately embarked on a journey to acquire the rights and get a team together. I am now happy to announce that I have both. Now, all we need is the funding to get this play on its feet and be able to do a 12 performance run in 2020! 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - - -

Mujeres que se aman, buscando desesperadamente  un hijo. Madres con hijos, desesperadas por asegurarles la felicidad. Hijos desorientados, desesperados por encontrar su lugar. Historias de seres buscándose la vida. Y el amor que lo atraviesa todo, que todo lo permite, lo bueno y lo malo.

Mi primer encuentro con la obra de teatro “El Viento en un Violín” del dramaturgo argentino Claudio Tolcachir fue en el Festival Cervantino en el 2013 y fue amor a primera vista. Me pasé los 90 minutos de la obra deseando que tuviera puesto un pañal para no tenerme que preocupar de hacerme pipí de la risa. Sin embargo, me sentía muy conflictuada. ¿Por qué me reí tanto? Las historias que acababa de presenciar eran obscuras, torcidas y conmovedoras, pero la comedia no dejó ningún momento la obra. ¿Cómo era posible sentir tantas emociones contradictorias al mismo tiempo? Pasé horas con mis amigos después de la obra intentando desenvolver lo que acabamos de ver y terminamos en una discusión profunda sobre los temas del género, la sexualidad y las clases sociales que habían sido tan bellamente cosidos a la narrativa de la obra. Estaba muy sorprendida de que una obra de teatro pudiera crear un diálogo tan productivo sobre estos temas complejos. 

Saltamos 6 años y me encuentro con el deseo de producir una obra de teatro. Pero no cualquier obra de teatro.  Yo quiero una obra que fuerce al público a reflexionar, porque creo que el teatro va más allá de sólo entretener. Yo quiero una comedia porque yo creo firmemente que la comedia tiene el poder de penetrar al público de una forma que la tragedia no puede. Yo quiero un obra Latinoamericana, porque estoy cansada de ir al teatro en la CDMX y solo ver traducciones de obras Estadounidenses que no hablan de la realidades que enfrentamos en México. En mi búsqueda por una obra que cumpla todos mis requerimientos, pienso en “El Viento en un Violín”, aquella obra que se rehusó a salir de mi cabeza durante todos estos años. ¡Es perfecta!

Inmediatamente embarqué en una aventura para conseguir los derechos de autor y armar un equipo. Estoy muy emocionada de anunciar que ya tengo ambos. ¡Ahora solo necesitamos financiamiento para montar esta obra y dar 12 presentaciones en el 2020!

Cristian Magaloni

Director

Actor y director de teatro en México y España. Egresado del Estudio Corazza para el Actor en Madrid, España. Entre sus trabajos más destacados se encuentran: “Comedia sin título” de Juan Carlos Corazza y  “La gaviota” de Juan Carlos Montagna. Y ha realizado montajes como: “Juegos a la hora de la siesta” de Roma Mahiue y “Calígula” de Albert Camus.

-

Director

He is a theater director and actor in Mexico and Spain. Graduate from the Corrazza Studio for the Actor in Madrid, Spain. He has worked in numerous plays including: “Comedia sin título” by juan Carlos Corazza and “La gaviota” by juan Carlos Montagna. His work as a director includes plays like: “juegos a la hora de la siesta” by Roma Mahiue and “Calígula” by Albert Camus. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Ariana Sacristán

Producción y Elenco

Estudió la licenciatura en artes dramáticas en Vassar College en Nueva York, donde sacó mención honorífica. En Nueva York actuó en obras como Love and Information, Into the Woods, La Hija de Rapuccini y protagonizó Crímenes del Corazón en el papel de Meg Magrath. Durante sus estudios hizo una estancia en la Escuela de Artes Teatrales de Moscú donde salió como Anya en El Jardín de los Cerezos. En la Ciudad de México ha actuado en obras como:  Los Últimos Apóstoles, Una Puta Crítica y Antes Muerta que Sencilla, y en cortometrajes como: Piérdeme Suavemente, 8 de Septiembre y Okinawa,  así como ha actuado en la serie de televisión Rosario Tijeras.

-

Producer and part of the crew.

She got a bachelor’s degree in from Vassar College in New York, where she graduated with honors. Once in New York she participated in plays like: Love and Information, Into the Woods, La Hija de Rapuccini and starred in Crímenes del Corazón as Meg Magrath. During her degree, she did a stay in Moscow where she studied in the Moscow Art Theatre where she starred in the play El Jardín de los Cerezos as Anya. In Mexico City she has acted in play such as: Los Últimos Apóstoles, Una Puta Crítica y Antes Muerta que Sencilla. She has also worked in short films such as: Piérdeme Suavemente, 8 de Septiembre y Okinawa, as well as in the tv show Rosario Tijeras. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Daniel Mandoki

Elenco -Dario-

Es un actor recién graduado de la escuela Pace University en Nueva York, en donde obtuvo su BFA en actuación. En Nueva York actuó en obras como “Bodas de Sangre” y “A lie of the mind”. También tiene experiencia actuando en cortometrajes como “Gao Year” y “Neither”. En octubre se estrenará el filme “Olimpia” de JM Cravioto, el cual representa su debut cinematográfico. 

-

Cast -Dario-

He just graduated from Pace University in New York, where he got his BFA in acting. In New York he starred in plays such as “Bodas de sangre” and “A lie of the mind”. He has also worked on short films like “Gap Year” and “Neither”. In october he will make his acting debut in the film “Olimpia” by JM Cravioto. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Danilo Méndez

Difusión y Publicidad

Danilo Méndez es un matemático de la UNAM y uno de los fundadores de Markita Marketing, una agencia de marketing digital. Ha trabajado con mas de 20 marcas y ha liderado todas las campañas de publicidad pautada de la agencia. Tiene certificaciones en Google Ads y Facebook Business. 

-

Advertising

Danilo Méndez is a mathematician from the UNAM, and one of the founders of Markita Marketing, a digital marketing agency. He has worked with over 20 different brands and has led marketing campaigns with paid media. He is certified in Google Ads and Facebook Business. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Mexico is living through a time of social change that, for the first time, has opened up a dialogue about the classicism, racism, sexism and homophobia that permeate our society. This play is our way of contributing to the conversation. Fist of all, we are excited to perform a play that shows lesbianism, which is extremely underrepresented in the performing arts and present it without the fetishism that so often accompanies it.  Also, we are going to adapt this play to a Mexican context so that we can speak directly to the way that these issues manifest themselves in Mexico, allowing the audience to identify themselves and therefore forcing them to reflect. If we are successful, we hope the audience will feel compelled to continue the conversation outside of the theatre, the same way I did when I first saw this show. 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

En México estamos viviendo una época de cambio social que, por primera vez, ha abierto la conversación del clasismo, racismo, sexismo y homofobia que contamina a nuestra sociedad. Esta obra es nuestra forma de contribuir a la conversación.  Nos emociona presentar una obra que enseñe lesbianismo, que pocas veces se ve representando en las artes escénicas, sin el fetichismo que tan comúnmente lo acompaña. También, queremos adaptar esta obra a un contexto mexicano para que podemos evidenciar directamente las formas en que estos temas se manifiestan en México, logrando así que el público se identifique y sea vea forzado a reflexionar. Si tenemos éxito en esto, esperamos que el público sienta la necesidad de seguir con la conversación afuera del teatro, de la misma manera que yo me sentí cuando vi esta obra por primera vez.

 

 

Producing a show is expensive and more often than not artists take a pay cut in order to make the production possible. I don’t want this to happen. I am committed to paying the director, actors and designers the decent wage they deserve for their hard work and talent.  You can help me with this commitment by donating! 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Producir teatro requiere de un presupuesto alto. Es muy común que para lograr una producción con pocos recursos, los artistas participantes no reciben el salario que les corresponde. No queremos que esto suceda.  Yo me comprometo a pagarles al director, los actores y los diseñadores un salario digno por su trabajo y talento. ¡Tú me puedes ayudar con este compromiso donando al proyecto!

 

 

If you can't afford to contribute to the campaign, that's ok! You can support us by sharing this campaign with a friend. Send them this link or click the share buttons at the top of the campaign. 

We're grateful for whatever help you can give. Thank you for helping us make this happen! 

We hope to see you at the show!

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Si no puedes contribuir a la campana, no hay problema. Puedes ayudarnos compartiendo esta campaña con un amigo. Mándale el link o pica el botón de compartir en la parte superior de esta página.

Estaremos agradecidos con lo que nos puedas dar. ¡Gracias por ayudarnos hacer esto una realidad!

¡Esperamos verlos en la función!
story_txt:
Una producción de Ariana Sacristán
Women that love each other, seeking desperately for a child. Mothers with children, desperately seeking to assure their happiness.  Disoriented children, desperate to find their place. Stories of people finding their path in life. And love that permeates everything, that allows everything, the good and the bad.  
I first encountered “El Viento en un Violín”, written by the Argentinian playwright Claudio Tolcachir, at the Cervantino Festival in 2013 and it was love at first sight! I had just spent the last 90 minutes wishing I had brought a diaper so that I didn’t have to worry about peeing my pants from laughing so hard. However, I felt very conflicted. Why had I laughed so much? The stories that I had just witnessed had been dark, twisted and deeply moving and yet the comedy never left the play. How was it possible to feel so many opposing emotions at the same time? I spent hours with my friends after the show trying to unpack everything we had just experienced and we found ourselves in deep discussion over the issues of gender, sexuality and class that had been so beautifully embedded in the storytelling of the show. I couldn't believe that a play could create such a productive dialogue on these complex issues. 
Fast forward six years and I find myself wanting to produce a play. But not any play. I want a play that forces the audience to reflect because I believe that theatre should have value beyond entertainment. I want a comedy because I firmly believe that comedy has the power to penetrate the audience in a way that tragedy can’t. And finally, I want a Latin American play, because I am fed up of going to the theatre in Mexico City and seeing only translations of American plays that do not speak to the realities we face. In my search for a play that fit all these requirements, I think of “El Viento en un Violín” that in all these years has refused to leave my mind. It’s perfect! 
I immediately embarked on a journey to acquire the rights and get a team together. I am now happy to announce that I have both. Now, all we need is the funding to get this play on its feet and be able to do a 12 performance run in 2020! 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - - -
Mujeres que se aman, buscando desesperadamente  un hijo. Madres con hijos, desesperadas por asegurarles la felicidad. Hijos desorientados, desesperados por encontrar su lugar. Historias de seres buscándose la vida. Y el amor que lo atraviesa todo, que todo lo permite, lo bueno y lo malo.
Mi primer encuentro con la obra de teatro “El Viento en un Violín” del dramaturgo argentino Claudio Tolcachir fue en el Festival Cervantino en el 2013 y fue amor a primera vista. Me pasé los 90 minutos de la obra deseando que tuviera puesto un pañal para no tenerme que preocupar de hacerme pipí de la risa. Sin embargo, me sentía muy conflictuada. ¿Por qué me reí tanto? Las historias que acababa de presenciar eran obscuras, torcidas y conmovedoras, pero la comedia no dejó ningún momento la obra. ¿Cómo era posible sentir tantas emociones contradictorias al mismo tiempo? Pasé horas con mis amigos después de la obra intentando desenvolver lo que acabamos de ver y terminamos en una discusión profunda sobre los temas del género, la sexualidad y las clases sociales que habían sido tan bellamente cosidos a la narrativa de la obra. Estaba muy sorprendida de que una obra de teatro pudiera crear un diálogo tan productivo sobre estos temas complejos. 
Saltamos 6 años y me encuentro con el deseo de producir una obra de teatro. Pero no cualquier obra de teatro.  Yo quiero una obra que fuerce al público a reflexionar, porque creo que el teatro va más allá de sólo entretener. Yo quiero una comedia porque yo creo firmemente que la comedia tiene el poder de penetrar al público de una forma que la tragedia no puede. Yo quiero un obra Latinoamericana, porque estoy cansada de ir al teatro en la CDMX y solo ver traducciones de obras Estadounidenses que no hablan de la realidades que enfrentamos en México. En mi búsqueda por una obra que cumpla todos mis requerimientos, pienso en “El Viento en un Violín”, aquella obra que se rehusó a salir de mi cabeza durante todos estos años. ¡Es perfecta!
Inmediatamente embarqué en una aventura para conseguir los derechos de autor y armar un equipo. Estoy muy emocionada de anunciar que ya tengo ambos. ¡Ahora solo necesitamos financiamiento para montar esta obra y dar 12 presentaciones en el 2020!


Cristian Magaloni
Director
Actor y director de teatro en México y España. Egresado del Estudio Corazza para el Actor en Madrid, España. Entre sus trabajos más destacados se encuentran: “Comedia sin título” de Juan Carlos Corazza y  “La gaviota” de Juan Carlos Montagna. Y ha realizado montajes como: “Juegos a la hora de la siesta” de Roma Mahiue y “Calígula” de Albert Camus.
-
Director
He is a theater director and actor in Mexico and Spain. Graduate from the Corrazza Studio for the Actor in Madrid, Spain. He has worked in numerous plays including: “Comedia sin título” by juan Carlos Corazza and “La gaviota” by juan Carlos Montagna. His work as a director includes plays like: “juegos a la hora de la siesta” by Roma Mahiue and “Calígula” by Albert Camus. 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 
Ariana Sacristán
Producción y Elenco
Estudió la licenciatura en artes dramáticas en Vassar College en Nueva York, donde sacó mención honorífica. En Nueva York actuó en obras como Love and Information, Into the Woods, La Hija de Rapuccini y protagonizó Crímenes del Corazón en el papel de Meg Magrath. Durante sus estudios hizo una estancia en la Escuela de Artes Teatrales de Moscú donde salió como Anya en El Jardín de los Cerezos. En la Ciudad de México ha actuado en obras como:  Los Últimos Apóstoles, Una Puta Crítica y Antes Muerta que Sencilla, y en cortometrajes como: Piérdeme Suavemente, 8 de Septiembre y Okinawa,  así como ha actuado en la serie de televisión Rosario Tijeras.
-
Producer and part of the crew.
She got a bachelor’s degree in from Vassar College in New York, where she graduated with honors. Once in New York she participated in plays like: Love and Information, Into the Woods, La Hija de Rapuccini and starred in Crímenes del Corazón as Meg Magrath. During her degree, she did a stay in Moscow where she studied in the Moscow Art Theatre where she starred in the play El Jardín de los Cerezos as Anya. In Mexico City she has acted in play such as: Los Últimos Apóstoles, Una Puta Crítica y Antes Muerta que Sencilla. She has also worked in short films such as: Piérdeme Suavemente, 8 de Septiembre y Okinawa, as well as in the tv show Rosario Tijeras. 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Daniel Mandoki
Elenco -Dario-
Es un actor recién graduado de la escuela Pace University en Nueva York, en donde obtuvo su BFA en actuación. En Nueva York actuó en obras como “Bodas de Sangre” y “A lie of the mind”. También tiene experiencia actuando en cortometrajes como “Gao Year” y “Neither”. En octubre se estrenará el filme “Olimpia” de JM Cravioto, el cual representa su debut cinematográfico. 
-
Cast -Dario-
He just graduated from Pace University in New York, where he got his BFA in acting. In New York he starred in plays such as “Bodas de sangre” and “A lie of the mind”. He has also worked on short films like “Gap Year” and “Neither”. In october he will make his acting debut in the film “Olimpia” by JM Cravioto. 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - 

Danilo Méndez
Difusión y Publicidad
Danilo Méndez es un matemático de la UNAM y uno de los fundadores de Markita Marketing, una agencia de marketing digital. Ha trabajado con mas de 20 marcas y ha liderado todas las campañas de publicidad pautada de la agencia. Tiene certificaciones en Google Ads y Facebook Business. 
-
Advertising
Danilo Méndez is a mathematician from the UNAM, and one of the founders of Markita Marketing, a digital marketing agency. He has worked with over 20 different brands and has led marketing campaigns with paid media. He is certified in Google Ads and Facebook Business. 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - -

story:
My name is Jamaal Burkmar, i'm an award winning contemporary choreographer based in the UK and I've spent this last year reimagining my practice for online audiences. I've been really interested in finding ways to demystify contemporary dance and dance theatre for people who aren't exposed to it and my next step is to create a series of roundtable discussions that are both interesting AND entertaining. I want to work with artists that are engaging and thought provoking but don't fall into the trap of speaking only to the initiated dance audience we already have. 


*************

At this point in time, it's hard to sell an idea that people haven't seen before with regards to dance and contemporary art. Right now i'm putting my own personal finances into the project and giving my time up for free, but unfortunately it's not enough.

This fundraiser will help me to hire the camera equipment for the shoots that I haven't been able to purchase myself, rent the space and pay a fee to bring in the voices I want to work with.

If we can raise the entire £4000 which is a hard task, we'd be able to create at least 2 to 3 half hour episodes of this show totally independently. If not then whatever funds we would raise would be used to try and secure funding from other sources but would however push our start date further away.

*************

Please check out the rewards for supporters. And PLEASE, if you have input, queries or concerns, drop us a message in the campaign. We're all about engagement and discourse so we want to hear from people and their thoughts on this idea.

story:
What is ReAct Theatre?

Artistic Director, David Hsieh, started ReAct Theatre 25 years ago and continues to produce theatre in the NW. He picks the perfect venue for each show he puts in his seasons. SALTY will open August 1st at the lovely 12th Ave Arts space on Capital Hill.

"ReAct strives to explore the diversity of our community and produce innovative, quality theatrical entertainment through multi-ethnic and non-traditional casting" ~David Hsieh

Why SALTY?

"A dear friend of mine was in the world premiere of SALTY in New York. I caught the show and I fell in love with it, and I knew I had to bring SALTY to Seattle" ~ David Hsieh 

What made you write SALTY?

We are thrilled that playwright, AJ Clauss, will be joining us for rehearsals and opening night of SALTY in Seattle. I recently asked AJ, what inspired you to write SALTY?

"Several years ago I ‘d heard about two male penguins that fell in love at a zoo and had never really heard of something like that happen before. More than their story, I was fixated on two circumstances around it: the media coverage, and the gender identity of penguins. In 2016, Kevin Matthews wrote an article on how gender roles were killing the crested penguin. The rules they have placed on themselves, on the female and male gender, are slowly killing them. I think this was my way in to the play."

"I grew up in small-town, Indiana and am working through my own traumas as a queer person from the midwest every day. In high school, when things were looking a little rough for me, my best friend got me a job at the Louisville Zoo, playing the Tin Man, every Thursday through Sunday, talking to kids, showing off my new heart... So many of my co-workers were queer and I grew so much in such a short span of time. The first man I ever kissed was the actor playing Superman at the zoo. And a couple years later, my friend who got me the job died rather tragically, he was the cowardly lion and the bravest person I knew. Some ten years later, I am writing a play set in a zoo, and I start seeing him in my dreams. It felt nice to reconnect with him, and now I understand what it means when my mentor says to write a play for the dead."

Art is Life and Life is Art

"When I was working on this play, my hometown was underwater, California was on fire, and it was the deadliest hurricane season since 2005. Mother Nature started burning the edges of my play, and I realized, it was never my play, it's hers. She gives and she takes and I wanted to honor that. I wanted to showcase our privilege as humans on this planet, and try to appreciate life and Earth in a way that isn't berating on climate change, but is witness to it."        ~ AJ Clauss

Why do we need YOUR help?

We have a mighty cast of 7 incredible artists who will bring this story to life. We have amazing designers who will take the show to the next level. David Hsieh, is getting posters designed, flyers for marketing, gathering props, creating wardrobe and so much more. This campaign will help pay these artists and all that goes into bringing POWERFUL theatre to the stage!

"There are 14 characters in the play, 7 zookeepers, 7 penguins, and a fox-- all intersecting and colliding their stories into one another-- and inevitably all pushing towards the same conclusion-- the same light. The actors double as animals and zookeepers and this is a really special part of the play, I think. To be the caretaker and the taken care of-- allows for 14 characters to seem more filled-in and wholesome that you could typically do in a 90-minute play because their storylines speak to one another. I think it’s a tasty experience to see both the beginning and the end at the same time." ~ AJ Clauss

story:
The Rosin Box

We are the professional ballerinas, and dancers of City Ballet of San Diego, and we are raising funds to put on our own performances during our off layoff from our September - May season, in Downtown San Diego this Summer 2018. 

We are asking you and our community to help us raise the money to be able to perform three shows over the course of one weekend this summer. Three shows of brand new work, and never before seen ballets. These ballets will be choreographed - rehearsed - and performed, by none other than the dancers of City Ballet of San Diego themselves. 

Please help us make these performances a reality!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to guarentee the performance venue and overall success of putting on these shows, we are hoping to raise $4000 for The Rosin Box project. This money will go towards renting the venue, transporting a proper floor for the dancers to perform on, sound and lighting technitions, costumes, pointe shoes, marketing, concessions, and compensation for various other necessities and personel that go into putting on a production. 

For every pledge you make, The Rosin Box dancers want to extend a thank you:

$25 or more-

Postcard of 'The Rosin Box' to commemorate the show, signed by the dancers!

$50 or more- 

Limited edition high resolution print from 'The Rosin Box' by Carly Topazio Photography.

$100 or more-

Can't make it to the shows? You can still support the dancers and see what was created! Receive a copy of the performances via a DVD mailed out one week following the performances.

$200 or more-

Get a signed pair of pointe shoes that helped keep one of these professional ballerinas on their toes!

$300 or more-

Have your business or company ad placed in our performance programs!

$500 or more-

Exclusive opportunity to sit in on "The Rosin Box' dress rehearsal the night before opening night. Get an even more personal, and raw look at what goes into making.

$1000 or more-

Two tickets to one of City Ballet of San Diego's performances during their 2018/19 season

The Impact

Everyone knows the term "starving artists". As ballerinas we don't make livable wages. It's a harsh reality, but true. The bare minimum is what we're use to. Unfortunate as it is, we pursue this artform still. 

It is not greed, or the pursuit of success that drives us, but passion. We love what we do. We cannot live without what we do. We are ballerinas, and we would like to continue to share and communicate the art of dance as it is a necessarry component to that which we call life, not just for us, but for everyone.

As humans, we are all adept creatures genetically made up to feel and experience a wide range of emotions. Art, on every medium, is the one way in which we can translate, share, explain, discover, transcend, and explore those emotions. We NEED art, it is vital to us.... if we lacked this capacity of being infected by art, or even lacked art itself, people might be almost more savage still, and -above all- more separated from, and more hostile to, one another. 

Risks & Challenges

The major risk we face is not raising the necessary funds needed in time to be able to not only secure a performance venue, but to properly compensate the artists and individuals involved in making these shows a reality. 
If we do not raise enough to secure a venue, the unfortunate reality is that the performances will not take place. We will do everything in our power to see this does not happen, but we need the help our supporters to see this project through!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!

Help us get the word out and make some noise about fundraising for The Rosin Box! Remember that you can always use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign with others and on social media

We are asking you and our community to help us raise the money to be able to perform three shows over the course of one weekend this summer. Three shows of brand new work, and never before seen ballets. These ballets will be choreographed - rehearsed - and performed, by none other than the dancers of City Ballet of San Diego themselves. 
Please help us make these performances a reality!

What We Need & What You Get
In order to guarentee the performance venue and overall success of putting on these shows, we are hoping to raise $4000 for The Rosin Box project. This money will go towards renting the venue, transporting a proper floor for the dancers to perform on, sound and lighting technitions, costumes, pointe shoes, marketing, concessions, and compensation for various other necessities and personel that go into putting on a production. 
For every pledge you make, The Rosin Box dancers want to extend a thank you:
$25 or more-
Postcard of 'The Rosin Box' to commemorate the show, signed by the dancers!
$50 or more- 
Limited edition high resolution print from 'The Rosin Box' by Carly Topazio Photography.
$100 or more-
Can't make it to the shows? You can still support the dancers and see what was created! Receive a copy of the performances via a DVD mailed out one week following the performances.
$200 or more-
Get a signed pair of pointe shoes that helped keep one of these professional ballerinas on their toes!
$300 or more-
Have your business or company ad placed in our performance programs!
$500 or more-
Exclusive opportunity to sit in on "The Rosin Box' dress rehearsal the night before opening night. Get an even more personal, and raw look at what goes into making.
$1000 or more-
Two tickets to one of City Ballet of San Diego's performances during their 2018/19 season

The Impact
Everyone knows the term "starving artists". As ballerinas we don't make livable wages. It's a harsh reality, but true. The bare minimum is what we're use to. Unfortunate as it is, we pursue this artform still. 
It is not greed, or the pursuit of success that drives us, but passion. We love what we do. We cannot live without what we do. We are ballerinas, and we would like to continue to share and communicate the art of dance as it is a necessarry component to that which we call life, not just for us, but for everyone.
As humans, we are all adept creatures genetically made up to feel and experience a wide range of emotions. Art, on every medium, is the one way in which we can translate, share, explain, discover, transcend, and explore those emotions. We NEED art, it is vital to us.... if we lacked this capacity of being infected by art, or even lacked art itself, people might be almost more savage still, and -above all- more separated from, and more hostile to, one another. 

Risks & Challenges
The major risk we face is not raising the necessary funds needed in time to be able to not only secure a performance venue, but to properly compensate the artists and individuals involved in making these shows a reality. If we do not raise enough to secure a venue, the unfortunate reality is that the performances will not take place. We will do everything in our power to see this does not happen, but we need the help our supporters to see this project through!

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!
Help us get the word out and make some noise about fundraising for The Rosin Box! Remember that you can always use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign with others and on social media

story:
OVERVIEW. SHORT SUMMARY. WHAT WE NEED. WHAT YOU GET.

OVERVIEW

Growing up in Brooklyn, I always enjoyed plays by Mel Brooks, Neil Simon & Woody Allen. I like writing funny New York stories of the people, places and things that I love.

SHORT SUMMARY

This is a parody on the history of exploration past, present, & future. 

WHAT WE NEED.

We want to bring this to the Broadway Stage for ONE NIGHT ONLY (2) performances. We have costed out a line item budget that includes everything: SAG/AFTRA/EQUITY Actor salaries, Direction, Costumes, Theater Rental, Props, Sets, Promotion. etc.  It comes to $13,680.  We are asking for $20,000 to play it safe.

WHAT YOU GET.

We have perks(benefits) @ $25, $100, $1000, $2500, $5000

story:
Hello!

I hope this finds you well! I'm launching this campaign because I've written a play entitled, "My Life Is Not A Movie", which has been accepted into a writer's workshop program in June in Saratoga Springs, New York, called The Orchard Project. I'll be working with Broadway producer, Dani Davis and acclaimed director & writer, BT McNicholl, who's been on the creative team of a dozen Broadway productions and is the Artistic Director of the Palace Theatre in Stamford, Connecticut. I'm thrilled and honored to have this incredible opportunity to collaborate with such creative artists in such an inspiring setting as The Orchard Project provides.

The Orchard Project is a nonprofit organization and requests that each project contribute 50% of the funds required for the residency. I'm reaching out to you to see if you would be interested in helping me raise the capital. The goal I'm reaching for is $8,000. This money will be exclusively used to pay for artist fees, travel expenses, and room & board for my team while at The Orchard Project.

The goal of my week long tenure  at The Orchard Project, is to make the script as strong as it can possibly be. This will be of huge importance in the life of the play. I will not only be engaged in full time intensive collaboration with Ms. Davis and Mr. McNicholl, but will be exposed to the ideas and inspirations of other leading theatre artists from around the world who have also been invited to take part in the program. This is a huge opportunity for the development of this play.

A little bit about the play...

The play follows a middle aged man, who would die just to be a guest star in his own life. Hell, he'd kill just to get the audition. 

Using direct interaction with the audience, this play is a humorous and poignant exploration through the rabbit hole of the daily matters that confront the everyman in all of us: the fear of failure, of unmet expectations, the frantic search for a faith in something greater than ourselves, and the battle between personal success in our lifetime and the desire to leave a better world for our children. My goal is for the audience to walk away with a greater understanding of their own special place in this often confounding world and, regardless of their belief system, to celebrate the infinitesimal chance that we exist in the first place. It seems to me that as humans, we have a need to believe in something greater than mere existence; of something beyond "chance". At the same time, we don't want to take responsibility for "choice", even in the face of a cultural belief in our ability to manifest our own destiny. Combine that with a world wide culture of connectedness, instant gratification and a tail-chasing pursuit of fame and fortune, and we are left with the aching feeling of disconnection from ourselves and the ones we love. 

I passionately believe this script, once fully developed, will resonate with a broad spectrum of people. I also believe that the audience will experience a unique and highly entertaining night at the theatre as they travel through this rabbit hole of thought and introspection. A tall order for a play, but one that I know I can tackle with humor and excitement.

A little bit about BT McNicholl and Dani Davis...

Director BT McNicholl was recently named the Producing Artistic Director of the Palace Theatre in Stamford, Connecticut.  He has been on the creative teams of a dozen Broadway plays and musicals including Billy Elliot, Cabaret, and A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum with mentor directors Sam Mendes, Rob Marshall, Stephen Daldry, Jerry Zaks, James Lapine, and Mike Nichols. An experienced dramaturg, he spent two seasons directing new work at the Eugene O’Neill Theatre Center.  He wrote the book and lyrics for the successful musical The It Girl and is a BMI-Award winning lyricist.  Regionally, his production of West Side Story won the 2014 Moss Hart Award. Internationally, he won the Australian "Tony" (the Helpmann) for "Best Direction" and staged the European premiere of The Producers for Stage Entertainment.

Dani Davis is currently engaged in the launch of Girl Starter - a nationally scaled for profit media company and incubator to build out businesses, campaigns, and movements created by teenage girls. Anchored by a seamless online community and a network unscripted reality television series - The Apprentice meets Shark Tank meets the Real World - Girl Starter is changing the access game, making it possible for girls across the US to make their dreams happen. Dani also has a long history producing live musicals on Broadway and for national tours with partners such as Working Title Films, Dreamworks, Universal Pictures Theatrical and NETworks Presentations. She is engaged in building new interactive, entertaining, and educational touring models with IMG and her new venture, Dance House. First projects include two popular title dance pieces in rep with first hand engagement for local dancers. Ms. Davis is an Emmy Award winning songwriter for Handel's Messiah Rocks. For PBS, Dani has directed large scale live music projects. She has written and directed webisode series and live events for the Meredith Corporation. She has written songs for the PBS children's series, Kid Concoctions. She has directed musicals around the country, and looks forward to more time for this creative work.

I understand that there are many opportunities to donate your hard earned money to many different causes, so I appreciate any help you can provide. Thank you so much for considering my request.




Jeffrey Doornbos moved to Los Angeles from New York City, where he was a Blue Man and a director with the internationally known Blue Man Group for many years. During his time in New York, he also appeared in many productions throughout the city, and regionally. Among other feature film credits, Jeffrey produced the award winning feature film “From The Head”, and appeared in Matthew Lillard’s directorial film debut Fat Kid Rules the World. He has also been seen on Prime Suspect, Grey’s Anatomy, Private Practice, NCIS, Law & Order (LA, SVU, & CI), Criminal Minds, Arrested Development, Guiding Light, As The World Turns, All My Children, Young & The Restless, and several appearances on The Tonight Show, The Late Show w/David Letterman, and The Emmy Awards. Jeffrey has collaborated on several projects with Dani Davis, including the Emmy winning Handel's Messiah Rocks for PBS. He has produced five plays in NYC,  written & directed three short films, developing a television project based on his life growing up in the Dutch enclaves of western Michigan, and is writing a television project with co-writer Joseph Ariel Towne. He is honored to be collaborating with BT, and Dani again!


EMAIL: jeffreysd@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

 

Evansville Community Theatre, or ECT, is a group of volunteers dedicated to promoting the theatrical arts in Evansville, Wisconsin. We are a non-profit organization that relies on ticket sales, donations, and community involvement for support. Our revenue is used to produce plays that are staged in Evansville such as this summer's production of The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe.

Not only do we strive to produce high quality theatre, we are also proud to sponsor a scholarship fund that awards scholarships to Evansville High School seniors who have been involved with theatre in our community. We are a volunteer organization so no one gets a payment of any sort. Consequently your money goes back into the community in the form of great theatre.

This is our second campaign with Indiegogo, and we greatly appreciated  how you helped make our production of Little Shop of Horrors a success, and now we need your help for our production of The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe so it too will be a success.  We are attempting to raise enough money to cover the costs of building the set, costumes and make up. Every little bit helps and is directly applied towards these costs. Evansville Community Theatre needs your help to make our production of The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe as successful as possible.

As an added benefit this year, for the first time in ECT's history we will have a sign language interpreter signing for a couple of our shows, this is an exciting benefit that we are thrilled to be able to offer.


What We Need & What You Get

 

The biggest hurdle of putting on a performance of, The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe.is costuming, make up and building the set. We are trying to raise $2000.00 in order to cover these costs.  

Everything that you donate is tax deductible and will be put directly towards the production costs.  Rewards for your support range from a thank you in our program to receiving tickets to our show and the chance to meet and get your picture taken with Aslan and the Witch.

Even if we do not reach our entire goal every penny that is raised through this fundraiser will be put towards these costs.

 

The Impact

With your donations we are hoping to put on our best show yet. Having access to this professional quality costumes will allow us to take our production of The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe to the next step and help our cast and audience become fully immersed in the tale.

We cannot thank you enough for your support and hope to see you at one of our shows. The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe will be performed at the Evansville Performing Arts Center July 10, 11th and 12th, and the 17th and the 18th.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes giving money is not an option. There are many different ways that you can help us that involve a donation of your time instead of money.  The other ways that you can help include

  • Costumes
  •  Spreading the word about this campaign to your friends and family
  • Set building
  •  Light Crew
  • Sound Crew
  • Helping out backstage during the show 
  • Getting involved with our 4th of July float
  •  Or coming to one of our shows!

There are endless other ways that you can help and if you are interested in becoming involved with our production of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe please email us at evansvillect@gmail.com . You can also visit our website at http://ecttheater.com/, or visit our Facebook page.

story:
A Holiday Panto:
The Story of the Princess and the Pea

By Margaret Baldwin
Directed by Karen Robinson & Richard Garner

Discover Pantomania at Georgia Shakespeare! We're boldly introducing Atlanta to the raucous fun of the traditional English phenomenon known as "Holiday Panto," a rowdy interactive performance that makes for the perfect family holiday event.

What do you get when you mix a fun-loving fairy tale with the audience participation of the Rocky Horror Picture Show? A Holiday Panto that is fun for the whole family!

The beloved British holiday institution known as a panto is a comedic feast for the eyes and ears with elaborate costumes and wild song and dance numbers. Sound like a rollicking good time? It is! Pantomania is about to descend on Atlanta - this will be the can't-miss hit of the holidays!

We need your help to bring Pantomania to Georgia Shakespeare! 

Check out this great Panto video from England:


What We Need & What You Get

We need $30,000 to develop and produce this world premiere holiday event - and with your help, we know we can get there! Every little bit helps, so whether you can donate $1 or $10,000 you will know that you helped to create a new holiday tradition for Atlanta. Check out our Perks section for details on how we will show our appreciation for your support - some of the Perks are pretty fantastic, including rehearsal updates, signed photos, a walk-on role in the Panto, and even dinner with our Dame, Chris Kayser! We hope you will also join us for a First Look at the Panto on Tuesday, November 18th.

How Your Donation Makes a Difference

Your donation will cover production costs including development workshops, sets. costumes, props, make-up, lights, and sound. Production costs can run high, especially with a fun, vibrant, and colorful production like a Panto. Your contribution helps us create the beautiful Panto world you would expect from Georgia Shakespeare.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Excited about the Panto but unable to donate at this time? We invite you to share your excitement with your family and friends and encourage them to donate, or buy tickets to the show. Organize a group from your office, church, or neighborhood to come see the show. Tickets are on sale on our website and can also be purchased over the phone by calling our Box Office at 404.504.1473. Having those who love Georgia Shakespeare tell others about us is a tremendous help!

story: Our Story
story_txt: Our Story

story:
The Company and The Idea 

The sculptures of the Air are a touring Corporeal Mime based company who are at the development stage of creating a new show "Every memory has a song." It tells the story of three friends. We see their journey as school kids, to friends and the relationships developed just between these three friends. With the use of Corporeal Mime we hope to show through these three characters the different barrios you face when in love, such as cultural, nationality and those barriors which society has put up. What is a normal love relationship?

With the help of a pianist and a singer we want each scene to create a different memory in the journey of these characters. Every song triggering a different memory just like we experience in life. A certain song/piece of music can take us back in time, to a different country, a whole different chapter in our life...

With the creation of this show we also hope to spread the use of Corporeal Mime through open workshops for those under certain circumstances would not have the opportunity to do so. 

We have already received a lot of help from Moveo - Centro de Teatro Fisico with rehearsal space and have secured a great location for the premier of the show at the Teatre Tantarantana located in the heart of Raval, Barcelona. We have further performances at the International festival in Colombia. 

What We Need 

We have already begun rehearsals for the show and have been bouncing with creativity but we are in need of additional resources. We're hoping to raise £3,000 which will go mainly towards production and artistic costs (rehearsal space, costume, props, set etc) and marketing and administrative costs (flyers, posters and promotion work).


Other Ways You Can Help 

Come to watch our work!!! In addition, if you are able to share our work through word of mouth, sharing the link, liking the 'Los Escultores del Aire' facebook page and any other amazing, creative way you think possible!


Meet the Mimes 

Niharika Mahandru (Nicky) I Performer & Co-devisor

A Performer, Workshop Leader and Movement Director. Niharika both graduated and toured as a company member with Theatre de L´ange Fou, where she performed in their international pieces "Waiting for Ulysses" (2013-2014) and "A Promethean Dream" (2012-2014), USA.

Since graduating she participated and led workshops for recognized international theatre companies such as The Coyote Theatre Collective (NYC), Fools Cap Theatre (London) and The Sculptors of the Air (London and Barcelona). Themes explored in these pieces range from migration, loneliness and relationships through the use of Physical Theatre. She also has experience in combining both physical theatre and speech. An example of this is a tour of the show "Salty Water and Us" by Purbanat Production which explored the history of the Bengali Lascars migrating to England. This production toured all through England and at the Brady Arts Centre in East London where there is a large Bangladeshi community.

Mai Rojas I Director & Performer 

Mai Rojas obtained a degree in Speech Theatre from the Royal College of Dramatic Art in Madrid. After starting his career with contemporary theatre companies such as Madrid XXI Century / Pro-RESAD, Giratablas, l 'Skene, Xavi Villena, National Theatre and other theatre groups. He graduated and toured with Theatre de Lánge Fou . As a performer of Cirque du Soleil in several of their productions, he uses corporeal mime tools to create characters. He is the founder of The Sculptors of the Air and has performed as a workshop leader in schools internationally such as; Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, England, Barcelona and Madrid.

Pedro I Performer 

Pedro graduated from Teatro Berty Tobias in Barcelona and The International School of Corporeal Mime in London, where he was the assistant to the professors and a member of their touring company Theatre de L'ange Fou. 

With his one-man show Like a Movie he won the award of 'Best Show' in the mime festival of Belgrado/Serbia.

In Catalunya he has led the direction of shows 'No es tan facil,' 'Love in Black and White' and 'La noche mas absurda.'
story_txt:
The Company and The Idea 
The sculptures of the Air are a touring Corporeal Mime based company who are at the development stage of creating a new show "Every memory has a song." It tells the story of three friends. We see their journey as school kids, to friends and the relationships developed just between these three friends. With the use of Corporeal Mime we hope to show through these three characters the different barrios you face when in love, such as cultural, nationality and those barriors which society has put up. What is a normal love relationship?
With the help of a pianist and a singer we want each scene to create a different memory in the journey of these characters. Every song triggering a different memory just like we experience in life. A certain song/piece of music can take us back in time, to a different country, a whole different chapter in our life...
With the creation of this show we also hope to spread the use of Corporeal Mime through open workshops for those under certain circumstances would not have the opportunity to do so. 
We have already received a lot of help from Moveo - Centro de Teatro Fisico with rehearsal space and have secured a great location for the premier of the show at the Teatre Tantarantana located in the heart of Raval, Barcelona. We have further performances at the International festival in Colombia. 

What We Need We have already begun rehearsals for the show and have been bouncing with creativity but we are in need of additional resources. We're hoping to raise £3,000 which will go mainly towards production and artistic costs (rehearsal space, costume, props, set etc) and marketing and administrative costs (flyers, posters and promotion work).
Other Ways You Can Help 
Come to watch our work!!! In addition, if you are able to share our work through word of mouth, sharing the link, liking the 'Los Escultores del Aire' facebook page and any other amazing, creative way you think possible!

Meet the Mimes 

Niharika Mahandru (Nicky) I Performer & Co-devisor 
A Performer, Workshop Leader and Movement Director. Niharika both graduated and toured as a company member with Theatre de L´ange Fou, where she performed in their international pieces "Waiting for Ulysses" (2013-2014) and "A Promethean Dream" (2012-2014), USA. 
Since graduating she participated and led workshops for recognized international theatre companies such as The Coyote Theatre Collective (NYC), Fools Cap Theatre (London) and The Sculptors of the Air (London and Barcelona). Themes explored in these pieces range from migration, loneliness and relationships through the use of Physical Theatre. She also has experience in combining both physical theatre and speech. An example of this is a tour of the show "Salty Water and Us" by Purbanat Production which explored the history of the Bengali Lascars migrating to England. This production toured all through England and at the Brady Arts Centre in East London where there is a large Bangladeshi community. 
Mai Rojas I Director & Performer 
Mai Rojas obtained a degree in Speech Theatre from the Royal College of Dramatic Art in Madrid. After starting his career with contemporary theatre companies such as Madrid XXI Century / Pro-RESAD, Giratablas, l 'Skene, Xavi Villena, National Theatre and other theatre groups. He graduated and toured with Theatre de Lánge Fou . As a performer of Cirque du Soleil in several of their productions, he uses corporeal mime tools to create characters. He is the founder of The Sculptors of the Air and has performed as a workshop leader in schools internationally such as; Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, England, Barcelona and Madrid. 
Pedro I Performer 
Pedro graduated from Teatro Berty Tobias in Barcelona and The International School of Corporeal Mime in London, where he was the assistant to the professors and a member of their touring company Theatre de L'ange Fou. 
With his one-man show Like a Movie he won the award of 'Best Show' in the mime festival of Belgrado/Serbia.
In Catalunya he has led the direction of shows 'No es tan facil,' 'Love in Black and White' and 'La noche mas absurda.'

story:
"Oh, you're a shoe-in for that grant!"

famous last words.

Mesdames et Messieurs, the show must go on. How can we not? We're a brand-new être given the gift of two weeks at the venerable Centaur Theatre in le Vieux Montréal.  We have this important new play by two young, local creators and this new way of working, cette rencontre, across linguistic and disciplinary divides. This is a project worth living for.

CHLORINE is the story of Sarah, a teenager with tetraplegia (who communicates only by opening and closing her eyes), her ever-vigilant parents, and her new friend Nathan. This play-wrapped-in-a-ballet takes a tragic real-life event and turns it into a celebration of youth, friendship, caregiving, the 80s,The Sound of Music, and everything messy and wonderful about how we relate to each other.

c r e a t u r e / c r e a t u r e  is a performance unit with a drive to come face to face with the other, to seek the strange in the familiar and the familiar in the strange. In this case, that means combining the talents of francophone and anglophone creators in a mash-up of theatre and dance.

La pièce originale, CHLORE, de Florence Longpré et Nicolas Michon, était le premier succès pour le Théâtre du Grand Cheval, et a fait salles combles à La Licorne en 2012 et au Théâtre d'Aujourd'hui en 2014.

Guided by Johanna Nutter, the creator of the international hit My Pregnant Brother (Mon frère est enceinte) and the response piece My Playwright Sister (next stop for the double-bill will be Calgary's High Performance Rodeo in January 2017), we collaborators are applying a mixologie approach to making art.

BUT WHY??

When asked why we did not get the grant, we were told that although our application was evaluated highly, it was rejected because Johanna was untried as a director and because the jury was not convinced of the validity of our mandate. By supporting this campaign, you will be sending a message that risk, innovation, and connectivity are valid contributions to the artistic landscape.

HERE'S HOW YOU CAN HELP!

We're sharing all the profits equally, and at this point, with a realistic estimate of ticket sales and the financial support we'll receive from the Centaur, we still need to raise close to $10,000 to keep our translator/director/producer from going into debt and to afford our 7 performers, 3 designers, 2 creator/choreographers, stage manager and technician basic compensation. Playwright and numerologist Jesse Stong suggested that $9888 was the most sacred and infinite number. So we're going with that as a target. We have some truly impressive art donations we will be surprising you with along the way, putting the FUN in the 'draising for people across the globe.

If you're in Montreal, the best way to contribute is by calling 514-288-3161 for tickets ($15-$28) to CHLORINE, playing Tuesday through Saturday, October 19 - 29 @7:30pm, with a 2:30pm matinee only on the 29th. (75min)

I'm confident that experiencing this story will be significantly rewarding. Please, give yourself this gift. If you just can't afford it, contact me and we'll work something out. This is the most beautiful play I've encountered and I don't want anyone to miss it.

  • And of course, THANK YOU FOR SHARING THIS WITH YOUR PEEPS!
  • love & amour, Johanna Nutter (the translator/director/producer)

If you're still reading, perhaps you'd like to take a look at my wonderful team's response to the news that we didn't get the grant: https://youtu.be/4ziYXhG6P9s

story:
Teri Carter, SOMAfest Founder and Director

TERI's creative embodied movement process is informed by over 30 years of dance, improvisation and mindful body practices (www.EmbodyLife.net).

Teri is an award winning dance artist, practicing improvisational choreographic and somatic based explorations with sound, video and audience participation.  Her work has been performed in Los Angeles, NYC, San Francisco, Washington D.C, Seattle, Portland, Milwaukee, Chicago, Eugene, Omega, Kripalu, Germany, Mexico and various dance festivals throughout the U.S.

She is an authorized Continuum Movement Teacher, Registered Somatic Movement Educator and Therapist, Body-Mind Centering® Practitioner, Tai Chi/Chi Gung Instructor, Personal Fitness Trainer, Life Success Coach, Bodyworker and Cranial Sacral Therapist. She is President of the Board of Directors for ISMETA (International Somatic Movement Education and Therapy Association) and on the Board of the Journal for Dance and Somatic Practices.  


SOMAfest: a Somatic Movement Arts Festival

Teri Carter conceived of SOMAfest as a space to engage in the inquiry of embodiment and explore the intersection where somatic practice meets creativity. This was the first festival of its kind to specifically present somatic practitioners who are also practicing as performing artists.

   

Over the last nine years SOMAfest has become a fertile ground for anyone looking to discover their own vitality. In our Los Angeles and NYC events, SOMAfest has been a home to some of the world’s most prominent movement innovators and to anyone who wishes to explore the body-mind connection for creativity, health and live performance. This festival offers invaluable opportunity for developing life long self-care practices and cultivating body-mind integration, creativity, presence & community. Last year we ran without our anticipated funding. We want to make the future of SOMAfest more sustainable. With your support we will be able to continue to offer our full line up of workshops, a performance lab intensive and present our Embodiment Performance Series each year. 

SOMAfest brings in world renowned movement innovators and aims to cultivate an experience for participants to bring more creativity, ease and pleasure into their lives and support a dynamic and responsive connection to the body's intelligence. Prominent movement innovators who have been part of SOMAfest include Emilie Conrad, Anna Halprin, Simone Forti and Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen. 

This act of coming together builds our global movement community and fosters meaningful connections between participants. It encourages the cross pollination of ideas, and plays a part in evolving the field of somatics.


What we’re requesting

We aim to raise $3,300, the amount we had applied for in funding. With this amount we will be able to secure spaces for workshops and performances, pay our teachers a modest honorarium, hire performance technicians as well as administrative staff for the performance, promote our festival in Los Angeles and globally, and document the festival. Our rental spaces have exceeded $2,500 in the past. Quite often our Director and staff donate their time out of passion for the festival.  

In coordination with SOMAfest's 501(c)(3) partner, Not Man Apart Physical Theatre, your contribution here is tax deductible and we are happy to be able to offer you some incredible perks in return! Our Bio-Creativity Somatic Summit is running in conjunction with our festival; this is where we bring experts across somatic fields together for interviews, telegatherings and virtual classes. Attend a class or take in a recording! Experience deep embodiment from wherever you are in the world and become part of the SOMAfest and global somatic movement community: 

http://tericarter.com/SomaticSummit_BioCreativity.html

Our aim is to provide people from around the world to grow the capacity to take their health and creativity into their own hands, to deepen into the greatest version of who they truly can be.  Help us to keep this vital work moving forward with another year -another decade- of SOMAfest!


Want to Support us in Other Ways?

Help spread the word about our festival - better yet, join us!


"Like" and share the SOMAfest group page on facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/SOMAfestLA/

RSVP and share our facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/1193314030692876/

Share our promo video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m9dT7PApWCc

Visit our website:

http://tericarter.com/SomaAbout.html
