story:
Campaign Photo Credit: Andrew Masi

What am I doing?

Throughout my work as a dancer, teacher and choreographer, dance has helped me heal from a past of intimate partner abuse. Because of my own experience utilizing dance as a tool for personal empowerment, I am interested in exploring the profound healing power that dance can bring to trauma survivors. My current interdisciplinary research on how the body stores memories suggests that dance is an effective healing modality because it enables trauma survivors to access, process and integrate traumatic memories stored in the body.

In this campaign, I'm asking for your financial fuel to embark on the next phase of my research, which is to study the methods used in a highly effective program at El Colegio Del Cuerpo in Cartagena, Colombia that implements contemporary dance training as a way to heal and empower children who come from difficult pasts of poverty, abuse, and human trafficking. 

My name is Bonnie Cox and I am an MFA dance student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, where I am combining psychology with dance in my performative, choreographic, pedagogical and scholarly work. 

In 2013 I produced a dance concert in Austin, Texas called Silence To Power: Dance as a response to trauma, that featured dances created by local artists to help them process traumatic experiences. After creating a solo that encapsulated my experience with intimate partner abuse, I was inspired to give dancers in the community an opportunity to share their experiences through their creative work. The show was powerful, moving and transformative for the artists and the audience. 

I have been hungry ever since to find out how and why the act of dancing, translating painful experiences into movement, and being witnessed by others can foment healing and catharsis for trauma survivors. 

Let's rewind to 2007...

I was a dance duckling at Austin Community College. The University of Texas brought Alvaro Restrepo from El Colegio Del Cuerpo to Austin for an artistic residency. Alvaro led a workshop for the community where he demonstrated the contemporary dance methods he uses to cultivate comfort, safety and empowerment for the children in his program. I was completely blown away by the power and simplicity of his methods. I felt a therapeutic shift in my body. I was in an abusive relationship at the time, but had not yet realized it. 

Ever since then it has been my intention to go to El Colegio Del Cuerpo to learn these methods and train with Alvaro Restrepo. In 2008 I set out to reach El Colegio by bicycle; I made it to Nicaragua, but fell short of my dream. Seven years later, the organization has grown exponentially, and my growth as a person, as a dancer, and as a researcher gives this mission even greater significance. 

Ya es hora. It is time to finish the journey.

The money I raise through this campaign will fund a preliminary trip to Cartagena in August, where I will clarify my research goals by meeting with the faculty and students at El Colegio Del Cuerpo, observing classes, and immersing myself in the environment. I will spend the next two semesters deepening the theoretical components of my research and securing grants to fund an extended trip to Cartagena next summer. 

Economic Necessity 

Grad school is an expensive endeavor, and Boulder is an expensive city to live in, so this trip is impossible for me to fund on my own. I am relying on your passion for dance and healing, as well as your generosity to make my vision a reality. Absolutely any amount you are comfortable donating is welcome. 

Here is a breakdown of the $1957 I am requesting:

$900-round trip plane ticket

$320-8 days of housing at $40 a night

$120-8 days of food at $15 a day

$192-8 days of dance classes at $24 a day

$349-Intensive spanish course in Boulder from June 8th-July 3rd

$76- Indiegogo fee

All contributions that exceed my fundraising goal will go toward my subsequent visit to Cartagena next summer where I will spend an extended amount of time conducting this research. If I fall short of my goal, I will postpone this trip until the winter and work on securing the rest of the funds until then. 

Photo by Andrew Masi

What You Get

Your financial support will contribute to the understanding of the healing power of dance, proliferate its use as a healing modality for trauma survivors, and help to spread these cutting-edge, life-changing therapeutic practices to people all over the world. In addition to my sincere, life-long gratitude, perks may include: a video recording of a dance incorporating elements of who you are performed at my MFA concert; a Colombian-style dinner at my home on Pearl Street in Boulder; a massage; a video of my current choreographic work, inspired by my research on body memory; a copy of my final research paper; a personalized shout-out dance video; and sweet nothings from Cartagena.

The Impact

Join me in jumpstarting the beginning of this important research which seeks to validate the effectiveness of dance as a healing modality, and explore the mechanisms involved in trauma memory in relation to the body. My intention is to work to increase the accessibility of this form of therapy to trauma survivors, and to improve upon current therapeutic dance practices. I will extend the reach of the work El Colegio Del Cuerpo has pioneered by incorporating the organization's methods into my teaching and choreography, and by sharing them with other trauma survivors, movement artists and therapists. 

Photo by Andrew Masi

Thanks For Your Time and Attention

Please spread the word by sharing this page with the people in your life: http://igg.me/at/danceheals 

Body memories manifest themselves as continually vanishing into the depths of our corporeal existence-and just as continually welling up from the same depths  -Maxine Sheets-Johnstone

Photo by Taylor Wasmer

story:
While the sexual abuse scandal in the Catholic Church has been in the headlines for years now, and the Church hierarchy and abusive priests are finally being held to account, the devastating effects on victims, their families, and others who have trusted the Church have rarely been brought to light. TRUST, a powerful new play by John Woehrle, seeks to fill that void by bringing one victim's story to life.

John developed TRUST in Minneapolis with the Self-Reliant Actors Workshop he founded. One workshop actor inspired the story, and four others inspired the roles they will be playing on stage in the play's premier.

The play tells the story of a Catholic college senior, Michael, who must come to terms with the sexual abuse he endured as a child by a trusted priest, who is also a close family friend. Michael thought he had escaped his past when he went away to college, but as graduation day approaches, his past catches up to him. His world begins to fall apart as it becomes increasingly difficult for him to maintain the divide between memories of past trauma and the normalcy he thought he had successfully built.

TRUST gives voice to the victims and their families and portrays the Catholic Church's profoundly negligent and scandalous response to the issue.  At the same time the play demonstrates the courage and love of those within the church and outside who put compassion and healing ahead of personal gain and institutional reputation. We have shared the script with local members of SNAP (Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests) who are very excited about TRUST and its potential to serve as an "intervention" for victims of clergy abuse.

The playwright, John Woehrle, was a finalist for the McKnight Fellowship for Screenwriters for his first screenplay, "West Metro” and later directed the award-winning documentary film about Sierra Leone, Pride of Lions. 

John was inspired to write TRUST when he directed Apostle on the Edge by Jim Hanson, who wrote and performed this solo theater piece in Minneapolis. Jim shared the heartbreaking story of his abuse and its devastating effects on him and his family, and, as a life-long Catholic, John felt compelled to bring it to a wider audience.

Your support will allow us to tell this story with maximum impact - rehearsal space, production design, and a cast that will bring it to life and create a truly powerful theater experience.

We realize not everyone will be able to contribute, but there are alternative ways to support us, including getting the word out to those in your network you think may want to help fund our story. Thank you for your consideration.
story_txt:
While the sexual abuse scandal in the Catholic Church has been in the
headlines for years now, and the Church hierarchy and abusive priests are
finally being held to account, the devastating effects on victims, their
families, and others who have trusted the Church have rarely been brought to
light. TRUST, a powerful new play by John Woehrle, seeks to fill that void by
bringing one victim's story to life. 
John developed TRUST in Minneapolis with the Self-Reliant Actors Workshop he
founded. One workshop actor inspired the story, and four others
inspired the roles they will be playing on stage in the play's premier. 
The play tells the story of a Catholic college senior, Michael, who must
come to terms with the sexual abuse he endured as a child by a trusted priest, who is also a close family friend.
Michael thought he had escaped his past when he went away to college, but as
graduation day approaches, his past catches up to him. His world begins to fall
apart as it becomes increasingly difficult for him to maintain the divide
between memories of past trauma and the normalcy he thought he had successfully
built. 
TRUST gives voice to the victims and their families and
portrays the Catholic Church's profoundly negligent and scandalous response to
the issue.  At the same time the play demonstrates the courage
and love of those within the church and outside who put compassion and healing
ahead of personal gain and institutional reputation. We have shared the
script with local members of SNAP (Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests) who are very excited about TRUST and its
potential to serve as an "intervention" for victims of clergy abuse. 
The playwright, John Woehrle, was a finalist for the McKnight Fellowship
for Screenwriters for his first screenplay, "West Metro” and
later directed the award-winning documentary film about Sierra Leone, Pride
of Lions. 
John was inspired to write TRUST when he directed Apostle on the Edge
by Jim Hanson, who wrote and performed this solo theater piece in Minneapolis. Jim
shared the heartbreaking story of his abuse and its devastating effects on him
and his family, and, as a life-long Catholic, John felt compelled to
bring it to a wider audience.
Your support will allow us to tell this story with maximum impact - rehearsal space, production design, and a cast that will bring it to life and
create a truly powerful theater experience. 
We realize not everyone will be able to contribute, but there are
alternative ways to support us, including getting the word out to those in your
network you think may want to help fund our story. Thank you for your
consideration.

story:
In this generation, teens do not have the opportunity of learning about varieties of theater, for example, classical theater, Shakespeare, Chekhov, Ibsen, and more. Electronics are taking over the minds of teens across America; reducing their knowledge of the wonderful world of theater. Though iPhones and tablets are a great contribution to the world, they do not give you the same experiences as watching a live performance of early playwrites.

Hello, our names are Liz and Nikki. I, Nikki, am one of the three children of Ella Ayberk. Our eighth grade drama class has gotten the opportunity to see one of the  classical production " Chekhov.PostScriptum" directed by the acclaimed Moscow Art Theater director and actors of Accent Theater Company.

Other teens, however, don't have the opportunity to do this. Our goal is to change this. Accent Theater Company will invite public middle and high school students to watch this play, with no charge. This will give teenagers the intellectual experience that they are lacking. Plays like this might not affect some, but can inspire and motivate others who didn't know they had it in them.

My mom was born and raised in Russia. As a teen, she didn't have  money to see productions like this. She grew fond of acting and the Theater. She raised three wonderful kids, became a nurse and is now pursuing her dream.

We're asking you to donate how ever much you can, even if it's a dollar. Our goal is get $1000 to pay for an additional rent and technical expenses  to cover some of the free performances for students.  My mother is working very hard, needing to balance her career as a nurse, taking care of me, my siblings and my grandparents, and now this production. Thank you for reading!

Nikki, 13 years old ( MS 54, New York City)

story:
Support Nickel Mines

Nickel Mines is a new theatrical work that interprets the 2006 Lancaster, Pennsylvania Amish schoolhouse shooting.

Originally developed at University of California, Irvine, creators Andrew Palermo (Allegiance, The Other Josh Cohen, dre.dance, productions at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center and others), Shannon Stoeke (reality show development with Taye Diggs and international performances) and Dan Dyer (Austin based singer-songwriter, award winning multi-instrumentalist) are thrilled to present this new piece at the New York Musical Festival, July 27-31, 2016.

With an incredible team, including Tony Award winning designers, (Howell Binkley and Nevin Steinberg of Hamilton and countless others), Broadway Music Director (David Gardos) and a mix of seasoned and up and coming performers, Nickel Mines at NYMF is only the next step in our show's journey.

New York Musical Festival is an excellent platform from which hundreds of new musicals have launched. Next To Normal, [title of show], Chaplin, Altar Boyz, The Other Josh Cohen, and The Great American Trailer Park Musical are just a few shows that got their start at NYMF.

For Nickel Mines to be presented successfully in New York this July, we need your help. The support generated by this fundraising campaign is a vital lifeline to our new piece. So donate today! 


Our Goal

$30,000 is only a portion of the Nickel Mines total NYMF budget.

Your support will help pay for production costs, all of which are set at incredibly modest rates. Your tax-deductible contribution will go directly to:

  • Performer, designer, musician staff and team fees
  • Venue rehearsal space rental
  • Costume, set and other technical costs
  • Web, PR and management costs

Why Nickel Mines?

Steven Stanley of StageSceneLA reviewed our UCI developmental production. “Extraordinary…tragedy turned into art, and the power of grace
as it may never have been shown before.”

Nickel Mines is an intersection of the creative team's highest held beliefs; that the arts can and should provide challenging and artistically satisfying interpretations of socially relevant issues.

It's no secret that America is facing a gun violence epidemic. 'The Happening' (what the Amish call the Nickel Mines shooting) is sadly just one of a horrifying spate of school shootings that have occurred over the last decade. Indeed, it's been 10 years since the Nickel Mines shooting, and the families and people of Lancaster, PA live in the aftermath of this terrifying tragedy everyday.

As Nickel Mines moves forward beyond NYMF, a portion of ticket sales will go directly to victims of gun violence. We are supporters and collaborators of Everytown For Gun Safety, Moms Demand Action For Gun Sense In America, The Brady Campaign To Prevent Gun Violence, The Coalition To Stop Gun Violence and others. Nickel Mines is proud to partner with these organizations and to continue to foster the conversation about the culture of violence that has tragically gripped our nation.

All of this said, Nickel Mines is a piece of theatre. We do not impose our own judgments on the people and stories of Lancaster, PA. We only aim to provide a lens through which to look at October 2nd, 2006, and to see how acts of violence affect not only the victims and their families, but those related to the killer and the community as a whole.

The grace Mr. Stanley so thoughtfully mentioned is the Amish community's public and practically instant forgiveness of the killer of their children. This is the true 'Why' of Nickel Mines.  This amazing response is the core of our show, and ultimately what we hope to leave the audience with at the end of our story. 


    Every Bit Helps

    If you support the arts and theatre, want to see new, relevant work on stage and believe the arts can help us understand our world, please support Nickel Mines. We need your help.  Every tax-deductible dollar will make a difference!


    THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

    Andrew, Shannon, Dan and the Nickel Mines company


    Absent Mind Productions/Andrew Palermo is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Absent Mind Productions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
I am excited to introduce you to Aries In Flight, a new organization I have launched to dedicate my life’s purpose to the preservation and future success of Theater Jazz dance.  Aries In Flight’s choreography evokes the styles of past Theater Jazz icons and merges them with a contemporary flair. The dance company aims to legitimize Theater Jazz as a valuable player in the concert dance world and educate both our audiences and the dance community in this historically rich tradition, delighting them with show-stopping repertoire. Our long-term vision is to strengthen future generations of Theater Jazz dancers through dance classes, educational programming in historical knowledge, performance opportunities, and collaborations within the dance community.

One of the ways in which I intend to carry out this mission is by performing in showcases throughout the NYC metropolitan area. My project was recently accepted into Kat Wildish Presents Performing In New York Spotlight Series and requires a participation fee as well as rehearsal fees. Today I am reaching out to ask you to consider making a donation to this project. With your support we will be able to fully participate in this performance opportunity and bring our mission further into the dance community. We are at a pivotal stage in this project and your contribution is essential to our success at this time. The performance will take place on Sunday March 1, 2015 in midtown Manhattan. We are expecting full performance details within the first few weeks of January. All monies raised will be used to pay the $320 participation fee, $120 in rehearsal rental space, and $310 in dancer stipends/expenses. We will not be able to participate in this prestigious NYC showcase without YOUR help. Our fundraising deadline is Friday February 6, 2015

story:
The 16th Annual March to Abolish the Death Penalty will be held Saturday, October 24, 2015 on the South Steps of the Texas Capitol at 2 PM. Now is the time to join the fight to end the death penalty! See you there!

Come to the 16th Annual March to Abolish the Death Penalty to recognize the progress made so far and to continue the struggle for more progress towards abolishing the death penalty. 

Great news! Alfred Dewayne Brown will join us at the 16th Annual March to Abolish the Death Penalty. He was released on June 8, 2015 after more than ten years on Texas death row for a crime he did not commit. Please come to the march so we can all warmly welcome Dewayne back to freedom in person.

In addition to Dewayne, we expect 4-5 other death row exonerees at the march. His legal team believes it will help Dewayne to attend the march and meet other death row exonerees, as well as people who support him.

Developments in 2015

So far in 2015, zero people have been sentenced to death in Texas. In 1999, 48 people were sentenced to death in Texas. Obviously, more and more people are concluding that the death penalty is a punishment that Texas can do without.

In 2015 Nebraska abolished its death penalty and Connecticut's highest court ordered that state's death row emptied out because it said the death penalty was unconstitutional. 

In 2015, we successfully lobbied Texas state senator Eddie Lucio Jr to file a bill for the first time in the Texas senate to abolish the Texas death penalty. 

Yet 2015 has also seen 10 people executed in Texas so far, with another 8 executions scheduled in Texas before the end of the year.

Texas has executed 528 people since 1982. 

Innocent People

Todd Willingham, who was an innocent person executed by Texas in 2004, was one of more than 250 people executed under former Texas Governor Rick Perry.

Alfred Dewayne Brown became the latest person exonerated off Texas death row on June 8, 2015. “I went in an innocent man and I came out an innocent man,” said Brown.

Anthony Graves is an innocent person who was released in October 27, 2010 after 18 years in prison for a crime he did not commit, including 14 years on Texas death row.

After a short pre-march speaker's program, we will march through the streets of downtown Austin with a stop in front of the Texas Governor's mansion and return to the Texas Capitol to hear more speakers against the death penalty.

Each October since 2000, people from all walks of life and all parts of Texas, the U.S. and other countries have taken a day out of their year and gathered in Austin to raise their voices together and loudly express their opposition to the death penalty. The march is a coming together of activists, family members of people on death row, community leaders, exonerated former death row prisoners and all those calling for repeal of the Texas death penalty.

The annual march is organized as a joint project by several Texas anti-death penalty organizations and their allies, including Texas Moratorium Network, the Austin chapter of the Campaign to End the Death Penalty, the Texas Death Penalty Abolition Movement, Students Against the Death Penalty, Kids Against the Death Penalty, and the Journey of Hope ... from Violence to Healing.

story:
Short Summary

The University of Miami Theatre Action Group is dedicated to the study and celebration of the craft of theatre. We are an entirely student-run organization which aims to nurture budding artists by providing opportunities not only to train in his or her chosen discipline, but to produce works which tackle current issues in unconventional ways. 

Our inaugural production, 30 Neo-Futurist Plays from "Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind" (30 Plays in 60 Minutes), not only challenges artists with a title that is longer than some of its plays, but with a style of performance which breaks the mold of traditional theatre conventions. In the production (that we've affectionately abbreviated TML), an ensemble of actors attempt perform thirty short plays in sixty minutes. The plays are selected in random order by members of the audience; the show is never the same twice! 

TML runs the gamut of style and genre, from improv to political satire to melodrama to theatre of the absurd. It's a wild hour of unconventional fun, but it also packs a strong point of view about the world we live in today. In short, it has something for everyone!

TML is already in rehearsals, and will perform February 12-14 on the University of Miami campus.

What We Need & What You Get

We aren't charging admission to TML because we feel that it's so important for our peers to see this show, no matter how much of a broke college student they are. But hey, we're broke college students too! That's why we need your help to cover the costs of our production. The major ones are:

  • The rights- $340 
  • The scripts- $130
  • The props- around $50                                                                                                       

It's not an expensive production by any means, but it's more than our ramen-eating selves can finance on our own! Fortunately, there are fantastic incentives for your generosity!

The Impact

On a personal level, producing TML is an opportunity for a group of young artists to test out their skills in an entirely new way. We're essentially running our own little theatre company, taking on not just performance duties, but directing, tech, publicity, and of course, fundraising. It's a hands-on learning experience for some passionate aspiring thespians to apply their skills outside of the classroom.
Even more importantly, though, TML itself is a show (well, actually thirty of them) that we think is incredibly important. TML forces audiences to rethink their preconceptions about what a theatrical production can be. We think that in the world of "peak TV" and Netflix, the theatre needs to perpetually reinvent itself to stay relevant, and shows like TML, which rely so heavily on audience participation and current events, are a way to do just that. College students need to fall in love with the theatre again. We give them that chance.

Risks & Challenges

We picked this show because it was going to be a challenge; we want to stretch ourselves outside of our comfort zones. So there are some risks to the production, but ones that will force us to grow as artists.

  • We're doing this project entirely on our own. No professors, no professional actors, nothing. We wanted the experience of forming an ensemble company. That means we're going to have to learn a lot of things as we go. There may be stumbles along the way, but we are determined to use them as an opportunity for growth.
  • Some of us haven't acted since high school, our director has minimal experience, and we're not master tech designers by any means. We're passionate students, not professionals. Part of the point of the whole process is to hone our craft. We're aiming for a professional quality production, but there is the possibility that we could fall short of that.
  • Although we think that TML is perfectly suited for a college audience, it's possible that people just won't be interested in coming out to see our show. The theatre department productions struggle to get students to turn out; we could have similar attendance problems. It's part of our goal to learn which publicity tools work, and which don't.

No matter what happens though, there will be a production, and we all will take away valuable experience with us for our future careers. With your support, we can make this a great show!

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you could give would be helpful (even just a dollar), but we understand that a lot of the people looking at this page are students just like us, who want to support our efforts but just don't have the cash. That's okay! You can be a part of our publicity team!

  • Share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. etc. etc. You might not be able to contribute, but your friends can!
  • If you're in the Miami area, come and see our show on February 12-14 in Studio A of the Communications School! There will be a Facebook event with more details.
  • Tweet about us with #TMLUM. Tell us what a short play you wrote would be about, why you want to see the show, any questions you might have. Get the word out!

Thanks for all of your support, both monetary and non. People like you help make art possible, and we artists could not be more grateful. 

Curtain!

Some of us haven't acted since high school, our director has minimal experience, and we're not master tech designers by any means. We're passionate students, not professionals. Part of the point of the whole process is to hone our craft. We're aiming for a professional quality production, but there is the possibility that we could fall short of that.
Although we think that TML is perfectly suited for a college audience, it's possible that people just won't be interested in coming out to see our show. The theatre department productions struggle to get students to turn out; we could have similar attendance problems. It's part of our goal to learn which publicity tools work, and which don't.

No matter what happens though, there will be a production, and we all will take away valuable experience with us for our future careers. With your support, we can make this a great show!   Other Ways You Can Help Anything you could give would be helpful (even just a dollar), but we understand that a lot of the people looking at this page are students just like us, who want to support our efforts but just don't have the cash. That's okay! You can be a part of our publicity team!  Share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. etc. etc. You might not be able to contribute, but your friends can! If you're in the Miami area, come and see our show on February 12-14 in Studio A of the Communications School! There will be a Facebook event with more details.
Tweet about us with #TMLUM. Tell us what a short play you wrote would be about, why you want to see the show, any questions you might have. Get the word out!   Thanks for all of your support, both monetary and non. People like you help make art possible, and we artists could not be more grateful. Curtain!

story:
Help us to:

  • Share Paradise at the Yukon Arts Centre in Whitehorse, Yukon from March 24-28, 2015 and in Haines Junction, Yukon the following week
  • Organize post-show talkbacks around issues explored in Paradise, including mental health, homelessness, addictions, poverty, human rights and justice
  • Hold community storytelling workshops involving people with lived experience of issues raised in Paradise, with community partners including Yukon Anti-Poverty Coalition
  • Make rehearsals and performances accessible to all people in our community, including our pay-what-you-can preview
  • Create a study and resource guide


This project matters. Here's why:

  • Theatre matters. Theatre remains a vibrant, sacred place where people come together to share stories. We all need stories. Stories are who we are. They are our society. Our weaknesses. Our dreams.  Paradise is a thought-provoking play which explores characters trying to do what we all, remain human, in the face of challenges including mental and physical health issues, poverty, addictions, human rights and justice.
  • Theatre matters to everyone. This project includes outreach to help people get to see the play – with a low-cost preview and blocks of tickets donated for lower-income citizens – in partnership with community organizations like the Yukon Anti-Poverty Coalition. Also, every Yukon community deserves the chance to enjoy the arts. We’re taking this play to the small rural Yukon community of Haines Junction, and offering a theatre workshop to high school students.
  • Everyone’s stories matter. Community storytelling workshops are geared to people with lived experience of issues raised in the play, and who may not have had opportunities to explore performing arts before.


What do we need funds for?

Gwaandak Theatre is a professional company which is both artist-centred and community minded. While we welcome volunteers, we pay all principal artists and production team members who will be working full-time on this project. We’ve almost raised enough funds for this world premiere production from our public funders, corporate and private donors, and sponsors. We’re nearly there. 

Funds raised will pay for:

  • Two facilitators for our weekend community storytelling workshops with experience in the performing arts, individual and community empowerment
  • A part-time coordinator for our community outreach, including workshops and audience talkbacks, in partnership with Yukon Anti-Poverty Coalition and other non-profit groups
  • Resource guide writer
And a portion of the following:
  • Our four talented actors, director, designers, stage manager, technicians and everyone on our team who will make the magic happen. They are outstanding professionals from the Yukon and other parts of Canada
  • A simple, decent place with a kitchen for our guest artists to call home for 6 weeks in the Yukon
  • Set, props, and costumes
  • Advertising so people know about the play and community workshops
  • Accommodations for two nights in Haines Junction, 150 kilometres from Whitehorse, while we share the play there


Impact of the project 

This project explores contemporary issues around poverty, homelessness, mental health, addictions and more – issues that unfortunately are commonplace in the Yukon as well as many other regions.. Our capital city of Whitehorse has high rates of poverty, addictions, disability and mental health issues and related stigma, lack of affordable housing, a significant minority population (25%) of Yukon First Nations peoples dealing with colonization and residential school trauma, large gap between rich and poor, dedicated community organizations, growing visible minority community, and an extremely vibrant arts community which is not always accessible to and reflective of marginalized people and groups.

Our project draws upon themes raised in this new Yukon play while allowing community members to develop and share their own stories, see the play Paradise for themselves and be fully involved in a larger community dialogue with responses to the art and how it connects – or doesn’t – with present-day realities.

Anticipated impacts include:

  • Bringing community together in sharing a story that we believe will make us think, feel and talk with each other about our world, our places in it, and how we can promote meaningful connection and dignity for all of us.
  • Empowering people to tell their own stories in community workshops.
  • Increased awareness of and compassion for people with mental health, poverty, addictions and human rights barriers
  • Promoting resources in the Yukon around mental health, addictions, homelessness, poverty and human rights
  • Offering valued and challenging opportunities for both emerging and established artists in the Yukon and across Canada to bring a new Canadian play to life for audiences


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Promote this page
  • Share it through your social network
  • Come and see the show between March 24 and 28 in Whitehorse and on March 31 in Haines Junction, and bring a friend who’s never been to a play before
  • Help us finding affordable transportation for lower-income citizens who would like to see the play. 
  • Volunteer (putting up posters, staffing our membership table, helping with opening night festivities, load in and striking the set, making a meal for cast and crew, promoting the play to your friends & co-workers, and more!)
  • Sponsor us through in-kind donations: food, restaurant coupons, gas coupons, etc. to feed and transport our artists


About Gwaandak Theatre 

Gwaandak Theatre develops, produces and tours professional plays to empower Indigenous and northern voices.

We’re a small theatre company based in Whitehorse, Yukon Territory with big seasons and bigger dreams – all with part-time staff and a small office with a view of the Yukon River. Whitehorse is a scenic, vibrant city of almost 28,000 and the entire Yukon has only 36,000 people.

We’re founded by a pair of artists – Vuntut Gwitchin playwright and journalist Leonard Linklater, born and raised in the North; and playwright Patti Flather, who fell in love with the North. Since then, we’ve developed, produced and toured many plays and readings, from tiny remote communities like Old Crow to the nation’s capital in Ottawa.

Gwaandak Theatre productions are recognized for their exploration of the human condition, particularly from Indigenous, northern and diverse perspectives. We’re known for our commitment to Aboriginal, rural and youth audiences and relationships with community partners to deepen dialogue and promote greater accessibility of theatre arts.

To read more about this production and our company, please visit our website.


Gwaandak Theatre's past successes

Gwaandak Theatre plays a growing role in the Whitehorse and larger Yukon artistic community as well as nationally, as an artistically outstanding professional Yukon theatre company. We are distinct and increasingly known for:

  • Developing and showcasing Indigenous and northern voices;
  • Meaningful community partnerships and creative collaborations;
  • Programming which explores relevant social justice and human rights issues without being didactic;
  • Extensive outreach to Aboriginal and youth audiences;
  • Programming annually in rural communities;
  • National-level touring.

To read more about our recent successful projects, please visit our website.


About the playwright

Patti Flather is an award-winning published and produced playwright, dramaturg, fiction and screenwriter and educator. She is actively involved in play creation and development as Managing Artistic Director of Gwaandak Theatre, which she co-founded with Leonard Linklater. She has a Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing from the University of British Columbia. Her produced plays include Sixty Below, West Edmonton Mall, Where the River Meets the Sea (winner of Theatre BC’s Canadian National Playwriting Competition), The Soul Menders, the collective creations Go Angel Girlfriends and Tell Me More… and others. She leads Gwaandak’s New Yukon Voices playwriting circle and has taught Dramatic Writing at Yukon College. Patti has co-produced all productions, co-productions and past tours with Gwaandak Theatre, including Sixty Below, West Edmonton Mall, Yellow on Thursdays the7-stop 2011 Yukon tour of Café Daughter, the 2012 Yukon tour of Justice, the 2013 national tours of Justice and Café Daughter, and the 2014 tour of The Hours That Remain. She is a proud member of Playwrights Guild of Canada. As well, her fiction has been published in literary magazines including Prairie Fire, Room of One’s Own and dANDelion.Originally from North Vancouver, Patti has called the Yukon home for more than two dedades. 


About the director

Majdi Bou-Mataris a theatre director and performer who immigrated to Canada from Lebanon in 2003. He holds an MA degree in Drama from the University of Guelph with research focus on Canadian intercultural theatre, a BA degree in directing from the Lebanese American University and BA Honours in theatre studies from the Lebanese University.  Majdi directed several productions in Beirut and has been a key participant in several theatre, television, and film projects in the Middle East and Tunisia. Majdi represented his country of origin in the Afro-Arab Centre for Theatrical Research in Tunis where he gained considerable knowledge in the inter-cultural aspects of theatre. An active member of the Waterloo Region arts community, Majdi founded The Multicultural Theatre Space (MT Space) in 2004. At The MT Space Majdi designed and managed several programs using theatre as a tool for community building, settlement, and social change. Such projects include the Immigrant Youth Theatre program with the KWYMCA and Theatre for Social Change with the Centre for Community Based Research.   Majdi’s directing portfolio includes Nijinsky the hour of his Wedding to the Lord (1998), Miss Julie (1999), Something Like Macbeth (2000), Three-Legged Horse (2004), Seasons of Immigration (2005), Yes or No (2006), Exit Strategy (2007), The Last 15 Seconds (2008) and Body 13(2010). Majdi is also the Artistic Director of IMPACT, a biennial international theatre festival in the Waterloo Region. In its first incarnation IMPACT 09 presented theatre from China, Hungary, Belgium and Canada. The festival engaged over 100 artists, 100 volunteers and 3300 visitors.

story:
Aenigma Theatre is proud to present the Vancouver Premiere of:

THE HOW AND THE WHY  by Sarah Treem

November 13-18 at Studio 1398 on Granville Island (1398 Cartwright St, Vancouver, BC V6H 3R8). 

“…a smart, densely textured work about men and women, love and conflict, genes and destiny.” —New York Times

“A tale of two female scientists caught in a knotty personal relationship, Sarah Treem’s play brims with ideas and emotional colors that eddy and refract like rivulets in a lively, plunging stream.”– The Washington Post

Evolution, Feminism and Destiny collide in Sarah Treem’s (House of Cards,The Affair) poignant play about science, family, and the difficult choices that women face.  

Why do women menstruate? Modern science has supplied us with the “How”, but no one seems to have answered the “Why”. Rachel, a young grad student in Evolutionary Biology visits Zelda, a pioneer of the field.  She posits a radical new hypothesis to answer this very question, which just happens to challenge Zelda’s own ground-breaking work. As the two brilliant women spar over their contrary views on science, career and generational divides, the ulterior motives surrounding their intense meeting slowly begin to unravel…

The Company

This production showcases emerging and established Vancouver-based artists. The cast includes Bronwen Smith (Classic Chic’s Much Ado About Nothing) and Annie Arbuckle (Aenigma Theatre’s No Exit). The production team includes: Erica Leduc (Stage Management), Aenigma Theatre Co-Artistic Director Sarah Melo (Set Design), Alix Miller (Costume Design), Chengyan Boon (Lighting Design), and two-time Jessie Nominee Scott Zechner (Sound Design). Aenigma Theatre Founder and Co-Artistic Director Tanya Mathivanan will direct.

“Aenigma Theatre…prove(s) once again: you don’t need a fancy set and expensive costumes to make theatre. All you really need is a good story, well-told.”—Jo Ledingham, on VIVA (2017)

Aenigma Theatre was founded by Tanya Mathivanan in 2013 with the belief that, in many ways, people are all enigmas, to each other as well as to themselves. Tanya's diagnosis of Fibromyalgia at the age of 15 amplified her interest in exploring the complexities of the human condition. Together with Co-Artistic Director, Sarah Melo, and a team of talented designers, Aenigma Theatre seeks to engage the community emotionally and intellectually by applying its unique aesthetic to challenging, relevant plays.  www.aenigmatheatre.com

The Impact

This play is important and startlingly relevant to the community, especially in this Socio-Political Climate. Conversations surrounding women, as well as the science field, have dominated headlines in recent years, and have gotten worryingly controversial. We believe that the issues articulated in this play are often ignored or dismissed, and that it is extremely important to highlight them in a public sphere and medium. 

This work is also emblematic of the female voice: it has an all female cast and director, it depicts two fully-rounded, complex female characters, and is also written by a female playwright. This is a rarity in an often male-dominated theatre scene, which allows us to discuss female bodies in space openly and honestly.

How You Can Help

This production is currently completely self financed. Therefore, we're hoping to raise approximately $1500 through the generous contributions of people such as yourself to help offset some of our costs. As a small, Not-For-Profit Theatre Company, any funds that we raise at all will help significantly. We are committed to paying all of our Artist for their work. However we would also like to keep ticket costs as affordable.

Your donations will go towards helping us cover the significant costs of Play Rights (approximately $1200 for Professional Rights), Theatre, Space ($2,872.00), Artist Fees ($6277.31), Props/Set/Costumes ($550) along with other marketing and logistical costs.  Any amount, no matter how small, that you are able to spare will be invaluable to us, and truly appreciated

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to aid us financially, don't worry, we understand! We would greatly appreciate it if you would consider spreading the word through platforms such as facebook and twitter. Tell your family, friends, neighbours, co-workers and maybe even strangers about this exciting production about women and their place in the world. Any exposure will help us greatly! 

https://twitter.com/aenigmatheatre

https://www.facebook.com/aenigmatheatre/

https://www.instagram.com/aenigmatheatre/

We hope to see you all at the show in November!!

story:
Sur le fil - Yann Tiersen

*WHO AM I/WHAT IS THIS PROJECT'S HISTORY?

My name is Mathilde Dehaye, both actress & writer.

I am graduating from the Lee Strasberg Theater & Film Institute in June 2014 with a "Two Year Acting Conservatory" diploma. I had recently submitted this play I wrote ("Snow White and The Beast") to "The Strasberg Works", which is a writing contest they hold once a year in my school. Having won that contest, I am now the producer of my full length play. The show will be up in the Marilyn Monroe Theatre, at The Strasberg Institute. It is located in Union Square and the play will be on in the summer, for 3 consecutive days (July 23,24,25). 

*GOAL?

This production is non-profitable, and the budget that is given to us is tiny ($200). Nevertheless, if we can raise funds, our project will meet higher standards. It will enable us to spend money on a few vital things, such as the scenery design (props), the advertisement of the production, as well as inviting industry people to come see the show, so that eventually, we could take this even further. Also, it could give me the opportunity to publish the play, which would simply be a dream come true.

I strongly believe in this play, and some knowledgeable and recognized artists from the business do too. The wonderful Margaret Ladd, wife of Lyle Kessler, is my writing advisor for this play, and it will be directed by the amazing Renoly Santiago, well-known actor and director from the industry.

  •  Margaret Ladd
  •  Renoly Santiago
  •  Renoly Santiago's website

*PLOT SUMMARY:

« Snow White and The Beast » is the story about two lost souls, Lili and Vincent, who fall for one another, and struggle to find the meaning, value, and worthiness of life and themselves in it. Lili and Vincent meet, and are drawn to each other like magnets right away. We’ll explore them going through the biggest challenges of their lives, facing problems related to drugs, loss, appearance, pregnancy, love, the world around them, and the too many demons they come to struggle with. Them two, feeling so alive and torn in a world that seems to be dead. But unfortunately, instead of using their burning flame to light up this world with their Art and understanding, their passion and talent, blow it all away.

*WHY SHOULD YOU HELP US RAISE FUNDS?

To start with, one of the main and most obvious factors is that this project is dear to my heart.

So why would you help us, and not anyone else? I believe I’d explain my reasons better by opening up to you a little, and share with you what might have led me to write this specific piece, besides making me who I am.    

LIFE IS FOR LIVING, that is the first rule I apply to myself. I also remember my mother one day giving me this book called "DREAM IT, LIST IT, DO IT ", and ever since then, it became my second standard. Finally, "IF I AM NOT FOR ME, THEN WHO WILL BE" was written by Eric Morris, and is my last and main principle.

 Humans interest me so much, intrigue, affect and amaze me on such a deep level. I care about people in a very special way and have always been interested in psychology, explaining why so many things occur in society. On the one hand, I want to give, I want to share, I want to help, I want to love. The human being touches me by behaving, by just BEING, by simply living truthfully and honestly. I constantly need to observe, read, explore, understand, comfort and bring answers." You just have to look to find out," as my dad insists on a lot. Yes, Stanislavski was right too when he said that the eye is the window of your soul. On the other hand, I've been hurt, disappointed and believed that, after these heartbreaking and destructive events, I'd never heal, nor forgive anymore because I'd never forget. Well, I decided to not take that path. My big heart might be a great trigger for further sorrows, but at least I know that I stay true to myself and live everything fully. This is called experience, and it is by falling that you learn how to stand up and can then, fall less. Holding grudge or being bitter won't make you climb the heel because it is refusing to fail, which will provoke standing still. No one is perfect, thus I will keep lifting my hand to others to invite them to share respect, honesty, empathy, caring and consideration. I can't change this energy that is on fire in my flesh.

Concerning « Snow White and The Beast », I truly believe that its message touches upon powerful and important subjects that many people come across and can relate to. Human beings from any walk of life can identify with the piece, in terms of «doing what you need to do in order to be whom you need to be.» 

Finally, I would treasure to see how my work is received, gain confidence in my abilities as a writer, and hopefully but most importantly, reach people’s heart, and affect them in a positive way.

I hope you can believe in our team strongly enough to help us raise funds for this beautiful production.
story_txt:
Sur le fil - Yann Tiersen*WHO AM I/WHAT IS THIS PROJECT'S HISTORY?My name is Mathilde Dehaye, both actress & writer.I am graduating from the Lee Strasberg Theater & Film Institute in June 2014 with a "Two Year Acting Conservatory" diploma. I had recently submitted this play I wrote ("Snow White and The Beast") to "The Strasberg Works", which is a writing contest they hold once a year in my school. Having won that contest, I am now the producer of my full length play. The show will be up in the Marilyn Monroe Theatre, at The Strasberg Institute. It is located in Union Square and the play will be on in the summer, for 3 consecutive days (July 23,24,25). *GOAL?This production is non-profitable, and the budget that is given to us is tiny ($200). Nevertheless, if we can raise funds, our project will meet higher standards. It will enable us to spend money on a few vital things, such as the scenery design (props), the advertisement of the production, as well as inviting industry people to come see the show, so that eventually, we could take this even further. Also, it could give me the opportunity to publish the play, which would simply be a dream come true.I strongly believe in this play, and some knowledgeable and recognized artists from the business do too. The wonderful Margaret Ladd, wife of Lyle Kessler, is my writing advisor for this play, and it will be directed by the amazing Renoly Santiago, well-known actor and director from the industry.
 Margaret Ladd

 Renoly Santiago

 Renoly Santiago's website

*PLOT SUMMARY:« Snow White and The Beast » is the story about two lost souls, Lili and Vincent, who fall for one another, and struggle to find the meaning, value, and worthiness of life and themselves in it. I can't change this energy that is on fire in my flesh.Concerning « Snow White and The Beast », I truly believe that its message touches upon powerful and important subjects that many people come across and can relate to. Human beings from any walk of life can identify with the piece, in terms of «doing what you need to do in order to be whom you need to be.» Finally, I would treasure to see how my work is received, gain confidence in my abilities as a writer, and hopefully but most importantly, reach people’s heart, and affect them in a positive way.I hope you can believe in our team strongly enough to help us raise funds for this beautiful production.

story:
About "Akka"

This July, Avant is proud to present the re-staging of the 1991 smash hit, “Akka”, and its much awaited sequel, “Akka - The End” as a double bill production guaranteed to be ‘singularly refreshing’!

A first in Tamil theatre, the “Akka” plays will focus on the issues surrounding Indian transgender women in Singapore and the lives they lead in face of sexual discrimination and communal exile. Taking inspiration from real-life accounts, “Akka” will be a compelling production that will re-evaluate our society’s understanding of sexuality and the phobias and prejudices it harbours on those who both captivate, and repulse its social fabric. 

Sponsership

We seek your generosity through financial support that could help alleviate the financial burden of this project. Your support and partnership will greatly influence the quality of the presentation, talent development, marketing outreach and aid production costs such as venue rental.

As you may already know, staging a performance is no simple feat, especially by a non-profit organisation such as ours. We humbly seek your considerate and substantial sponsorship so that our artistic vision may be realized. 

The Impact

Given the recent debates on sexuality that have begun to arise among our fellow citizens, Akka will prove to be relevant to educate on LGBT issues and provide a platform for audiences to engage in discussions that may change the biased perspectives that one has based on misinformed notions of morality. 

Do Come & Watch Our Show!

The plays are presented on 3rd July till 5th July 2014, 8pm at School of the Arts Drama Theatre. If you would like to come for our production, please do purchase your tickets from Peatix at http://avanttheatreakka.peatix.com

Contact Us

If you are interested to partner with us or to contribute to our project in terms of cash sponsership or in-kind donations, do contact Mr G Selva, Artistic Director for Avant Theatre & Language at 91816737. 

For more information, do visit us at http://www.avanttheatre.com or email us at admin@avanttheatre.com

story:
My name is Carrington and I love dancing, acting and singing! I’m an honor student at a high school for the performing arts where I dance and attend acting classes three days a week. I also take classes at the Richmond Ballet four days a week. In all, I’ve spent the last six years dancing, and the last two years studying acting. I’ve also been working on my singing … mostly in the shower. You’d be surprised how good the acoustics are!

And now, it looks like all my hard work has paid off in a really amazing way – I’ve been accepted into the Boston Conservatory’s Musical Theater Dance Intensive this summer!

The MTDI program helps dancers strengthen their triple threat skills by working with Broadway veterans and acclaimed faculty during a three-week long program. Six days a week I will be taking rigorous dance classes in addition to voice and acting lessons. What an opportunity!!

This intensive is one of the top programs in the country and I know that the experience will make me a stronger singer, actress, and dancer, and help me realize my dream of someday appearing on Broadway.

Any amount you can contribute will put me closer to attending the Summer Intensive at the Boston Conservatory (and help my family immensely). I know that the experience I stand to gain there will help me become a triple threat performer with the confidence and ability to someday make my Broadway dreams come true.

I am turning to all of you for help. Summer Intensives aren’t cheap and the one in Boston is no different. The tuition is $2,250, and housing and meals are another $1,900. Travel expenses, pointe shoes, leotards, and laundry will be additional. My parents have agreed to put a total of $2,000 towards it but I still need to come up with a good chunk of money to make up the difference. I plan on doing what I can to earn money and have a bake sale planned in May. However, between school and dance classes, my schedule doesn’t allow me much free time to earn money … but I guarantee that I’ll keep working hard to earn every penny I can.

 

 Please know that I am forever grateful for anything you are able to contribute!

story:
What we're doing
For our newest, most collaborative project to date, we are selling a house. Yes, we decided to put the property at 5507 Link Avenue on the booming housing market.

We're Uh Theatre Company, and we've been creating new theatre in Austin, TX for a little over a year now. This is our fifth production, and it is amongst our most ambitious to date.

In an immersive journey play, Charley has inherited her childhood home, and with it, the responsibility to sell it as quickly as possible. But this house isn't going without a fight. As our audience moves through the house with Charley, the haunting memory of her friends and family stand between her and giving a successful tour. Prepare to embark on a journey to see both a home and the inner-workings of Charley's mind.

What we need help with
Here's a quick breakdown of our budget for this show:
set - $500
costumes - $180
publicity - $160
tech - $160

These funds are going into original designs for our set, costumes and technology as well as promoting our show to the Austin community.

These are some high stakes. But we're committed to putting For Sale By Owner on without charging our audience, in order to continue providing accessible new theatre. So if you've got some loose coins laying around or a couple million dollars you need to get rid of, consider helping this production become a reality. We need all the good vibes and funding we can get.

Check out our Week 1 of production update!

story:
Our production of Shakespeare's Pericles is a one night only celebration of storytelling at its best. We have six ridiculously talented actors playing a multitude of characters and making music out under the stars with the barest of sets, costumes and props. We believe this aesthetic allows our artists to shine and create a more meaningful connection with the audience. All you need for a great evening of storytelling are some really great storytellers who can spark the imagination of an audience with their voice, body and hearts.

This minimalist aesthetic allows us to keep our budget low, but we still have a few expenses. We need to pay our brilliant actors, rent lights and chairs for the performance venue, purchase necessary props and costumes, and cover the cost of copying our script for all the actors during rehearsal. 

We've already begun the rehearsal process and are incredibly excited to share our work with an audience soon. Help us with this last hurdle, we can't do it without you!

Directed by 

Nora Ives

Starring 

Kate Berman

Sam Bolen

Claire Neumann

Devon Martinez

Keith Rubin

Tom Sanchez


One night only in the garden at Caprices, 138 N 6th Street, BK, NY

June 21st, 8:15 pm showtime

L to the Bedford stop in the heart of Williamsburg

Cash only at the door- $20

*Come hungry, dinner and pastries included in price of ticket

story:
Short Summary

To honor means to remember,

to respect, to pay homage to,

to salute, to recognize.

Theatrical Synergy Productions was pleased to present a reading of Act I of this show on January 26, 2013.  We want to honor all women who served their country in Vietnam.   The Lakeshore Arts Alliance saw this reading and decided to produce this play.  We need your help to present a full production alongside the help from the Lakeshore Arts Alliance.  As we learned from the reading, a piece of their heart goes out to each and every one of them and you can help honor the women who served in Vietnam with not just a piece of your own heart, but with all of it and just a little financial support. 

In order to mount a full production, we will need your financial support. There are many up-front costs associated with putting on any play, not just ours.  Of course, we will recoup most of these costs through ticket sales, but without your up-front support, we cannot produce the show.  Up front costs can range from rights to the play, rental of the venue, materials to build set pieces, costumes, and something as simple as electricity at the rehearsal space.  We’ve come up with a range of fun perks for our backers and we hope you enjoy them and support our creative endeavor.

By supporting this production you are helping us honor, and remember the women who served in Vietnam.  With your financial support at any level, we are able to salute the women of our armed and volunteer services, both past and present. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get:

$10 (Groundling) – A signed program and email or social media thank you from the Lakeshore Arts Alliance (LAA)
$25 (Rush Seating) - A digital 3x5 print of the cast, a signed program and email or social media thank you from the Lakeshore Arts Alliance (LAA)
$50 (Mezzanine Seating) - Facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website and 1 ticket plus a signed program from the cast  and a digital 3x5 print of the cast
$75 (Lower Balcony) – credit in the program and facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website and 1 ticket plus a signed program from the cast and a digital 3x5 print of the cast
$100 (Orchestra Seating) – 2 tickets, credit in the program and Facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website plus a signed program from the cast  and a digital 3x5 print of the cast PLUS "Mary Jo" will serenade you with a song from the show on your voicemail.
$500 (Dress Circle) – opening mention during the director’s curtain speech, 2 tickets, credit in the program and Facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website plus a signed program from the cast  and a digital 3x5 print of the cast PLUS "Mary Jo" will serenade you with a song from the show on your voicemail. 
$1000 (Stage Right Box)  – 2 tickets, credit in the program and Facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website plus a signed program from the cast and a digital 3x5 print of the cast, a photo opportunity on the walkway at the Red Barn with the cast PLUS "Mary Jo" will serenade you with a song from the show on your voicemail.   (only 5 available)
$1000 (Stage Left Box)  – Sit backstage during a show for a different perspective, and join the cast in greeting the audience post show (not available on opening night, limited to one person per pledge.) A signed program from the cast  and a digital 3x5 print of the cast, a photo opportunity on the walkway at the Red Barn with the cast   (only 5 available)
$2000 (Producer) – Q & A for 20 people and reception (not available on opening night), 2 tickets, a mention in the program and Facebook credit and thank you and credit on LAA's website plus a signed program from the cast, and a digital 3x5 print of the cast a photo opportunity on the walkway at the Red Barn with the cast PLUS "Mary Jo" will serenade you with a song from the show on your voicemail.   (only 5 available)
$5000 (The Bard) - The cast and crew of A Piece of My Heart will travel to you; date to be determined between production staff and perk donor.  A private "Donut Dolly" reception will follow your invite only performance of the show.  A digital 3x5 print of the cast, a photo opportunity on the walkway at the Red Barn with the cast, a signed program and email or social media thank you from the Lakeshore Arts Alliance (LAA)

The Impact

The Lakeshore Arts Alliance  (LAA) was created in 2005 by a group of Saugatuck area residents in order to provide a venue that supports local and regional talent  through education, volunteering and performance. LAA is a not-for-profit membership organization with a 501(c)3, nonprofit status comprised of artists and those who love and support the arts. Our focus is all aspects of arts education and performance with both  in-house and outreach programs. The Alliance promotes increased exposure to a variety of arts disciplines in southwest Michigan. 

Who We Are

"A Piece of My Heart" was brought to the Lakeshore Arts Alliance by Theatrical Synergy Productions as a show that needs to be done; a story that needs to be shared.  The Lakeshore Arts Alliance willingly picked up the production to help spread the story as they too believed in the message behind the play. 

The name “Theatrical Synergy Productions” is new; a fresh perspective. The founding members want to share a more enlightened theatrical experience with you. We bring you our experience and talent, not only to both entertain and enrich our audiences; but to bring you shows that demand that you think about what you have seen.  We strive to bring you the best productions possible – shows that you will not only remember, but feel compelled to share with your friends.

The founding members of Theatrical Synergy Productions are Margo Ramos Kendall and Ed Walters.

Margo was involved in theatre from kindergarten on; ending at Regina Dominican High School; then she majored in Theater at Indiana Univeristy, and earned a Theatre teacher's certification at Loyola. She is the Director/creative force on stage for Theatrical Synergy.

Ed played the male lead in his second grade play, and the very next year, ran lights instead. He's always been the tech guy. Also a former educator, he has worked with many local school drama groups and community theatres. He operates The Solution LLC, which provides exactly that -- solutions for presentation, audio, video, lighting and control.

Theatrical Synergy strives to bring you shows that are socially responsible, that make you think, and that bring issues into the public eye.  These shows cannot happen without your support!

LAA is a not-for-profit membership organization with a 501(c)3, nonprofit status comprised of artists and those who love and support the arts. Our focus is all aspects of arts education and performance with both  in-house and outreach programs. The Alliance promotes increased exposure to a variety of arts disciplines in southwest Michigan. 
Who We Are
"A Piece of My Heart" was brought to the Lakeshore Arts Alliance by Theatrical Synergy Productions as a show that needs to be done; a story that needs to be shared.  The Lakeshore Arts Alliance willingly picked up the production to help spread the story as they too believed in the message behind the play. 
The name “Theatrical Synergy Productions” is new; a fresh perspective. The founding members want to share a more enlightened theatrical experience with you. We bring you our experience and talent, not only to both entertain and enrich our audiences; but to bring you shows that demand that you think about what you have seen.  We strive to bring you the best productions possible – shows that you will not only remember, but feel compelled to share with your friends.
The founding members of Theatrical Synergy Productions are Margo Ramos Kendall and Ed Walters.
Margo was involved in theatre from kindergarten on; ending at Regina Dominican High School; then she majored in Theater at Indiana Univeristy, and earned a Theatre teacher's certification at Loyola. She is the Director/creative force on stage for Theatrical Synergy.
Ed played the male lead in his second grade play, and the very next year, ran lights instead. He's always been the tech guy. Also a former educator, he has worked with many local school drama groups and community theatres. He operates The Solution LLC, which provides exactly that -- solutions for presentation, audio, video, lighting and control.
Theatrical Synergy strives to bring you shows that are socially responsible, that make you think, and that bring issues into the public eye.  These shows cannot happen without your support!

story:
We are fundraising for the 4th cycle of the Right to Dance: 2 Month Intensive!!
*note: video now has closed captions! 

What is the Right To Dance : 2 Month Intensive?
This revolutionary movement program, approaches dance with the idea that we all have the right to dance.  We affirm and welcome Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans, Queer, and Spectrum people, people of colour, and people with varying body sizes and abilities. Each year 10 people are selected through applications and over 2 months are mentored to create their own solo performance piece  and given training in  dance techniques including hip hop, street styles, ballet, and contemporary. The program culminates with a two night showcase of solo performances at a local theatre for friends, family, and our communities in Toronto. We are seeking your support to fund the 4th cycle of this  incredible program.

“I know that almost instantly after beginning to work with ILL NANA, everything changed. I have grown almost incredulously only because of the strength and vision of ILL NANA and their tireless commitment and care to their programming and the people in it; people who have previously been kicked out, pushed out of dance, discouraged, silenced, erased out of dance; but who are ESSENTIAL to dance, NON-NEGOTIABLE to dance.”
- Shaunga (2M1 Cycle 1 participant, Cycle 2 guest facilitator, Cycle 3 guest choreographer)


“The intensive taught me a different way to see myself and move through the world. If it weren't for the affirmative and insightful teaching style of kumari, Jelani and Sze-Yang I would not have been able to connect to dance, something I have always been afraid of doing or felt excluded from. As a vital resource for marginalized communities, the RTD 2MI nurtured close relationships among our group and offered the precious space to hold each other throughout our journey to tell our stories through movement. The intensive was the single most life-altering event in my life and I can only hope support for it keeps growing, because it is so urgently needed.”
- Anabel (RTD: 2M1 Intensive cycle 3)

What your support will go to:
$7, 800 - Facilitation and Mentorship
$1, 200 - Program Coordination
$1,000 - Participant Honorarium
$1 000 - Program expenses- including snacks and Transit tokens
$1 000 - Showcase venue rental and staff

Please give generously and check out our perks!!

"As both a past participant and guest facilitator of the Right To Dance Two Month Intensive, I cannot overstate the relevance of this project to the lives of queer youth. The connection, validation, strength and support that I felt in finding community and genuine self-expression within the art form that I love was overwhelming.”
-Meg Leitold (RTD: 2M1 Cycle 1 participant, and Cycle 2 guest facilitator

Who we are:
ILL NANA/DiverseCity Dance Company is a queer multiracial dance company that embraces difference as strength and are committed to challenging the landscape of dance by performing our stories on stage as well as providing more accessible education and performance opportunities for LGBTTIQQ2S communities prioritizing people of colour, various body types, backgrounds, classes, and abilities. ILL NANA/DCDC hosts Making a Stage For Our Stories Annual Dance Conference and Showcase, Right To Dance: free affirming drop-in dance classes, and 2 month dance intensive. For more details on our programming and to donate to our other initiatives visit: www.illnanadcdc.com

If you'd like to offer a perk, please e-mail us at ill_nana@live.ca

Please spread the word or donate!!

Thank you for supporting the 4th cycle of the 2 Month Intensive.

story:
Starring Clara Bow, (the It Girl Musical ) is the fascinating musical story of Clara's remarkable rise to "Fame and Fortune" as the biggest star of Paramount Pictures during the late 1920's and how she became the worlds first silent film sex symbol. Brooklyn-born Clara Bow came from abject poverty and was determined from an early age to become a movie star. Her mother was mentally ill, and her father was an idle alcoholic, who rarely worked. Somehow Clara managed to scrape together enough money for some photographs and with them she entered a popular movie magazine beauty contest, and won it. The Fame and Fortune contest promised the winner pictures in the Magazine, a part in a movie and an evening dress.

Little did anyone realize this was the first step in what would become an amazing if short lived career in Hollywood pictures. Clara made it through the talkies  transition and was a highly paid and in-demand actress. She turned her back on Hollywood at the remarkably young age of 28.  For a really vivid overview of Clara check out the BBC video at You Tube (click the arrow above). It will inform those of you who may be less familiar with her history. This documentary is very well done and very informative..

We have written a show that takes the theater audience through Clara's incredible life from the age of 16 until her passing at the age of 60 in a Culver City bungalow, a nearly forgotten star. Listen to the simple demos of the first two songs. The first is "Hittin The Bricks"  which decribes how Clara's first agent Maxine Alton will get her around New York City right after she won the Fame and Fortune contest. The second song is "On the Road Before Me Now"  sung at the end of Act One when Clara departs for Hollywood to see if she can truly become a Movie Star

It's going to be a big musical. The role of Clara will be played by two actresses, one for the 1920's and another as Clara in later years. I have written the Book and Lyrics. The delightful score is by Barry Fasman, my long time writing partner, with whom I wrote the musical Chinaberry Bayou ( ASCAP and Disney's first Musical Theater workshop.) Among his many achievements, Barry was Musical Director for FAME which ran on NBC-TV for many years. 

Our project is in need of funding to record 16 new songs for the score, and to begin the workshop process, where we sit with actors and dancers to work out the production. I have done this before, most recently with The Seven Year Itch, which I have workshopped twice, once with Jane Kralowski and Peter Scolari and once with Rachel York and Ross Lehman, both in New York. Indiegogo backers will help us develop this project for the Broadway stage by raising the funds to cover the costs of recording demos, preparing the script, hiring rehearsal space, finding and casting actors in the parts and developing the art direction of the project. 

Here is  a portion of the script with the song  "Hittin the Bricks"  Remember  at this stage we have just a simple demo. It will be professionally recorded later.

Act One Scene Six

Brewster Publications 1922

At rise:Photographers and newspaper men have gathered for the Award ceremony of the Fame and Fortune contest. Present are Clara, Maxine Alton, Gillespie, Allcock, Fisher, Neysa McMein, Miss Palmer, and Christy, plus a group of office workers.

Brewster

Here she is Boys, the little lady who has won "Fame and Fortune" for 1922. She is very young, only 16, but full of confidence, determination and ambition. Her 5 screen tests show an emotional range of expression beyond her years. Every judge had the same enthusiastic verdict, she screened perfectly. From Brooklyn, New York, Miss Clara Bow!

Sound but polite applause. Shyly, Clara steps forward, uncomfortably wearing a nice new dress.

Clara

I wanna ~~~well, to thank everybody, here at Brewster Movie Magazines ~~for the kind treatment I got~~ and all the wonderful things they done for me from the time I entered the contest ~~~ until today, and also for the really beautiful gown they so kindly gave me today and, Um, I hope with all the proper training I will get ~~I will grow into a really proper actress~~ worthy of all your help. Mr. Brewster said the magazine will help me get a part in a Motion Picture and I am most of all~ grateful for that. It’s my dream to be a real big movie star. I hope you will let me. That’s my prayer.

Brewster

Thanks indeed Clara, and now the Boys here wanna take your picture holding the cup.

Clara then poses, while Brewster takes Maxine Alton aside.

Brewster

As I promised Maxine, here’s 25 dollars advance to show our girl around to some of the movie outfits. We promised in the contest to help get her a part, and in years past we have done that, such as we did with Corliss Palmer.

Maxine

Yes, Corliss seems to have done well enough. But remember this kid is only 16. There’s a law against doing too much for her at that age.

Brewster

Now,now.. Maxine. Remember!Corliss is living with Mrs. Brewster and me.

Maxine

How convenient. OK. I get it Eugene.This kid’s got something. Let’s see what I can do. She’s had it pretty tough, at home I mean. Anything she gets now will be an improvement.

Brewster

I’ve heard. It sounds rather sordid.

Maxine moves to Clara and the throng around her.

Maxine

Ok Boys! Let her breathe.You’ve got all you need and we have to get her started.

Clara, my girl, we’ve got people to see and places to go.

Clara

Thanks everybody, be seein ya!

Maxine

We’ve gotta catch the subway.

We’ll take the IRT.

There’s some one in Astoria~

I want you to see.

From now on every day~

From eight o’clock to six~

We’re gonna be hittin’ the bricks!

We’re gonna be hittin’ the bricks!

The studios are busy.

Producers run the show.

We’re gonna be presenting you~

To everyone we know.

It’s not gonna be that easy~

You’re gonna take some licks.

We’re gonna be hittin’ the bricks!

We’re gonna be hittin’ the bricks!

Clara

I’m nervous ~I’m excited.

I wanna do my best.

My heart is beatin’ like a drum~

That’s poundin’ in my chest.

I wish I didn’t but I feel~

Afraid and insecure.

I hope I’m what they’re looking for ~

I’m really not so sure~

But if I’m gonna make it in the flicks~

I’m gonna be hittin’the bricks!

I’m gonna be hittin’ the bricks!

Maxine

Directors take a concept~

They call it mass appeal.

They pedal it ferociously~

A giant spinning wheel.

They do their hocus pocus~

An keep it all in focus!

Cut and print and put it on the reel.

But they need a face to work with~

With Arrow collar’s manliness~

They need your beauty’s sweet caress.

And Baby lets face it~you’re ideal!

And when I say we’ll show‘em~

What’s in your bag of tricks~

We’ll start out by hittin the bricks!

Clara

It’s not gonna be that easy.

We’re gonna take some licks.

But we’re gonna be hitting the bricks!!

Clara

If I’m gonna make it in the flicks~

MAXINE

You’re gonna be takin’ some licks!

TOGETHER

We’re gonna be hittin’ the bricks!!
