story:
Short Summary

Sarah Tuning has dedicated herself to bringing beauty into the world by dancing on stage.  She applied and was accepted into the California State School of the Arts in their summer dance program with an emphasis in ballet.  Sarah did receive a partial scholarship, but not enough to cover the expenses of the tuition, the supplies and the travel to and from Valencia.   For a minimal amount of funding, we can further Sarah's dreams.

What We Need & What You Get

After scholarship, tuition to CSSSA is $1050.

Sarah also needs to purchase jazz shoes, knee pads, a CD-R or iPod, a Lapa, new pointe shoes, several new leotards and tights and other supplies so she is prepared for her month of classes in Southern California.  We estimate this will cost between $300 and $500.

Lastly, Sarah needs to be able to get to and from Valencia.  Depending on the funds raised, driving her down and back would cost $300 or flying her down and back would cost $450.

What you get?  Satisfaction in helping a rising young dancer and scholar, a personal thank you note, recognition in her dance recital program, and a copy of her final dance recital video from CSSSA.  Finally, you get immense gratitude from a young lady whose dreams are in the making.

In addition, if you have suggestions for what you might like as a "perk", please let us know and we'll see if it can be accommodated.

The Impact

Sarah is two steps away from Company where she currently dances and she dreams of going to college to major in dance.  We're a family of artists and musicians so funds have to stretch as far as they can.  Sarah is talented and has a giving heart and shares her art form with younger students.  Attending CSSSA would give her more knowledge to share and with which to create a more peaceful and beautiful world.

Sarah says, "Attending CSSSA, first and foremost, would greatly further my dance skills.  It would give me experience working with teachers and dance forms that I would not normally have the opportunity to do.  CSSSA would also allow me to network in the dance world, as well as have the opportunity for further scholarships for college.  In addition, upon graduation from the program I would be named a California Arts Scholar which helps when applying for colleges of dance."

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE THIS SITE!!!  Send it by email to others, post it in your Facebook, in your Live Journal, or your blog.  Tweet about this.  Even if you can't contribute funds, someone you know may be dying to support a young artist and you're giving them an opportunity by sharing this website with them.

THANK YOU!!!

story:
We are Proximity, a theatre company dedicated to telling stories that expose the human heart. 
 
I am Kyra, Proximity's Artistic Director. Each time I embark on a new show I ask myself why I do this work. The answer is: Because it's all I know how to do. I am most honest when I am creating a show. I want to walk towards what scares me and what feels impossible in hopes that others will feel inspired to do the same. Creating shows is the language I use to frame the moments that make up our lives.
 
This summer, Proximity will be creating two original pieces of work. Our first piece, "Desire," is about bravery, fear, intimacy, embarrassment, love, fantasy and truth. It is a piece about the space between what is real and what is myth. It is a piece about the unknown. The second piece will be created with a group of teens. They will be asked to bring their own point of view and create a show that explores what it means to be alive.  It will be about bravery, fear, intimacy, embarrassment, love, fantasy and truth. It will be a piece about the unknown.
 
We are asking for your help to make these projects possible. This work could not exist without an audience or without the support of our community. Your generosity will inspire people to connect to their bodies, themselves, and each other by vigorously exploring how alive we can be in our own skins. To tell stories that expose the human heart.
 
Sincerely,
Kyra Lehman
Artistic Director
Proximity

story:
Am 9. November 2014 wurde dem Mauerfall zum 25. Mal gedacht. 25 Jahre nach dem deutschen Mauerfall sind Europas Grenzen erneut dicht. Zehntausende Menschen ertrinken, dehydrieren und kentern an Europas Außengrenzen. Alles zum Projekt "Erster Europäischer Mauerfall" hier:

http://www.europaeischer-mauerfall.de
story_txt: Am 9. November 2014 wurde dem Mauerfall zum 25. Mal gedacht. 25 Jahre nach dem deutschen Mauerfall sind Europas Grenzen erneut dicht. Zehntausende Menschen ertrinken, dehydrieren und kentern an Europas Außengrenzen. Alles zum Projekt "Erster Europäischer Mauerfall" hier:http://www.europaeischer-mauerfall.de

story:
So…What Is This?

Featuring Christine Schisano and Abby Pechman as the writers and performers of this original sketch comedy show. 

“Dear Tina: I’m Wearing a Wig” has been a passion project for over 8 months and will finally be realized November 2014. Through many ideas, good and bad, we are finally ready to put something up in front of live people.  There is only so much feedback one can get from a Chihuahua.

This show will feature live sketch comedy, filmed sketch comedy, original music as well as song parodies. 

The location is currently TBA.....once contracts are signed we will confirm the location!!

What We Need 

All funds raised will go to:

-Theatre rental and fees

-Costuming

-Wigs…lots of wigs

-Props

-Rehearsal space

-Filming and editing of sketches

-Paying the actors enough to get a large iced coffee

Check out our page for some great PERKS when you donate!

If we exceed our goal, the surplus of funds will be applied to our upcoming sketch comedy web series Spring 2015!

The Impact

Many hours have been spent, over coffee and beer and on late-night subway rides, writing and dreaming of putting up our own project. (And meeting Tina Fey)

We want to make people laugh. (Especially Tina Fey)

We want to take an idea and make it a reality. (Tina can you hear us?)

Risks & Challenges

This show is a huge risk for us.   Any show in NYC is a risk.  Will anyone show up?  Will anyone be drunk enough to laugh at our work?  Will the wigs stay on our tiny, misshapen heads?

We think this risk is worth it!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate funds, there are other ways you can help!  Help us get the word out via Facebook, Twitter, and even good old-fashioned email.  Don’t forget to use the share tool on our Indiegogo page!

And if you are in the NYC area and want to help out the day of the show, contact us!

Stay tuned to this page for more information including show date and time!

story:
The Little Match Girl on Tour!

In March 2012 we presented a brand new theatrical imagining of 'The Little Match Girl' to audiences in Manchester, UK. The show was such a success, less than a week later we were offered the chance to tour the show as part of a cross-cultural exchange in Tunis!

  • Schmucks Theatre was founded in Manchester in 2009 and has since produced 7 acclaimed productions across the UK. 'The Little Match Girl' will mark the third country we have performed in, and our first international tour! The show won three Manchester In Fringe Theatre Awards; for Best Director, Best Lighting and The Judge's Award for Originality and Innovation. 
  • We are planning on touring the show AND making a documentary about the entire process. This isn't just taking an award-winning show to another country, this is also giving us the opportunity to make a (hopefully award-winning) documentary about the whole process, from the first rehearsal to the plane ride home!
  • The production has the potential to be received in any culture, and by an audience of any language. The piece is without spoken dialogue, and is very visual, featuring extensive, complex puppetry. The show also features an original score, which is performed live as part of the performance, fully immersing the audience in the world of 'The Little Match Girl'.
  • By contributing to this project, you will be enabling a group of emerging British theatre and filmmakers to have their work seen on the international stage at an early point in their careers; not only benefiting them, but also aiding the development of the exciting cultural scene in Tunisia following the peaceful revolution there. This project will have an impact on people internationally, not just at home! The project is championed by the University of Manchester's research programme 'In Place of War', which is currently focussing on the digitlisation and online sharing of theatre practitioner's work following the Arab Spring. 

What We Need & What You Get

Lets break it down:

  • We need to raise the money to pay for 20 return flights from London to Tunis. As you can well imagine, these don't come too cheap! We have a cast of 9, a director, producer, two stage hands, a musical director, a band of four, a documentary filmmaker and a cello to get across the pond to Tunis! We want to take the production in its entirety from Manchester, so that we don't sacrifice on artistic quality for our Tunisian audiences. Move over Lloyd-Webber, this is the theatrical tour of the year!
  • We also need to raise the money to pay for the hire of sound equipment for the making of the documentary, for the week that we will be working in Tunisia. 
  • We have some really great perks for you all, to get you excited about helping us (literally) get this project off the ground! These include tickets, signed posters and props, and a very exciting exclusive filmed version of the show! A school play this show ain't, and the DVD will reflect that, with the show being filmed specially on location in Tunis. 
  • If we don't reach our goal, then all of the money we have been able to raise will go towards cutting the cost of flights for everybody involved as much as we can to make this amazing opoortunity become a reality.

Why you should support us

  • This is a rare opportunity to take an exciting revitilization of a classical piece of European culture into an African artistic community, and to share our culture with the audiences of Tunisia. In the years following the revolution in Tunisia, the cultural scene there is thriving, finally able to develop its artistic practise without a dominating, censoring regime. By taking 'The Little Match Girl' into this cultural revolution, we are able to learn from Tunisian artistic practises and Tunisian art culture, as well as weaving our own work into the thriving cultural fabric of the country. This will not only benefit the participants of the tour, but also all those who view the documentary, as we hope it will capture the reality of the cross-cultural exchange process, and share it with as wide an audience as possible. 
  • Schmucks Theatre, and Nathan Shreeve (Director) has a strong track record for theatrical work, being critically acclaimed in publications such as The Huffington Post, The Scotsman, Whatsonstage and The Jewish Chronicle. Schmucks Theatre has been seen at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, the Buxton Fringe Festival, and even the Liverpool Shakespeare Festival. 
  • Jo Gewirtz, our resident filmmaker has had her work exhibited at the London Soho Shorts Festival, on the TimeWarner cable network in the US, and UK satellite television. She has worked on music videos (Mel C's 'Rock Me'), documentaries (The Rushes - London Soho Shorts) and narrative short films (Can I Interest You in Christ - New York Film Academy). 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and help us make some noise about our campaign!

story:
Summary

I am sooo excited to be named a 2012 EMERGENYC artist by NYU's Hemispheric institute for Performance & Politics and I'm fundraising in order to take part in this amazing program. During this process I'll be creating the next draft of my solo 5 STAR Chick and by donating you will be helping create this work of art too!

What I Need:

$700 

Simply put, NYU awarded me a $200 scholarship, I've put in $200 and I'm fundraising! All funds raised above the goal will go to the production budget for the full show in the fall.

The Impact

5 STAR Chick is my first self produced solo work in New York City and I'm diving into full fledge artist life. You support will help me along this path. I look forward to creating art that that reflects my interests in humor, the unraveling of formality, the collision of pop culture with fine art and the multiplicity of existence. What does this look like on stage you ask? Watch the "Booty Pageant" Section of 5 STAR Chick via the Youtube video above.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends.

Participate in the creation of the piece! I'll be collecting 5 Star stories and ideas along the way so be sure to sign up to my mailing list.

Sign up to volunteer to help with the full production of the dance Fall 2012 by joining my mailing list.

Donate one of your amazing skills. Maybe you can sew a mean headband or read a contract like nobody's business - all skills are welcome! Join my mailing list.

Join my mailing list to get updates on performances, open rehearsals and volunteer opportunities by clicking here https://denae.batchbook.com/lists/form/52

story:
HELP SEND THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA'S BICYCLE DANCE TEAM ON TOUR!!

We’ve been invited to Mini Bike Winter in Portland to dance, ride and plan the revolution with our bike dance compatriots from across the globe, but we need your help to get there!

Donate online here, and help support our vision!

We are twelve women who dance on, with and about bicycles.  We dance to promote health, camaraderie, positive body image, gender equality, environmental responsibility, autonomous transportation and FUN.

Mini Bike Winter is an annual gathering in Portland, Oregon dedicated to every possible kind of fun that can be had on two tiny wheels.  People come from all across the country to ride, play and explore the many possibilities of bicycles together.

What we'll do with the money:
+ outfit all our dance bikes with pegs and gyro headsets
+ buy fuel filters and a new tire for our veggie oil tour bus
+ print sweet new t-shirts and stickers
+ GET OUT OF DODGE to entertain, inspire and collaborate with the people of Portland and along the way!

In return, what we have for you:
Oh my goodness, so many things!  We've got tickets to Freak Bike Cabaret, the hottest bike event of the winter (co-presented with Cyclecide!).  We've got stickers, t-shirts and posters.  We've got custom bike bling.  And we have superfine one-of-a-kind experiences - the kinds of thrills that money just can't buy... except right now.  Check out the sidebar over there >>>>> for all the dirty details!



What else you can do to help support us:
Help spread the word!  Check the IndieGoGo tools up there to post our campaign to Facebook and Twitter and all that kind of thing.  And, even more fun, help out!  We need paparazzi to photograph at Freak Bike Cabaret, we need video editors for all our movie projects, we need designers and illustrators and printers and welders and dancers.  Email us!  We'll hang out!  bayareaderailleurs@gmail.com!

story:
In 2002 when DIVAfest began, the primary goal was to provide women theatre artists with a supportive place to develop and showcase new plays and theatre work.  Now DIVAfest begins a new decade by embracing many different art forms and female voices, spreading our wings and gathering our collective power.  We look forward to the festival launching women into new worlds of female creativity and leadership through the arts.

Join us for three weeks of theatre, dance, music, burlesque, visual arts and crafts, empowerment workshops, lectures, demonstrations and symposiums inspired by the female perspective.  Thank you to the many, many women who have come together to make this happen. And thank YOU for considering a contribution to the cause!

What does it cost to put on a festival?

  • $10 pays for one hour of rehearsal space
  • $25 provides an hour of production support
  • $50 helps us to host a symposium
  • $100 supports one DIVAfest performer
  • $250 gets the word out with postcards and brochures 
  • $500 opens the theater for one night

What are the rewards of supporting DIVAfest?

  • $1 + the undying gratitude of the DIVAs
  • $10+ special thanks on our website and at the theatre
  • $25+ two complementary drinks at the theatre
  • $50+ two tickets to the performance of your choice
  • $100+ a special invitation to the closing celebration
  • $250+ a VIP pass to all performances and events in the festival
  • $500+ lunch with the artistic director

DIVAfest is a fiscally sponsored project of EXIT Theatre. Your donation is tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you can make a donation, there are plenty of ways to support DIVAfest.

  • Spread the word! Find us on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Come to the festival!
  • Email mail@divafest.info to volunteer.

story:
The Story:

Scott is breaking up with Audra, abruptly ending three years of serious dating. But it is not going well.

Because after refusing to let Audra in on the reason for the breakup, Scott finds himself unwittingly locked in her coat closet.

So begin two tales of coinciding desperation, made worse by that recurring closet, a spider, some dirty dishes and a lot of bad weather.

Audra and Scott fall apart and together, wondering all the while "is love ever enough?"


Who We Are:

We are three theatre artists and friends coming together to put on an original play in the Venus/Adonis Theater Festival in NYC this February.  But putting on a play is a big job, especially for three people just in the relative beginning of their professional theatrical careers, and we could use some support to make this production one that we can be completely pleased with and proud of.

We are Benjamin Shipley, Matt Hays and Lisa VillaMil, three graduates from Ithaca College with the singular desire to make good theatre.  Between us we have dozens upon dozens of productions, ranging in experience from stage management to acting to design, and everything else in-between.  We are people who live for the arts, and who are passionate about telling  truthful, meaningful stories through our theatrical medium. 

We are taking on all aspects of this production all by ourselves, from playwrighting to producing, from directing to acting and advertizing.  Yeah.  We're going to be pretty busy.  But ownership of a production is important to us.  It allows us to be our most creative, experimental and independent.

By contributing to our campaign, you are helping us ensure our ownership, and also enabling us to take an otherwise basic production and make it an extraordinary one.  Our set will improve in aesthetic; we will hire a Stage Manager to help keep the production on track; you will help us pay for festival costs and professional recording - and those are just a few of the ways you could help us, all of which would make a huge impact on the overall success of our production and vision.

By helping us, you would nurture three budding artists, and help us create a foothold for our careers in one of the greatest - and possibly the most pivotal - theatrical cities in the world. 

See more info on our production and the festival:

https://www.facebook.com/ACertainFallofRain

http://venusnytheaterfestival.com/venus-adonis-theater-festival-thespis/


What We Need & What You Get:

For this production, we need $1,500.  This includes the $500 festival participation fee, a $200 professional video recording fee, a $250 set/scenic budget, $200 printing/advertising costs for playbills, scripts and posters, and an amount to hire ourselves a stage manager.  Also added to this amount are estimated fees for indigogo's cut of our campaign, and shipping costs for perks.

Perks are awesome!  We will personalize an offstage character with your name, or take you out to coffee, or amuse you with our dazzling personalities in a video thank-you.  Or you could be listed as a producer and see your name in our playbill.  And these are just a few of our great perks for helping us out!

If our campaign doesn't reach its goal, we will have to cut the professional recording of our show - something that could be put on actors' reels, or be used to advertise the play to other theatres for further productions.  We will also have to cut back significantly in advertising and set design.  While none of these are things that would break our production, their inclusion would ensure that our show is fully successful with a hopefully packed house, and a chance to win prizes at the end of the festival's run.  The Venus/Adonis Theater Festival is also a competition, and we want a product worthy of competition standards, as well as our own high artistic standards.

Please help us create something new, powerful and meaningful.


    Risks & Challenges... bleh...

    If you help us, we basically risk being too awesome.

    Seriously though, we are already in the festival and committed to it wholly.    Nothing will stop us from telling this story, but your help and contributions will take our production to a new level.

    "A Certain Fall of Rain" actually marks 4 NYC theatrical debuts between two of the production members.  For Ben, this will be his first time directing in NYC.  For Lisa, this is her first time producing in, having her original play mounted in, and acting in NYC.  But new-ness shouldn't pose a risk.  Everyone in this production is well-experienced and quite dedicated.

    Theatre is challenging by nature - but that's the fun part!

    Other Ways You Can Help!

    Can't contribute?  No worries!  You can still help by spreading the word.  Share us on Facebook, and like our page.  And of course - come and see the show!

    We appreciate any help you can give us.  Thank you for reading and we hope to see you in NYC for the opening of "A Certain Fall of Rain!"

    Tickets!! - http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/1087538

If our campaign doesn't reach its goal, we will have to cut the professional recording of our show - something that could be put on actors' reels, or be used to advertise the play to other theatres for further productions.  We will also have to cut back significantly in advertising and set design.  While none of these are things that would break our production, their inclusion would ensure that our show is fully successful with a hopefully packed house, and a chance to win prizes at the end of the festival's run.  The Venus/Adonis Theater Festival is also a competition, and we want a product worthy of competition standards, as well as our own high artistic standards.
Please help us create something new, powerful and meaningful.
   
Risks & Challenges... bleh...
If you help us, we basically risk being too awesome.Seriously though, we are already in the festival and committed to it wholly.    Nothing will stop us from telling this story, but your help and contributions will take our production to a new level."A Certain Fall of Rain" actually marks 4 NYC theatrical debuts between two of the production members.  For Ben, this will be his first time directing in NYC.  For Lisa, this is her first time producing in, having her original play mounted in, and acting in NYC.  But new-ness shouldn't pose a risk.  Everyone in this production is well-experienced and quite dedicated.Theatre is challenging by nature - but that's the fun part!
  Other Ways You Can Help!Can't contribute?  No worries!  You can still help by spreading the word.  Share us on Facebook, and like our page.  And of course - come and see the show!We appreciate any help you can give us.  Thank you for reading and we hope to see you in NYC for the opening of "A Certain Fall of Rain!"Tickets!! - http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/1087538

story:
A Short Summary

  • Hey Friends and Family! It's Camilla and David (just two) of the creative team behind the play Hour Farther (You'll hear from Kirk Taylor in a bit)
  • The Emerson Theater Collaborative (ETC) seeks to bring to life an unforgettable story about adoption, family, love, and what holds us together
  • Hour Farther will inspire our Youth to learn the importance of family and community
  • Our Youth face many challenges today in the absence of strong family ties
  • Hour Farther opens the doorway for conversation about family and the critical importance of communication, reconciliation, and redemption
  • To donate is to give a child and a parent a second chance at life and love

What We Need & What You Get

  • ETC needs $2,000 to bring the production to life in CT and get it moving in NYC
  • Funds from this campaign will be used toward venue rental, actor honorariums, travel, marketing, and other production expenses 
  • By supporting this new work you can ... get an autographed picture of our star, Kirk Taylor, in the Last Dragon (or Full Metal Jacket or School Daze) ... get a copy of the script autographed by the Playwright ... have dinner with the Playwright and Director ... get a small role in the play ... visit a rehearsal and talk with the actors ... even become a Producer.  Feeling excited!? These are just a few of the exciting perks you can have!
  • Indiegogo allows us to keep what we raise, so all of your donations will help ETC have an amazing run in CT and help us get the show to NYC

The Impact

  • Adoption is an act of unconditional love that makes an incredible impact on adopted children, their parents, their family, and their communities

  • Hour Farther educates the world on the significance of adoption while creating an incredible piece of Art 
  • Hour Farther elevates the challenges that adopted children (and adults) face
  • While the focus is on adoption, the play's themes of reconciliation and redemption are universal 
  • The plays also dove tails with the I Am Worthy Suicide Prevention Project, which ETC raised funds and awareness for (thank you to those who donated!) 

Risks & Challenges

  • ETC produced two readings to develop this beautiful story
  • The impact of this story far out weighs the risk and challenges of producing it
  • The issues raised in the production may make people uneasy, but we know by telling the story with compassion we can eliminate those concerns
  • ETC plans to continue to raise awareness of our funding needs in order to bring this heart felt story to life

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people are not able to contribute financially and we understand.  There are other ways that you can help:

  • Encourage others to get tickets and to go see the play
  • Share our FB posts with others
  • Encourage others to visit our Indiegogo campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to helps us get the word out about this amazing production

And that's all there is to it.

story:
I am hoping to raise $2000 in order to stage a production of "The Belle of Amherst" by William Luce from the 26th- 29th of March, 2015 as an actor showcase at the beautiful Local Woman's Council House.  “The Belle of Amherst” is a one woman show portraying the life of Emily Dickinson.

After being challenged by actor/ director Jeremy Webb to get off my behind and create my own work, I stumbled upon "The Belle of Amherst" and fell immediately in love with it's humour, power and character. It's the perfect piece for an actor to sink their teeth into and with its 15 characters it's the perfect little show off piece for an emerging artist. 

A week after receiving Jeremy's challenge I brought him the script and demanded he direct me in it and thankfully he agreed. A minute later we convinced stage manager/ theatre artist Daniel Oulton to join the project and all of a sudden I had my dream team. 

Now all we need is some help from you! All funds raised will go to production costs:
-Script licensing rights
-Venue
-Costume
-Props
 -Set

Every little bit helps and we are so grateful for your donations. If donating is not an option but you still would like to lend a hand, simply press the share button and tell your friends, parents, grandparents, baristas and the like and come on out to "The Belle of Amherst" in March! 

xox

Robin Hebb

story:
Short Summary

We are The Cage Players, a group of teenagers with a passion for the theatre and a love for working together. Simply for the reason of preference, we wanted to perform in our own non-profit group rather than a school production or costly teen stage show.

Because of these ideals, last year we started this acting group comprised of teenagers, where we could pick our own shows, gain some leadership skills, and get experience in the acting world that we hope to someday be a bigger part of.

Last year, our own Alison Lucero wrote a parody musical that we performed and can be found in its entirety on youtube. (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUuUKtH7gtw)

Now we are preparing to do our next show, CLUE: The Musical, a musical interpretation of the internationally popular board game of murder, mystery, and mayhem, written by Peter DePietro.

What We Need

To break down our expenses:

  • The rights to the show, which will allow us to legally put on the performance

                         --------------> $1300

  • Costumes, Props, and Set

                          -------------->$500

  • Renting Stage space

                         -------------->$500

  • Extra donations will always be appreciated and can be put towards bettering this performance or future performances.
  • Similarly, if we do not reach our goal, but have at least enough to rights, we will still be doing CLUE, but with a lower budget.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's fine, there are plenty of other ways to help out:

  • Get the word out, share this campaign with all your friends.
  • If you'd like to volunteer your personal services, we do need people to help build sets, help with costumes, and even usher the performances

If you have another ideas to help out or have any question or concerns, we encourage you to contact us at thecageplayers.tumblr.com/ask

story:
“The Journey” follows the progression of dance history from the traditionally theatre-based art form as it develops and expands out into the world. Comprised of four distinct movements, this film follows a dancer’s experience in each of the pieces as she adapts to the new styles. Several phrases of movement echo throughout the project, as the pieces of choreography dynamically alter and grow depending on the style being performed. 

First movement (2:31) – Classical ballet performed in a traditional theatre setting, with lights, costumes, and music reflecting the recent history of the art.

Second movement (2:10) – A study in modern dance, based in Duncan, Limon, and Graham techniques. Filming will take place in the gardens of a local park, representing the return of dance to the earth from the theatre. 

 Third movement (1:19) – Gesture-based choreography, utilizing American Sign Language as the basis for creating its motions. This movement will be filmed at the water to incorporate different elements into the environments. 

 Fourth movement (2:59) – Contemporary dance, filmed in a busy, common location. Unexpected pops of dancing will erupt from the pedestrians, after which they return to normality (walking, on their phones, tying shoelaces, etc.) This piece is the culmination of the project, showing the pervasiveness of dance and movement in everyday life, even if it is not choreographed. Anyone can dance. I repeat: ANYONE can dance. This piece shows the dancers of life. 

At the end of the project, we will email out a private video link with a limited time access. This will allow all of you lovely contributors to see all of the things that we were able to do through your generosity. I want to share this project with the people who made it possible!! Thanks for believing in me!

 Budget summary: 

Crew – $1500 (Cameramen, photographers, lighting techs, logistical assistants) 

Equipment – $2300 (Cameras, rentals, editing software, lights) 

Logistics - $1200 (stylists, costumes, sets, etc.)

Risks and challenges? Yes. There will be lots. I'm in school, so timing, coordination, and logistics all present potential problems. But, I have an amazing team to work with, from my co-producer Anthony, to the costume designer Summer, and all of the other crew that want to make this a success. We will make this project happen, and we are so excited to get started! I have three other choreographers working with me for the finale, so the craziest part has the most people covering it. We have all of our team, now we need to get the rest of the equipment and finalize the production schedule. We have to maneuver the theatre schedule, the local weather (for the outdoor shots), and get adequate permissions for our final location. Honestly, I don't know what to expect. I have never done anything like this before. But, I have to start somewhere, and what better support group than other people who love the arts? No one starts out knowing it all, so I am looking forward to learning and adapting as this project comes together.

About me: 

I'm Hannah! I was born in Pendleton, Oregon, and raised in Walla Walla, Washington, and am currently studying Mechanical Engineering and Dance in Spokane, Washington. 

Dance experience: 

Prior to university - nineteen years of training, starting with classical ballet at age 3 (Ballet, modern, jazz, pointe, urban, tap, social dance, hip hop, etc)

I have studied under - Idalee Hutson-Fish*, John Passafiume*, Lydia Tetzlaff, Lisa Bostwick*, Melvin Clark III, Allison Keppel*, Nancy Wells*, Justine Clark, Jennifer Clark*, Phillip Krauter, Paul Koverman, J.C. Aimee-Cordiero, Ricci Adan*, Tinka Dailey*, Toni Pimble*

      (*performed with)

Competed in Dance Grand Prix Italia 2008 (team took 1st for ballet, 2nd for modern, 3rd for costumes)

In university - Pamela Erickson*, Carla Parbon, Suzanne Ostersmith*, Stephanie Lindsay*, Patricia McArdle*

While studying abroad in Florence for four months, I enrolled in a local ballet class taught by a wonderful Argentinian teacher.

I have taken dance classes all four years of my college experience, coached the Bulldog Dancers at St. Al's for two years, taught Zagdance, and participated in Boundless Club classes and Student choreography, as dancer, student, teacher, and choreographer. 

My technical background in Audio-Visual work, theatre tech, and music editing will help me accomplish this project, as well as nineteen years of dance training. I have held a technical position for two years at school, working with various environments and requirements involving music, video, dance, and productions.

story:
uno spettacolo di Gianmarco Pozzoli, Simona Angioni

diretto da Gianmarco Pozzoli

con Gianmarco Pozzoli e Roberta Mengozzi

supervisione artistica Walter Leonardi

musiche e sound design Gianluigi Carlone

disegno luci Monica Gorla

coro Barbara Bedrina, Fedra Biffis, Elisa Bottiglieri, Niccolò Collivignarelli, Lorenzo Covello, Carlo Decio, Valeria de Michele, Ivana Hostakova, Ivan Senine, Libero Stelluti, Lucilla Tempesti

una coproduzione

Luca del Fuego Confortini e Teatro Primo Studio – Film Beyond

Vogliamo far volare queste farfalle al 
Fringe Festival di Edimburgo 2014?

Allora ci serve il vostro aiuto. 

Dovete aiutarci perché bisogna affrontare dei grossi investimenti e alcune di queste spese vanno anticipate entro novembre 2013.

Dobbiamo affittare un teatro, stampare più di 5000 volantini, affittare 2 appartamenti perché siamo 12 attori più un tecnico.

Prenotare 13 voli andata e ritorno.
Poi, una volta là, queste 13 persone dovranno anche mangiare (poco) per un mese, insomma, i soldi che ci servono sono molti. Circa 10mila Euro.

Ci stiamo buttando in un'avventura piena di incognite, ma così meravigliosa che non vediamo l'ora di rischiare.

Vi chiediamo un aiuto per portare uno spettacolo italiano al Festival di Teatro più importante al mondo.

Dateci una mano, anzi un aiuto, il VOSTRO aiuto, bello, prezioso, essenziale.


Perché dovresti aiutarci?

Perché ce l’abbiamo messa tutta.
Perché' in Italia ha poca probabilità di sopravvivere per il grande numero di attori in scena.
Perché il nostro è un lavoro generoso, delicato ma anche potente e merita di essere visto.
Perché i soldi, in questo caso, fanno la felicità.
Perché abbiamo sempre pagato le tasse.
Perché il Fringe è un’occasione unica.
Perché portiamo fortuna come i cornetti napoletani.
Perché nessuno di noi si droga.
Perché ci devono scegliere fra 2600 spettacoli.
Perché se non ci aiuti qualcuno di noi inizierà a drogarsi
Perché Edimburgo è cara.
Perché ci mettiamo in punta di piedi per farti ballare.
Perché abbiamo le scarpe strette ma ti sorridiamo lo stesso.
Perché così farete parte di un’opera d’arte.
Perché se non sfondiamo andiamo a fare gli ausiliari della sosta (e tutti voi avete una macchina).
Perché non si vive di soli telegiornali.
Perché siamo innamorati di ogni singolo momento di questo spettacolo.
Perché accarezziamo ogni cane che incontriamo. I gatti invece anche.
Perché nessuno di noi, nonostante i soldi che ci donate, probabilmente, guadagnerà nulla durante il Fringe Festival, tranne una meravigliosa esperienza che ci farà crescere come artisti e come esseri umani.
Perché se vedrai lo spettacolo, lo sentirai il perché.


Vi ringraziamo anticipatamente per essere qui a condividere un sogno.

PINK PUNCH THEATRE

story:
Who We Are

We provide an affordable, accessible, and intergenerational community theatre experience for the township of Montgomery, NJ and its surrounding areas. Founded in 2000, Sourland Hills Actors Guild was created by a group of grassroots volunteers who wanted to provide, both young and old, an opportunity to experience the performing arts. In our thirteen year history, Sourland Hills has produced twenty-five large-scale shows, and has grown from 40 actors and volunteers in our first production to 173 in our most recent show.

This campaign is to raise funds so that we can continue to bring live theatre to the Montgomery Community. In the last 3 years, the rental fees for the performance space have increased 325%.  Achieving our goal of $8,000 will supplement our existing funds enough to cover the higher rental fees allow us to continue our mission to produce a full-length musical in the Spring of 2014.

Eighty Actors on Stage! Footloose, 2011

What We Need & What You Get

We need $8,000 to rent the Montgomery Performing Arts Center for one week. This gives us the space we need to create our fantastic sets and theatrical magic, and allows us to have a large cast participating!

The magical flying car in the US Amateur Priemier of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, 2010

As a supporter of our project, you will get some awesome perks and get sneek peeks at our show as it comes to life! For a complete list of giving options see all the categories listed at the right. A sampling of donor levels includes:

  • All donations of $35 or more receive official membership in the Sourland Hills Actors Guild, which entitles you to all official communications, and scheduled audition appointments
  • For a donation of $50, you get a personal thank you card, a cast photo, a digital poster, and an exclusive video of a rehearsal!
  • Donations of $100 or more get the above plus 2 FREE TICKETS to the show!
  • Donate $500 and get  4 FREE TICKETS to the show, a T-Shirt, 2 concession photos, and a MEET & GREET photo with a cast member!
  • Get EXCLUSIVE ACCESS: a donation of $2000 or more gets you a private backstage tour and a photo with a cast member, a post production discussion with members of the creative team, AND all of the above.
We are a registered 501(c)3. All donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

The Impact

Sourland Hills Actors Guild is one of the only community theatre companies that is intentionally intergenerational. We have cast and crew members from ages 8-75, and there are no participation or costume fees allowing a cross section of the surrounding communities to participate.

We have produced 25 productions in 13 years, and have consistently had over 3,000 audience members attend over 3 performances. We have seen youth grow in confidence as they work side-by-side with adults. New friendships emerge, talent showcased, and the performing arts are available to the entire community at an affordable price. With your help, we can continue performing locally.

Jellyfish Dancers, Seussical 2012

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Tell your friends and family: share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Email, Everywhere!
  • Volunteer with us: we have opportunities in production support, set building, concessions, and more!
story_txt:
Who We Are

We provide an affordable, accessible, and intergenerational community theatre experience for the township of Montgomery, NJ and its surrounding areas. Founded in 2000, Sourland Hills Actors Guild was created by a group of grassroots volunteers who wanted to provide, both young and old, an opportunity to experience the performing arts. In our thirteen year history, Sourland Hills has produced twenty-five large-scale shows, and has grown from 40 actors and volunteers in our first production to 173 in our most recent show.
This campaign is to raise funds so that we can continue to bring live theatre to the Montgomery Community. In the last 3 years, the rental fees for the performance space have increased 325%.  Achieving our goal of $8,000 will supplement our existing funds enough to cover the higher rental fees allow us to continue our mission to produce a full-length musical in the Spring of 2014.

Eighty Actors on Stage! Footloose, 2011
What We Need & What You Get
We need $8,000 to rent the Montgomery Performing Arts Center for one week. This gives us the space we need to create our fantastic sets and theatrical magic, and allows us to have a large cast participating!

The magical flying car in the US Amateur Priemier of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, 2010
As a supporter of our project, you will get some awesome perks and get sneek peeks at our show as it comes to life! For a complete list of giving options see all the categories listed at the right. A sampling of donor levels includes:

All donations of $35 or more receive official membership in the Sourland Hills Actors Guild, which entitles you to all official communications, and scheduled audition appointments

Get EXCLUSIVE ACCESS: a donation of $2000 or more gets you a private backstage tour and a photo with a cast member, a post production discussion with members of the creative team, AND all of the above.

story:
"Tomorrow everything changes."

What would you do if you knew that your life would change tomorrow, but you had no idea if it was for the better or the worse?  The List is a story about two best friends on the verge of change.  Mike and Jo have known each other almost their whole lives, but now they're worried that their friendship will transform into something different.  The List takes a non-linear journey through the lives of these two very quirky people from the moment they meet at seven years old, well into their golden years.  It is a story about the importance of friendship and how a single person can impact your entire life.  The audience is kept guessing as to what exactly is happening tomorrow, and as they see glimpses into the future of these friends, they continue to guess just how this story will end.

The List began as a ten-minute play I wrote during an independent study course on playwriting in college.  When I wrote it, I knew that the story wasn't finished.  I knew that these two characters, Mike and Jo, had so much more to say.  After many attempts at trying to figure out the best way to approach it, I looked at a central part of the ten-minute play: Mike gives Jo a gift of a bucket list they'd made years earlier of all the things they want to do in their lives.  When I realized that the story should be told through these events, I had the play.  The list that these two create shows their innate humor and just how well they know each other.  They planned their lives together in the hope that they will always be there for one another.

I decided to tell their story non-linearly to give a broader view of their friendship.  Plus, it's a much larger challenge for the actors playing Mike and Jo to have to switch from 30 years old to 7 to 77.  In terms of the actors, I added two others as narrators of sorts, who jump in and out of Mike and Jo's lives as all the various characters they meet, from Jo's mother to Mike's childhood friend and beyond.It evolved into a full length play that has touched everyone who's read it.

At its heart, The List is a story about people, people who live, love, and have to make their way through the ups and downs that life brings.  It just so happens that these two particular people are a bit quirky and zany in their own ways.

"I'm expecting a gold plated, jewel encrusted, life size ostrich."

As you can see, we are offering an array of rewards for our backers.  We're hoping that we can entice some people to help us out.  We would love to give more mementos from the show, but as it is very minimalistic, there are not many items in the way of props and set pieces.  Still, we are happy to do what we can.

Got a venue and want us to tell this story for you?  Take special note to the side; we can travel to you and perform this show for your group, community, or, if you're a rich eccentric type, just you.

"Where has the time gone?  It seems like only yesterday you were playing in the mud."

Rehearsals for this show have been underway for a while now.  We have our Man and Woman, along with our various tech roles.  The show opens in just a few weeks, but we do need some help supporting this process.  We will be doing the show regardless of our funding, but it would certainly help improve it if the financial strain was lightened some.

We will open at the new Talking Horse Theatre located at 210 St. James Street in Columbia, Missouri.  Our production will run for 5 performances.  Opening night will have a special talkback session with the cast, crew, playwright, and director.  Our show dates are 09/27-09/28, 10/04-10/05 at 7:30 and 10/06 at 2:00

"Thanks for stopping by!  I feel much butter!"

Help make this world premiere a possibility!  We can't do this without you!  Remember, no money exchanges hands unless we meet our goal.  What have you got to lose?  Help a group of people who believe in this story have the chance to tell it and earn our eternal gratitude.

In the mean time be sure to like us on our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/OriginalOddityProductions.

or visit our event at:

https://www.facebook.com/#!/events/514074498672450/

"If I were a princess, some big catastrophe would happen right about now."

Anything involved in the arts is a risk.  Will people like it?  Can it succeed?  It's true that theatre is a risky business and people need to know their audiences.  I can say with certainty that everyone who has read The List has been moved by it.  I have been working on this script with the hope of getting it produced for almost two years and now it's almost come to fruition.  Columbia, Missouri, is small town known for it's support of the arts.  It has a lot for people to go and do or see, so we need to make it enticing for them to want to see this show.

We may be a new theatre company getting off the ground, but our members have long years of experience behind them.  I've been in theatre for the last twelve years and have numerous other plays under my belt.  Our director and co-founder of Original Oddity Productions has more years than she'd prefer to admit living and breathing the theatre life. 

Getting this together from start to finish has been a challenge in and of itself, but now the only thing keeping us from moving forward is money.  We have a great director, an accommodating venue with Talking Horse Productions, a minimal set to build, and a great story to tell.  Help us get this out there.

story:
"Rite" is the first evening length contemporary dance concert that is solely comprised of Maryland based choreographer and performing artist; Desiree Koontz-Nachtrieb's work. "Rite" is the performance component of her MFA, Performing Arts and Choreography at The George Washington University. The majority of "Rite" will be performed by the following artists: Erin Gum, Meagan Singleton, Maria Vitery, Marcie Day, Brandon Rapp, and Desiree Koontz-Nachtrieb. Koontz-Nachtrieb is excited to announce that she will be setting a piece on "Howard County Ballet" student company members. Get ready for two evenings of exploring the most intimate details of the human condition via the medium of dance in Ellicott City and Baltimore, Maryland.

This project comes from asking the following questions: How do higher reasoning beings, specifically in the west, remember and process the most intimate details of the human condition? What is the connection between ritual and memory? How is a ritual developed and executed?

"Rite" seeks to use various light sources as representative of the human memory and the ways in which individual and collective memory functions in conjunction with video projection and contemporary choreography to explore what is remembered as well as what is forgotten over time.

The movement in "Rite" is the physical manifestation and creative ritual of specific memories of both myself and those of my dancers. Through writings generated about the human condition as it pertained personally, as well as, readings on the topics of the human condition, memory, and the creation of ritual, I built a "phonetic movement vocabulary" that embodies the rhythm and shape of the topic previously mentioned. The project is intended to be a gift to the audience: intangible yet beautifully necessary. This campaign allows the work to happen.

"Rite's" evening length performance is comprised of three vignettes. Each of the vignettes represent moments in my and and my dancers past and present and seek to present via movement; the most intimate details of the human condition ; the ebb and flow of tragedy and humor and all that lies in  between. This project is driven by personal memories, daily life, rituals, and the ever evolving discovery of self-identity

Funding a professional show is extremely costly: costumes, light design, and advertising, promotional video, space rental, etc. We are asking $1,000 to cover the bare essentials to enable the work to happen.

We are grateful for any contribution you are willing to give. If you are unable to send money or attend the show, send your good intentions our way! We would love it if you would share our info on your Facebook! Art is necessary, and we would love for you to be a part of "Rite."

"Rite" performs: October 19 at 8:00 p.m. at the University of Maryland at Baltimore County FA 317 located, 1000 Hilltop Circle • Baltimore, MD 21250.

October 26 at 8:00 p.m. at the Howard County Center for the Arts: Black Box Theater located, 8510 High Ridge Road Ellicott City, Maryland 21043.

story:
"Changing the Lives of People One Step at a Time"

About "The NJ Dance Network"

"The NJ Dance Network" is a facility that will be located in the heart of downtown Newark, New Jersey. As an advocate of youth empowerment, a proud recipient of a "Key To The City" and a mother, I embarked on this endeavor along with other distinguished community leaders to help deter children from getting into trouble with their idle time. With the staggering number of cases of youth-targeted violence, I felt behooved to rise to the occasion. Once renovated, this community center will function as a meeting ground for talented children of Newark as well as surrounding cities. It is my belief that an establishment such as this one will appeal to the common thread most of our youth have here and that is their love for dancing. The focus will be on dance in all of its variations, representing an opportunity for more inner-city kids to avoid urban pitfalls and receive formal training at no cost to our residents. Our goal is to develop full-scale dance recitals and theatrical productions.

About “Hood House: So Jersey” 

Our first musical production will be a dance DVD in conjunction with a 3-4 song EP entitled Hood House: So Jersey tentatively scheduled for December 2013. The NJ Dance Network will be releasing a series of videos for the EP that will cast its participants. It is our hope that employing people directly from the community would be a great way to boost morale and offer them a chance to experience pop culture in a positive environment while utilizing his or her natural born talents.

 About “Breaking in the Brix” 

Breakin’ In the Brix is the current working title for the first stage production for the NJ Dance Network. It is a musical remake of the 1984 classic movie “Breakin” to be performed at any one of Newark’s arts and entertainment venues such as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center or Newark Symphony Hall’s Terrace Ballroom. We are prepping to have it ready by Spring 2014. We will launch another fundraiser for this project sometime around January. I'm currently working on obtaining 501(c)(3) status so that all contributions are tax deductible. Until such time, I've been spending my own personal funds to make such a dream of mine come to fruition! 

Where does the money go?  

Funds from this campaign will be used towards building renovations, producing the videos for the EP and making the preliminary preparations for our first stage production. There are hefty production costs as well as salaries for (but not specific to):  

• Scriptwriters • Choreographers • Videographers • Production hands • Producers • DJs • Set designers • Dancers • Recording Artists • Music supervisors • Instrument players • Costume designers • Vocal coaches • Youth advocates • Hair/Makeup artists • Team leaders  • Life coaches


Every project has its risks. In our inner city communities, we are constantly losing young adults to street violence and domestic violence with minimal resources to help them. I have a personal stake in this so I'm willing to contribute any personal funds necessary to see this through ensuring all contributors' rewards are delivered in a timely manner.
Underneath all the grit and crime that you hear so much about on the news is a world of endlessly talented future leaders. We want to show kids that they can come from humble beginnings and create greatness for themselves and those around them.
That's what you call an artist giving back!



For more about NJ Dance Network:

www.NJDanceNetwork.org

Follow us on Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr: @NJDanceNetwork 

Contact: njdancenetwork@gmail.com 

Every contribution counts so please help spread the word!!

story:
About Us

Shadow Horse Theatre Productions was started in 2004 in Los Angeles by Matt Saxe and Craig Bender.  It's current Executive Directors are Matt Kelly and Matt Saxe.  

Its goals are to produce new plays by new playwrights, as well as modern or new versions of classic tales for contemporary audiences.

Our most popular productions include the popular "A Drinking Game" series since February 2012, with titles including Princess Bride, Back to the Future, Ghostbusters, Beetlejuice, When Harry Met Sally, The Big Lewbowski, and many others.  In addition, we were one of 9 cities in the United States to celebrate World Commedia Day on February 25th, 2012.  We also produced two shows for the Minnesota Fringe.  Sex, Soap, Torture, Weather - a set of four one-act plays in 2010 and the 4 and 5 star reviewed Grimm for Kids! in 2013, adapted from George Larkin's LA Weekly award winning show.   

Our future productions include monthly Drinking Game shows through December 2014, A Kind of Love Story, a 2012 LA Weekly Award winning play by Jenelle Riley and directed by Bethany Simmons making it's Minnesota premiere in February 2014 at the Old Arizona Theater; World Commedia Day on February 25th, and Clive Barker's Crazyface in Summer 2014.

Currently, our past productions have been personally funded by the executive producers.  As we venture into bringing unique productions to a larger audience, our costs have increased significantly.  The purpose of this campaign is to fund our inaugural 2014 season and you can be a part of making that happen.  

Our costs include production items such as theater rentals, props, set construction, lighting, and costumes.  Costs also include providing small compensation to the actors, the directors, lighting designers, set designers, stage managers, and other production staff.  Our company members often work in various roles throughout the productions and do not receive compensation for the production until it turns a profit on its original budget.  

Impact

Shadow Horse Theater's commitment to bringing unique productions mean that the Minneapolis/St Paul theater community will get to experience new plays and productions not seen by other theater companies in the area and sometimes, for the first time in the world.  


Perks and Reward Tiers

Our perks and rewards include novelty Shadow Horse logo items, complimentary tickets to future Drinking Game shows, a pair of tickets to A Kind of Love Story, a season pass to The Drinking Game (February 2014 - December 2014), and the highest tier includes an onstage supporting role at a future Drinking Game show.  

For Free tickets, ticket holder will need to contact Shadowhorsetheater@yahoo.com to reserve tickets 24 hours before show time.  Tickets will be held at the Will Call office. Unused tickets will not be refunded and hold no cash value until redeemed


How You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please share this campaign with your friends, colleagues, or any companies.  

You can also come out to our shows and you can stay up to date by visiting our various webpages:

Feel free to check out our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/adrinkinggamemn 

Our official website updated monthly at: http://www.shadowhorsetheatre.com

You can view clips from previous Drinking Game Shows at: http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaKhAnve3lPdDQR7NxYjdnXU44lE8O3BN

in 2013, adapted from George Larkin's LA Weekly award winning show.   Our future productions include monthly Drinking Game shows through December 2014, A Kind of Love Story, a 2012 LA Weekly Award winning play by Jenelle Riley and directed by Bethany Simmons making it's Minnesota premiere in February 2014 at the Old Arizona Theater; World Commedia Day on February 25th, and Clive Barker's Crazyface in Summer 2014.Currently, our past productions have been personally funded by the executive producers.  As we venture into bringing unique productions to a larger audience, our costs have increased significantly.  The purpose of this campaign is to fund our inaugural 2014 season and you can be a part of making that happen.  Our costs include production items such as theater rentals, props, set construction, lighting, and costumes.  Costs also include providing small compensation to the actors, the directors, lighting designers, set designers, stage managers, and other production staff.  Our company members often work in various roles throughout the productions and do not receive compensation for the production until it turns a profit on its original budget.  ImpactShadow Horse Theater's commitment to bringing unique productions mean that the Minneapolis/St Paul theater community will get to experience new plays and productions not seen by other theater companies in the area and sometimes, for the first time in the world.  Perks and Reward TiersOur perks and rewards include novelty Shadow Horse logo items, complimentary tickets to future Drinking Game shows, a pair of tickets to A Kind of Love Story, a season pass to The Drinking Game (February 2014 - December 2014), and the highest tier includes an onstage supporting role at a future Drinking Game show.  For Free tickets, ticket holder will need to contact Shadowhorsetheater@yahoo.com to reserve tickets 24 hours before show time.  Tickets will be held at the Will Call office. Unused tickets will not be refunded and hold no cash value until redeemedHow You Can HelpIf you can't contribute, please share this campaign with your friends, colleagues, or any companies.  You can also come out to our shows and you can stay up to date by visiting our various webpages:Feel free to check out our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/adrinkinggamemn Our official website updated monthly at: http://www.shadowhorsetheatre.comYou can view clips from previous Drinking Game Shows at: http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaKhAnve3lPdDQR7NxYjdnXU44lE8O3BN

story:
The National Ballet Company and Institute for the Arts

Celebrating 65 years of providing outstanding performances to the public and education in the art of ballet

Founded by Helen Moore in 1948, the National Ballet has been training dancers for 65 years.  Dancers trained at National Ballet can be found around the world teaching and performing.  The company, Maryland’s oldest professional ballet company, provides exceptional performances to the public and schools.

The mission of the National Ballet Institute for the Arts is dedicated to the professional training of students, teachers, and professionals in ballet.  A welcome atmosphere for all ages is provided to enjoy the study of ballet, art, and music. Under the direction of Pamela Moore, Co-Chairman of the Board of Examiners for the Cecchetti Council of America, Diploma Fellow with the CCA and Cecchetti USA, the institute offers a thorough education in all aspects of ballet technique. 

Support the Arts

The National Ballet Company and Institute for the Arts moved to a beautiful space in Annapolis in January 2013.  The new location, equipped with two ballet studios, offices, study rooms, costume storage, and art gallery, is ideal for the institute's dedication to dance and arts.  With its new home, the company seeks to enrich the Annapolis community and continue to provide outstanding performances and arts eduction to Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia.

Your Contribution is Needed

National Ballet Institute for the Arts is a Maryland non profit corporation seeking to provide services to the community. 

In addition to superb ballet performances for the general public, the company works with schools to provide valuable arts education to children through performances and lecture-demonstrations.   Senior citizens benefit from performances brought to senior communities to provide accessible quality entertainment.  Adult classes are offered to encourage mobility and health at any age.

Your contribution will ensure the existence of affordable arts education, performances, and outreach programs in the arts for children, adults, senior citizens, and special needs groups throughout Maryland, Virginia and District of Columbia.

NBIA is offering perks to thank you for your valuable donations.  Every dollar is appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

Be sure to check the website for more information or to register for Summer and Fall classes.  Two Summer camps are also available: "Let's Paint, Dance, and Make Music," a fun-filled day camp for ages 5-12, and the "Maestro Enrico Cecchetti Intensive" for ballet students who are studying the Cecchetti Method or are interested in exploring the method.
 
Share the National Ballet's fundraiser with your friends, family, and community!

story:
What is Rhapsody Collective?

About a year ago, I had a dream of bringing a group of young artists together to create new works from the very beginning and devise plays under one common theme.  Well, 36 artists were brought together and we presented six plays with the theme of Dreams. After a successful run of sold-out, one-night only presentations, a new ensemble of artists, containing both old and new members, came together and we’re eager to share seven new plays with you. This Cycle’s theme: The Seven Deadly Sins.

Rhapsody Collective is a group of young theater artists dedicated to creating new works from the ground up. Rhapsody Collective strives to foster new and innovative ideas in a safe environment of peers. The goal is to create, not produce. Over the course of a cycle, the ensemble of actors, directors, playwrights, and dramaturgs are randomly broken up into teams to create a brand new piece. The challenge for each team is “freedom within restrictions.” Each cycle has a theme each piece must incorporate. Additionally, the roles created must be written specifically for the actors on their team. At the end of the cycle, each play will be presented in one harmonious rhapsody.

Since October, we have met as an ensemble to learn about who we are as individual theater artists. We have now been divided into our 7 Seven Deadly Sin Teams and have been steadily devising our seven diverse plays. We can’t wait to show just how sinful we are in Cycle 2!

Why We Need Your Help:

In order to bring our seven pieces to life, we need your help. This May, we will present our seven teams’ plays in workshop style. Our goal is to charge a suggested donation as admission so you can see all seven presentations and not feel you have to pick and choose. And that’s why you’re here! The more we raise, the bigger the space, the more people we can share our work with!

We need to raise funds to:

·  Rent rehearsal spaces for all of the seven teams

·  Rent a week-long residency space at the new home of Alchemical Theatre Laboratory

·  Print programs

·  Order and print postcards and posters

If we exceed our goal (which would be awesome!), those funds will go to future Rhapsody Collective projects and the start of Cycle 3 in the Fall of 2014! Just look at all the perks you could collect just by donating to Rhapsody Collective!

Rhapsody Collective Cycle 2 Teams:

Team Envy: Olivia Rose Berrasi (Actor), Stephanie Jean Davis (Actor), Melody Goodell (Actor), Brian Knoebel (Director), Rebecca Knowles (Actor), Andrew Massey (Playwright), Julia Warner (Actor)

Team Gluttony: Justin Blake Broido (Actor), Matt Ketai (Actor), Mat Leonard (Actor), Preston Maguire (Actor), Benjamin Martin (Playwright), Alex Morgan (Actor), Catherine Weingarten (Director)

Team Greed: Whitney Conkling (Actor), Nikki DiLoreto (Director), Julie Ann Earls (Actor), Amanda Lea Mason Sophie Moshofsky (Actor), Ryan Pater (Actor), Nathan Shapiro (Actor), Luke Wise (Playwright)

Team Lust: Michael Block (Director), Cameron Burns (Actor), Alicia Evancho (Actor), Dean Preston (Playwright), Jeffery Roth (Actor), Catherine Woodard (Actor)

Team Sloth: Andi Alhadeff (Actor), Tony Curtis (Director), Matthew Hansen (Playwright), Marion LeCoguic (Actor), Sarah Lusche (Actor), Cameron Mason (Actor)

Team Vanity: Christo Grabowski (Actor), Eric Marlin (Playwright), Elliot Miranda (Actor), Michael Orlandi (Actor), Sasha Rivera (Director), Julia Yarwood (Actor)

Team Wrath: Christina Cervenka (Actor), Gillian Durkee (Playwright), Anna Fearheiley (Actor), Emily Jackson (Director), David Mangiamele (Actor), Molly O’Keefe (Actor), Forrest Weber (Actor)

Dramaturgs: Olivia Rose Berrasi, Gail Shalan

Production Manager: Tom Kordenbrock

For more on Rhapsody Collective, please like us at Facebook.com/rhapsodycollective and check out our Dramaturgy page at http://rhapsody2sevendeadly.wordpress.com/

From all of us at Rhapsody Collective, we thank you for all your support and donations!

story:
Aurora Borealis Dance Company, being in only its second year, needs your help to put on our 2014 full length production.  ABDC prides itself on their commitment to give back to the community having danced for noble causes such as Andrew's Helpful Hands, The Muscular Dystrophy Association, and now Big Brother Big Sister. We have the passion, the talent, and the dedication; the only thing we lack is the money to allow our dancers to perform in a beautiful theater that will complement and enhance our performance.  So now we are asking our community to help us; we are asking you: our friends, family, and fans to help make this project a truly inspiring and successful experience for all involved by contributing to our campaign.  

We thank you sincerely for taking the time to donate to our production and cannot wait to see you at "Inspired By True Events" on March 15th, 7:00 at The Rose Performance Hall at Endicott College.

story:
Help create and sustain "Life"!

Damsels in De-Stress Productions invites you to experience Life x 3 by Yasmina Reza at Unit 102 Theatre.

Henry and Sonia are (unsuccessfully) putting their 6-year-old son to bed when Henry’s bombastic colleague Hubert and his wife Inez show up to dinner – a day earlier than expected.  Ever resourceful, Henry and Sonia serve up a confection of cheezits, chocolate fingers, and pistachios washed down with copious amounts of Sancerre – but the evening quickly disintegrates.   Over the course of the play, the audience is treated to three versions of this comically disastrous evening.  You’ll laugh, you’ll cringe, and you’ll have to stop at the corner store to pick up a bag of cheezits on the way home.

Directed by Andrew Lamb (My Mother’s Lesbian Jewish Wiccan Wedding), the cast features Tara Baxendale, Rob McKee, Sean Tabares and Esther Thibault.  Life x 3 is an Equity Artist Collective production.

What We Need & What You Get

Of course what we really hope happens is that you get yourself over to Unit 102 Theatre, 376 Dufferin Street, between May 2 - May 11 and see our show.  Tickets are only $25 - and $20 if you're a student, a senior or an artsworker!

But maybe you live out of town - or you have a little extra cash burning a hole in your pocket - and you'd like to help us out by making an advance contribution to our production budget.  And in exchange, you get our undying gratitude, the satisfaction of knowing you're an arts patron, and a fun perk or two.

The Impact

Even though this is an Equity Artist Collective (which means our actors and our artistic team are deferring their salaries in exchange for a share of the profits), it still costs a lot of money to put on a play.  We have to pay for the rights, rent performance space, rent rehearsal space, pay for publicity - the list goes on and on.  Esther and I hope that Damsels in De-Stress Productions will be around to bring you fun, affordable, contemporary theatre for many years to come - but this is our first production and we need YOUR help!

Our biggest cost is renting space for rehearsal and performance.  $2000 would cover a significant portion of those costs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to our campaign right now, you can still help us make Life x 3 a success: use the Indiegogo share tools to help us get the word out about this campaign - and about our show!

Thanks!

Esther and Tara

story:
About GASP

GASP (Girls Assembling Something Perpetual) was founded by six female poets in Denver, Colorado in 2011. Combining elements of the sparse and often absent stage direction with dance, improvisation, and interpretation, GASP creates a poets’ theater of part abstraction, part sublimity, part accident, and part gesture. GASP seeks to find ways within theater, within a “play,” to parallel, not translate, radical elicitations of text, body, and atmosphere. To speak as both mouth and limb simultaneously.

For their next project, GASP will perform Alice Notley’s The Descent of Alette. Previously, GASP performed Leslie Scalapino’s Sweet: A Play using her minimal stage direction to examine aspects of the politicized body, war, and groupthink. Their performance of  four short plays from Gertrude Stein’s Geography and Plays explored language, love, feminism, gender roles, and play through essential and explosive performances.

GASP performers for The Descent of Alette include Alexis Almeida, Sommer Browning, Serena Chopra, Yanara Friedland, HR Hegnauer, and Andrea Rexilius.  


Funding

GASP is seeking funding of $2500. This will help cover the costs of our 2015 performances, which will take place in Los Angeles, Denver, Boulder, and Colorado Springs. All of our performances are free and open to the public, and your contribution helps us keep it like this!

For the first time, GASP is taking their performances on the road! While we are based in Denver, and have had performances along the Front Range in previous years, 2015 marks the first year where GASP is truly branching out. We've been accepted to perform Alice Notley's The Descent of Alette at CalArts at part of the &Now literary festival. Your contribution helps get the 6 of us from Colorado to California, and we are so appreciative for your generosity!


2015 Performances

Please join us at any of our 2015 winter performances:


Thursday, February 19, 2015, 7:30 PM

Savoy @ Curtis Park: 2700 Arapahoe St. Denver, CO

Friday, February 20, 2015, 6 PM
Naropa University, Student Union: 2130 Arapahoe Ave. Boulder, CO

March 25-28, 2015, Details TBA
&Now Conference, CalArts, 24700 McBean Parkway, Valencia, CA, 91355

Saturday, April 18, 2015, 7 PM 
Mountain Fold Books: 121 E Costilla St. Colorado Springs, CO 


Website

Please visit our website, http://www.gasptheater.org/, learn more and see photographs from previous events.


Thank you for your support!

story:
Hi! I’m Angelo Divino. I've always admired Frank’s brilliant style, and last year, it occurred to me to write a show in his honor. After the successful Hollywood opening of “Lucky So and So,” my homage to the great Duke Ellington, something told me to follow up with another show. I started reading about Frank and was floored by his dynamic life, right from the moment of his perilous birth! The more I read, the more I saw how well certain songs he sang narrated his lofty highs and devastating lows. He always spoke his mind, inspiring the show’s title, "Let Me Be Frank!" Though he made singing seem easy, Frank worked tirelessly to hone his craft, aware very early on that he was headed for greatness. 

After nearly a year of writing, the show is ready for rehearsals. That’s where you come in, to assist me in getting the show on its feet! This show warrants great musicians and they charge for their services. We’ll begin with piano rehearsals and commission unique, precise charts for all arrangements in the appropriate keys.

Soon, we’ll start booking club dates, printing promotional materials and listing the show on prominent web sites. There will be meetings with an Arts attorney to make sure that everyone who created this great music is honored. To me, the music Frank sang is some of the best music ever written. My mission is to disseminate this music to the emerging generations, along with the history of how it was created and by whom. The show will begin in small local clubs and expand into live theater venues nationwide, including Las Vegas and New York, then onto the International scene! The show is written so other musical actors can take on the role, increasing its scope indefinitely.

Your enthusiasm for this project inspires me and the perks will make this process more fun for both of us. Perks include show tickets for local supporters and signed posters, post cards and customized musical greetings to those who live outside the Los Angeles area. Angelo is an established visual artist and an art image will be created, highlighting the show's theme. Prints of this artwork will be available in large 11" x 14" and small 8.5" x 11" sizes. All Prints, poster and Post Cards will be signed by Angelo. All perks will be available on 12/12/12, Frank's birthday! You may support at any dollar amount you choose and all who pitch in will be thanked for their support. For those who cannot contribute, you can help by spreading the word and getting friends and family to pitch in. Using the Indiegogo share tools makes it easy! To view more musical video clips, search for Angelo Divino on Youtube.

** Show tickets will cover admission only and will not include venue minimums and gratuities.

All Prints, poster and Post Cards will be signed by Angelo. All perks will be available on 12/12/12, Frank's birthday! You may support at any dollar amount you choose and all who pitch in will be thanked for their support. For those who cannot contribute, you can help by spreading the word and getting friends and family to pitch in. Using the Indiegogo share tools makes it easy! To view more musical video clips, search for Angelo Divino on Youtube.
** Show tickets will cover admission only and will not include venue minimums and gratuities.

story:
Etobicoke School of the Arts is Canada's most reputable free standing Arts school, with approximately 1000 students majoring in Music Theatre, Drama, Dance, Music, Visual Art, Dance and Film.  One of the most high profile ensembles from the school, is Canada's two-time National Show Choir Champions SPLASH!

Splash desperately requires funds, which do not come from the Toronto District School Board, to help offset the cost of costumes & maintenance, designer fees, guest choreographers, performance rights, competition and travel fees, etc.  This amazing group of students has been rehearsing with no show choir risers, and we are ready for a change.  We could be even BETTER than we are now, if we could rehearse in a studio with the appropriate show choir risers.  However, they are extremely EXPENSIVE!

Your contribution to this campaign will go a long way in helping all of our vocal ensembles rehearse more effectively.  The risers we would need are very durable and portable and will allow the students to accomplish so much more than they already do at ESA and in the competition world.

If you cannot contribute to the campaign, perhaps you could forward the link to someone who can.  Maybe your family and friends have a business who would like to sponsor the campaign.  PLEASE HELP SPLASH REALIZE THEIR DREAM OF OWNING SHOW CHOIR RISERS!
