story:
*UPDATE*

Our premiere of Telepresence on December 17th went swimmingly! The HTC served up a dynamic mixture of electrifying sounds, fresh moves, and captivating imagery, leaving Charlotte audiences buzzing with energy, asking thoughtful questions, and effectively provoked! We cannot wait to be back in the creative process, continuing to dig deeper in developing this work, and seeing everyone again for our Spring premiere!


The Low-Down:

The Human Triptych Collective (HTC) is a group of independent artists comprised of dancers, musicians, and visual artists. For our current project, Telepresence, we are creating a multi-media performance art piece that features live music, live dance, and visualizations that focuses on the social effects of social media and communication technology usage. The performance explores society's current philosophy of technology and encourages viewers to consider the manner in which technologies shape everyday life. 
With our unique and wholly collaborative blend of performance art, we are interested in removing our work from concert halls and traditional fine arts venues, and bringing it directly to our audiences into unexpected and accessible spaces.

The subject of Telepresence looks at how our human to human experience is augmented by the pervasiveness of modern technologies. In exploring such dense and complex ideas, we are committed to continuing it's development beyond our premiere performance. 


The second installment of Telepresence is slated for mid-April at a newly-opened bar and music venue in Charlotte, NC.

This is where we performed in December 2011:
THE EVENING MUSE, Charlotte, NC




We have also performed:

The Orange Peel, Asheville, NC



The Neighborhood Theatre, Charlotte, NC



What We Need: 

So making good work with a lot of fabulous artists (14 to be exact) comes with a hefty price-tag. We are creating this campaign in hopes to cover only a FRACTION of our actual expenses...
In continuing to develop Telepresence, our goal is to raise funds for the purpose of space rental. This is a two fold expense which firstly includes renting a consistent rehearsal space, that can accommodate both dancers and our musicians. It's imperative for the musicians and dancers to be in the same space during the creative process so that the collaboration between the two is genuine and in the moment. Secondly, we need to rent the venues in which we perform. We carefully choose spaces, primarily bars and music venues, that will expose a crowd that might not otherwise find themselves dashing off to the ballet.

BUDGET BREAKDOWN:

Rehearsal space: $20/hr x 12 week rehearsal period = $1300
Performance space: Avg. overhead for music venues = $500

Lift up the couch cushions and throw some change in our direction! 
You can be sure your dollars are providing a foundation for change 
in the arts community in Charlotte, NC. 
Our budget does not include artist's stipends or paychecks!
You're looking at a group of creative individuals
who
are making work out of passion and creative necessity,
but need your generous donation 
of 
$1  $5 $100
to make things happen.

Thanks, ya'll!


Telepresence is:

Musicians:
Eric Mullis (Actual Proof), Chad Thompson (Asleep in the Weeds), Charlie Trexler, Johnny Abraham Jr. (Actual Proof)

Dancers/Choreographers:
Colton Southworth, Melissa Word, Blakeney Bullock, Nia Galas, Mineko Shannon, Caitlyn Swett


Check out these links and tell all yr friends!

story:
So, Who Are We?

a chick & a dude productions is an Austin-based theatre company celebrating its 10th anniversary season in 2011-2012 with David Mametâ€™s Glengarry Glen Ross! The â€˜chickâ€™ is Co-Artistic Director Melissa Livingston-Weaver, whose work has been described by NYTheatre.com as doing "...a fine job of creating tight and crisp scenes." The â€˜dudeâ€™ is Shanon Weaver, Co-Artistic Director and Resident Playwright. Company members include Technical Director Shawn Ferrell, Graphic Designer Dan Price, Marketing Communications Director Heather Levy, Production Manager Katy Billik and Artistic Associate T. Lynn Mikeska.

For more information, and a trailer for Glengarry Glen Ross, visit www.achickandadude.com, where you can see trailers and videos of past shows, as well as production photos and history!

 

The Impact!

We are thrilled to be producing this Pulitzer Prize winning classic, particularly at a time like this. What could be more relevant today than a play about men lying, cheating, stealing and screwing anyone over to get rich and stay that way?

 

So, what do we need, and what do you get?

As a lot of you may know, raising that curtain ainâ€™t cheap. Hereâ€™s a brief list of just a few things that go into our shows!

Graphic Design (posters, programs, postcards, web-based graphics)

Marketing/Communications

Costuming

Script licensing rights

Venue rental (around $2250 alone!)

Set construction

Press releases

Sound design

Light design

And of course, PAYING OUR ACTORS/CREW!

So what does your gracious contribution put back in your hands? We have lots of goodies including tickets to the show, company t-shirts, and even an invite to an exclusive private reception with the cast and crew to give away, based on your donation level. Check it all out in detail over there on the right!

And did we mention that ALL donations can be 100% tax-deductible, thanks to our sponsoring project, the Austin Creative Alliance? TAX. DEDUCTIBLE. Just make sure you choose the PayPal option at check out! If you're not concerned about a tax deduction, just choose the credit card option without going through PayPal. You get the perks either way!

 

How else can you help?

We know times are tight. We appreciate any help you can give us, and would love to have you join the team to get us to our goal. Every little bit helps. And please, feel free to share the campaign if you feel weâ€™re a worthy cause!

 

Thanks,

Shanon Weaver & Melissa Livingston-Weaver

Co-Artistic Directors, a chick & a dude productions

story:
OUR STORY

Hello,Nikk Alcaraz and our theatre group is called Darling Starr Productions. Our group was formed in late 2011 with a production of the Rocky Horror Show. Our purpose of the group is to grow as young artists and learn what it is to produce, direct and budget a show built from the ground up. We start fundraising for our shows as soon as January for a show in June. Our cast holds bake sales, car washes, raffles and sells advertisements in our programs to businesses around Santa Fe, New Mexico. We are recently going to put on a production of The Little Shop of Horrors this summer 2013. For every production we put on, we meet new faces and participants. Joining the group all depends on what production we are doing. This year we will have at least 10 cast members and 5 crew members. Our casts age usually ranges from 16-25 and we are all grateful that Darling Starr Productions is in action. There are so many people in Santa Fe that have been waiting for an opportunity like Darling Starr Productions to come along, and I am honored to be a part of this opportunity. Darling Starr Productions usually has all of its shows at Warehouse 21 every summer. Our most recent show was RENT, the musical. We all overcame huge challenges and struggles before and during RENT production. The end result of RENT was rewarding, it caught a lot of wind from the media. We couldn't have started this group without the support from our community.

What We Need & What You Get

Darling Starr Productions has the talent and all we need is the supplies. We need to reach a goal of $1,500 to make this show possible. All funds will go to the set, costumes, microphones and our big man eating plant. If you donate to our cause, your name will apper on our program graciasly thanking you for supporting Santa Fe's young artists. So please any donation is accepted, please help Santa Fe's youth stay creative.
 

The Impact

We are ALWAYS appericiative of anyone who donates to our productions. Darling Starr Productions is ctreated by teens for teens and young adults. The only way we get funds is by having bake sales every saturday and thats not making a dent in our goal. Darling Starr Productions has provided EXTREMELY talented young performers a chance to share their love of performing with the Santa Fe area. You're support will keep us young artists in Santa Fe active and will let us continue what we are truly passionate about.

 

Other Ways You Can Help.

You can help by sharing this page with your family and friends.

story:
Hello Mappsters and new supporters! Below is a brief description of our 30 day campaign and a personal story. This is an important moment in the history of MAPP. With the new relationship to our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, we can now raise important funding for new development and expansion of our exciting work!  If you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask. I am looking forward to this!

Tom Kellogg 

 

Campaign: May- June 2013

We need $30,000* to put immediately into project development and preproduction toward MAPP programs in the 2013/14 school year with the Coeur D' Alene Tribe, the Nez Perce Tribe, and cross-cultural (native, refugee, latino, LGBT) MAPP projects in Boise, Idaho.

All of these community partners are currently pursuing funding for MAPP programs through tribal grants, arts foundation grants, and regional business sponsorships. Your support here, will allow us to assist this process, make commitments to key community partners, as well as stay focused on planning and scheduling of MAPP programs and participants into the next school calendar year. 

This funding will also help us to re-establish development with our community partners in Oregon, California, Alaska, and British Columbia. 

This funding will be critical to building a solid base from which to reach out to new communities who have requested our help to bring MAPP to their reservations or urban centers throughout the country and abroad.

* To make $30,000, we set a goal of $33,333, because 7%  goes to  Fractured Atlas for fiscal sponsorship responsibilities. The other 93% will go toward MAPP production costs.   

 

now, if and when you have the time, please read below...

 

The MAPP Story:

It is just after 4 am… Too early for coffee. I got out of bed with so many thoughts about how to talk about this amazing work I’ve been involved in for 20 years now… I know it is the most authentic thing I have ever done. It seems to be as simple at times as gathering a group of adults, stepping into a circle in a room with a group of young people and spending some very special time listening to each other… and that’s where the magic happens…

and what is this magic exactly? Well, its those moments when a young person tells you a story that breaks your heart, or makes you laugh, or gives you an insight into her dreams, and how she sees the world… powerful stuff… epic really. If you have been in that room you know what I am talking about… it never leaves you… that is the power of this creative work. It makes the unseen visible. It heals us… Yes, that is the word I have heard many times over in community, from parents, and elders, and teachers, and artists. This work heals us… bringing our children into the circle makes us, as a people, whole again…

Then we get this other benefit that comes with the work. We get to take these young people and their dramatic stories and we get to share them with the world… And all over again, the magic is there in the room…  Once again, the voices of our young people are honored, through the performances of adults sitting there on stage only a few feet away from the young writer, conveying the poetry and deep song…  everyone melded at the heart… and the audiences are changed, because they are witnessing a birth really… and they are connected to a basic human need, the need to connect at the level of spirit, a need often glossed over by the rush of the mundane reality…

So this is the aspiration and the narrative that has carried me for 20 years now. This is the passion that took me out of the more seemingly comfortable confines of my life in Los Angeles into juvenile lock down facilities, drug rehab centers, and orphanages throughout the country. This is the desire that gave me the courage to reach beyond seemingly impossible barriers to work on Native American Reservations and in urban Native centers all over North America… this is the need that has led me to some of the most recent heart- stirring work with multicultural community including recent refugees from Afghanistan, Pakistan, the Congo, Somalia, and Zimbabwe… with Latino youth… with LGBT youth… with young people, some who have learning disabilities, but also spirits and imaginations as big and powerful as the universe.

 

Many of you have been there with me, over the years, in the room. So many people have supported this precious work. Sometimes it is hard to believe we have achieved what we have… So many dialogues, at times late into the night, about how amazing these young people are. So many talks, and planning meetings, and work sessions, and rehearsals, and celebrations…  it feels good to have this history. It feels good to experience people on this level. It feels good to have friendships that are connected to this cause.

MAPP has always been structured to make its community partners the owners and driving force of the project… In other words, MAPP works for its communities. Because of this, so many of our community partners continue to seek and provide essential financial support and in-kind contributions. But the fact is, the economic crisis over the past 4 years has kept MAPP from developing in the places where we have already created a vibrant , exciting tradition.  And we have not been able to respond fully to the multiple requests from marginalized communities all over the country, who have asked us to help them develop ongoing MAPP programming, which will allow them to do the healing work we can do through this program.

It may sound strange, but during this time of extreme belt tightening, I have actually been focused on expansion. I’d like to see the development of a MAPP institute: A training center for mentor artists, educators, and community developers. A place where the pulse of what we do, can be felt and transferred to the next generation.

 

I am hoping you will become a visible part of the MAPP community through our Facebook page, the MAPP blog, or if possible, as a mentor in one of our programs.

 

Thank you!

Thomas Dean Kellogg

Founder/ Director

Mentor Artists Playwrights Project (MAPP)

In the circle of light, we gather, to illuminate the world

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Even if you can give, please get the word out and make some noise about our MAPP campaign. 

THANKS!

THANKS!

story:
Greetings!

TALA is back for a second workshop production at HERE’s Summer Sublet Series, July 28-31st, 2012, and we need to raise $5,000 to make it happen! Your donations will help us provide artist stipends, pay our design and technical crew, and support our production costs.

TALA is a meta-theatrical play that merges the playwright’s autobiography with the story of Pepe and Lupe, two lovers caught on the Chilean island of Chiloé the night before Pinochet’s military coup. Collaging satirical sketches based on Samuel Beckett’s works, letters and poems written by Chilean poets Pablo Neruda and Gabriela Mistral, and autobiographical monologues, TALA explores the surreal parallels between life, performance, and the creation of art as an act of revolution.

TALA is the first production written and directed by Kyoung H. Park as Artistic Director of Pacific Beat Collective. Pacific Beat Collective (PBC) is a multi-cultural collective of artists creating interdisciplinary works of original theater that explore our world’s interconnectedness. We believe that theater has the power to bridge cultural differences and serve as a tool for non-violent social change. Through art and dialogue, our work questions oppressive social structures and promotes a culture of peace, by radically de-stabilizing normative assumptions that cause direct and structural violence in the world.

TALA

Written and directed by Kyoung H. Park
Performed by Rafael Benoit, Daniel K. Isaac, Flor de Liz Perez
Produced by Pacific Beat Collective (PBC)

Creative Team:

Sound Design: Chris Barlowâ€¨
Lighting Design: Chuan-Chi Chanâ€¨
Costume Design: Elizabeth Grothâ€¨
Composer: Svetlana Marasâ€¨
Video Design: John Knowlesâ€¨
Installation Art: Jason Krugmanâ€¨
Dramaturg: Keren Toledano
Choreography: Yin Yueâ€¨
Set Design: Marie Yokoyama
Stage Manager: Steven Roweâ€¨
Producer: Amanda J. Crater

FOR TICKETS: http://www.here.org/shows/detail/990/

story:
DEATH, THE MUSICAL

Death, the Musical is a comedic, irreverent musical revue about all aspects of death.  It was created over a two-year period by a Houston-based team, which received nearly 200 submissions from composers and writers all over North America.  They selected the best and funniest of the bunch and compiled them into a hilarious musical revue.  


We'd like your help funding a premiere performance and a CD recording of this new revue!  The performance will run at Houston's Ovations throughout the month of October 2011, closing with a special Halloween performance and after-party.


Thunderclap Productions

Thunderclap Productions is a Houston-based theatre company dedicated to producing new, emerging, and underrepresented plays and musicals.  Though new to the Houston theatre scene, the company has already made its mark, with sold-out shows and critical acclaim!


Thunderclap Productions is honored to be premiering Death, the Musical.


What We Need & What You Get

This production and recording are estimated to cost around $10,000!  We need your help to raise at least $3,000 of that!


To thank you for your generosity, gifts include the CD with the music from the show (or digital downloads), tickets to the show, and various other swag as detailed on this page.


Thunderclap Productions is also completing its 501(c)3 application.  If we are approved, your donations will be tax deductible for the 2011 tax year!


Other Ways You Can Help

Let others know about our fundraising campaign!  Also, consider buying tickets to the show or CDs of the cast recording.

story:
Who We Are

Cowardly Kiss Theatre was founded in February of 2006 by writer/director Andrea Beça in order to produce her works at the Edmonton International Fringe Theatre Festival.


After four successful festival productions at the Edmonton Fringe, Cowardly Kiss took a huge leap to produce its first fully independent play, BUNBURYING, written as Andrea's Master's in Playwriting thesis at the University of Glasgow, Scotland. The play, which was produced at the Transalta Arts Barns in the Spring of 2011, was very well-received by the Edmonton theatre community, and was recently named the "most audacious idea for a new play" by Edmonton Journal reviewer Liz Nicholls.


This summer, Cowardly Kiss is thrilled to be returning to the Edmonton Fringe with a play unlike any other. Joan. Edie. Joyce. Carolyn. Joan. Elise... Inspired by the lives of the women of the Beat Generation, (Real) Gone (Girl) is more than a play - it's a theatrical experience for everyone involved, including the actresses, who will be exposed to the script word by word, live on stage on the night of their performances, just like the audience. Each actress will perform the script once. Each audience will see (Real) Gone (Girl) once. No two performances (or performers) will be the same.


Here's what people are saying about Cowardly Kiss and its productions:


"Here's a little company that's definitely got something going on." - The Edmonton Journal


"Impressively audiacious." - The Edmonton Journal


This Campaign

As an independent theatre artist, I run Cowardly Kiss Theatre on a completely out-of-pocket basis. This means that every show I've produced since 2007 has been put on my credit cards (sometimes split between a few of them!) in hopes that I'll be able to pay them off with ticket sales. But beyond paying my own bills, it has always been my goal, first and foremost, to be able to provide my cast and crew with a paycheque (no matter how humble) to show them how much I value the countless hours of "blood, sweat, and tears" hard work they put into my plays. We as artists all have to start somewhere, often working for free, or even paying to work. I understand that, and I've been there. Sometimes I still am there. Which is why I strive to do the best I can by my cast and crew.


(Real) Gone (Girl) is no different, and due to its nature (of having a different performer for each night of the production), it's a large cast and crew - there are 10 incredible, beautiful, committed theatre practitioners involved, doing everything from acting and stage management to choreography and dramaturgy.


What (Real) Gone (Girl) Needs From You

Let's be frank: in theatre - especially festival theatre like the Fringe, where there are so many different plays to choose from - there are no guarantees of ticket sales, even with five-star reviews. In order to ensure that Cowardly Kiss Theatre stays on top of its finances, and can therefore continue to make audacious, thought-provoking theatre, we need to raise $2,000 to help cover the majority of the costs of this production. The simple truth is that if we don't raise that much, we're less likely to make profit at the Fringe, leaving me unable to pay my cast and crew. If we raise more, we're that much closer to profit, I can pay everyone involved, and I can move forward with my company and all of its future projects (which includes a web series coming late summer 2011 and a series of plays in 2012). I've been blessed (and lucky) to never have to stop making art, and I hope that with your help, I'll never have to.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can only donate $10 to (Real) Gone (Girl), you'll be making a difference for our production, and there are numerous other ways you can help, too. Please pass this campaign along to everyone you know - spread the word through email, Facebook, Twitter, however you can!


And when the 2011 Edmonton Fringe Festival rolls around (August 11-21, 2011), please come out to see (Real) Gone (Girl) at the Westbury Theatre! Our performance (and performer) schedule is as follows:


August 11 @ 8pm - performed by Sarah Horsman

August 13 @ 6:15pm - performed by Elisa Benzer

August 16 @ 12:15pm - performed by Mari Chartier

August 18 @ 4:45pm - performed by Georgia Irwin

August 19 @ 11pm - performed by Louise Large

August 21 @ 2:15pm - performed by Delia Barnett


Finally, from the bottom of my heart, thank you so much for your time and your support! Local, independent theatre would not be possible without you all.

story:
Our Story

Hi! I'm Allison Lerman-Gluck, a Division III (senior) student at Hampshire College studying Theatre, Education, and Community Building. For my thesis project, I'm directing a production of 'The Fantasticks' by Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt at Hampshire College. This show will be a study in collaboration and ensemble/community building, with Hampshire students working hand-in-hand with Amherst Regional High School students. Both the acting team and the design/production team of the show will be comprised of Hampshire AND ARHS students. This show is a great opportunity for myself, the 25+ other people who will be working on it, and the Hampshire/ARHS communities to open the lines of communication between ARHS and Hampshire, so that we can start utilizing each other as members of the same community and as theatrical/educational resources. 


The plot: Two lovers (Matt and Luisa) live on either sides of a wall erected by their fathers, who are in the midst of a 'feud.' They get involved in a passionate secret romance, certain that they are disobeying their fathers. Little do they know, the fathers have started this pretend 'feud' in order to bring their children together- acting under the belief that parents can manipulate their children simply by saying 'no.' To bring the families together, the fathers develop an elaborate ruse (with the help of El Gallo) that establishes Matt as a dramatic hero. However, their plans go sour when the children find out that they were manipulated.  

This is a story about finding the recipe to love, about age-ism, about power dynamics, about family relationships, about building and dismantling archetypes. It's a timeless and hilarious story, and the music is absolutely gorgeous, containing classic standards (such as 'Soon It's Gonna Rain' and 'Try To Remember'). 

The Impact

Hopefully, this collaboration will lead to future collaborations and more open lines of communications between the students of both schools. It will be a wonderful learning experience for both Hampshire and ARHS students, and a great training tool for those who wish to enter a future career in the performing arts. 

What We Need & What You Get

The problem? We have no funding for things like props and costume, unless I plan to fund the production out of pocket. I'm looking to raise a total of $500.00, with the hope that these funds can be put towards props, set, costume design, potentially having to acquire outside lighting and sound equipment, and potentially having to order extra scripts for our designers. I'm setting the bar high at $500, but I'd really love to aim higher. Please donate, it would be great if we could hit $700-$800! This show will happen regardless of whether we get all of our needs met here, but if we don't, we just may end up scrimping. The finished product can be just that- a finished product!- with your help! 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE SHARE THIS WITH ALL OF YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY MEMBERS/COMMUNITY MEMBERS!!!


In accordance with the 'Dramatic Performing Rights License':
THE FANTASTICKS is presented through special arrangement with Music Theatre International (MTI). All authorized performance materials are also supplied by MTI. 
421 West 54th Street, New York, NY 10019
Phone: 212-541-4684 Fax: 212-397-4684
www.mtishows.com

story:
One of the major themes I explore in my work at hyperRitual is the mediation of magic, especially through digital, electronic, and new media. Magicians often employ various artifacts to express their intentions or alter their states of consciousness: wands, cups, daggers, pentacles, drums, bells, incense, candles, cards, stones, and many other things might be interacted with in the context of a magic ritual or to communicate a magical idea. I believe we can interact with robots in these contexts, and that their animated and responsive natures allow for novel ritual designs and magical experiences. Here is an example that I recently exhibited.

So, here is my pitch: I want to write a book about robotic magic (robomancy). The first that I know of. Actually, more than that: I want to create a community of robomancy enthusiasts. I don't want to write something people will read and say, "Wow, this is cool, but I don't know how to build or program robots."  I want to make something that inspires magicians to make robots, and inspires roboticians to make magic, and that uniquely shows how to do each in the context of the other.

Now, while I love fine occult books, and have friends who write and publish them, I want to make a living, online book that needs not wait for a second edition because it is continually updated with new information, ideas, and designs. A book with (embedded, not auxiliary) multimedia including HD video; hyperlinks; file downloads; interactive programs; and integrated social media so readers can discuss and share their own ideas and works, all within the same cyberspace. Thus, Robomancy.com, in two parts:

Robomancy in Theory and Practice (A TalisManual of RobotiCraft) will feature reflections on and applications in robotic thaumaturgy and theurgy including a variety of magical and ritual designs involving astral, virtual, and mechanical robots, and techniques for blending magic and robotics to help you create your own designs. In order to appeal to a wide audience including novices to robotics, the book's examples will use free, open-source, and/or affordable technologies popular with amateurs and hobbyists. The book will be rife with links to supplementary resources, and will observe the principles of Open Sourcery while conserving some of the aesthetic, curiosity, and mystery of talismanic books and the grimoire tradition. All content will be licensed under Creative Commons to encourage re/distribution, adaptation, and, most of all, participation.

The Robomancers' Guild will be an integrated social network including discussion forum, robomancer blogs (you can have your own!), and access to member swag, exclusive content, and special offers as a way of showing gratitude to participants.

The site is expected to go live at the end of this year (December 2012).




Why a fundraiser?

All of my previous projects were funded from my own pocketbook, but the scope I envision for Robomancy demands a greater investment. I figure IndieGoGo will be a fun way to crowd-fund the project while raising awareness and interest, and also something of an experiment in the viability of funding esoteric projects this way. Your contributions will help me pay for the website development, content creation, electronics and other materials used for the projects described in the book, and of course the funder perks.

I have set a conservative, all-or-nothing goal of $1000 for this fundraiser. If we do not raise that amount or more by the next new moon, then all contributions will be refunded.

What perks?

In addition to the satisfaction of having contributed to the world's first esoteric book and community about robots, everyone who funds the project will receive thank-you gifts called perks, many of which are exclusive to this campaign. My friends Cathartech, Rosarium Blends, and Dakota Crane have generously donated their mad skills to creating unique robomantic artifacts to get your gears turning. The various perks are listed on the right-hand side of this page.

If we exceed the $1000 goal, then I will find ways to add value to the project, which I will share in the campaign updates. Also...

Unlock additional perks!

In addition to the perks listed at right...

  • UNLOCKED! All contributors will receive a free Seal of the Robomagi embroidered patch to display on their ritual robes or lab coats!
  • UNLOCKED! All contributors will receive a free laser-cut acrylic Ouranos/Uranus pendant to honor and invoke the wandering star governing electricity, technology, and invention!
  • UNLOCKED! All contributors will receive a free download of Azoth of the Robots animated digital art for meditating on the Anima Machinae (soul of the machine)!
  • If all 5 ROBOMAGUS pledges are claimed, then all (and only) Robomagi (including the Grand Robomagus) will receive a free 8Ã—10 Robotheosis screen-printed diagram in electrically conductive ink on goatskin parchment (or paper substitute for you vegetarians), showing the ascension of a robot into a god!

Let's rock this!

And make occult history, together... robomancer style! Please contribute what you can, claim your perks, and help us spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Digg, Reddit, Boing Boing, Tumblr, Posterous, your favorite occult and robotics forums, etc. Thank you!

Footnotes

  1. Thanks again. Your contribution also helps increase awareness of the project, but you can help even more by promising to tell at least three people about us.
  2. Est. delivery April 2012.
  3. Est. delivery April 2012. Listen to some of Cathartech's sonic munitions here.
  4. Email address: Technically, an email forwarding address. Incense/oil: Approx. 0.5 to 0.75 oz. (~50 mL) of loose incense, or 1 full dram of oil. Est. delivery July 2012. Click here to read well-deserved praise for Rosarium Blends products.
  5. PCB artifact: 6Ã—6 in. printed-circuit-board artifact designed by Dakota Crane and etched, numbered, and ritually consecrated by Joshua Madara. Includes instructions for use. Est. delivery July 2012. See samples of Dakota's sigil machines here.
  6. Talismachine: 8Ã—10 in. interactive (and hackable) electronic art print. You can actually connect the print to your computer and communicate with it, reprogram it, whatever. Here is an example of an earlier Talismachine of lesser quality (yours will have a microcontroller and more components). Est. delivery July 2012. Art: All artists will be required to digitally sign a magical contract nullifying the power of the sigil in the event that its true intent is malicious or inappropriate to the ritual the sigil was created for.
  7. Ordination: In person if you can travel to Seattle, otherwise via Skype or similar. Robot: Est. delivery December 2012.

If all 5 ROBOMAGUS pledges are claimed, then all (and only) Robomagi (including the Grand Robomagus) will receive a free 8Ã—10 Robotheosis screen-printed diagram in electrically conductive ink on goatskin parchment (or paper substitute for you vegetarians), showing the ascension of a robot into a god!
Let's rock this!And make occult history, together... robomancer style! Please contribute what you can, claim your perks, and help us spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Digg, Reddit, Boing Boing, Tumblr, Posterous, your favorite occult and robotics forums, etc. Thank you!Footnotes
Thanks again. Your contribution also helps increase awareness of the project, but you can help even more by promising to tell at least three people about us.

Est. delivery April 2012.

Est. delivery April 2012. Listen to some of Cathartech's sonic munitions here.


Email address: Technically, an email forwarding address. Incense/oil: Approx. 0.5 to 0.75 oz. (~50 mL) of loose incense, or 1 full dram of oil. Est. delivery July 2012. Click here to read well-deserved praise for Rosarium Blends products.


PCB artifact: 6Ã—6 in. printed-circuit-board artifact designed by Dakota Crane and etched, numbered, and ritually consecrated by Joshua Madara. Includes instructions for use. Est. delivery July 2012. See samples of Dakota's sigil machines here.


Talismachine: 8Ã—10 in. interactive (and hackable) electronic art print. You can actually connect the print to your computer and communicate with it, reprogram it, whatever. Here is an example of an earlier Talismachine of lesser quality (yours will have a microcontroller and more components). Est. delivery July 2012. Art: All artists will be required to digitally sign a magical contract nullifying the power of the sigil in the event that its true intent is malicious or inappropriate to the ritual the sigil was created for.

Ordination: In person if you can travel to Seattle, otherwise via Skype or similar. Robot: Est. delivery December 2012.

story:
Who We Are and What We're All About

Jazz Squared Theatre is a new Toronto based Company committed to creating and nurturing Canadian Musical Theatre.

Our first project is The Beaver Den: A New Canadian Musical. Set in 1999 at the wake of children’s entertainment, The Beaver Den follows a cast of young actors “stuck” on a kid’s TV show filmed in the Muskoka Region.

Meet a cast of ridiculous characters including a Keanu-Reeves-obsessed actor, a Princess of Plaid, a Coca-Cola-addicted star, and a puppeteer struggling with his inner-beaver.

Please help us raise funds to mount our show at the Lower Ossington Theatre which premieres October 10th, 2012.

What We Need & What You Get

Mounting a musical theatre show has more hidden costs than a bad phone bill. The money we raise will first be used to pay off the space itself. We have to perform somewhere! Next there's the set and costumes. Our set is pretty minimal but still costly, and no actor wants to go on stage naked...well, maybe some actors. Another cost is our adorable Beavy puppet. He's cute and high maintanance. 

Your generous donations, no matter how big or small, are all extremely appreciated. If you look to the right of this blurb you will see many perks offered for different donation amounts. Some of these perks include hugs, tickets, music, etc... 

If you make any donation over $25, please email us with your full name and the amount you donated. Our email adress is located at the bottom of the page.

We know there is a possibility of not reaching our goal. All of the funds contributed, however, will be used and appreciated. We will also still be distributing the perks. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't contribute financially. But if you want to contribute in another way, we won't complain! Here are some ways:

Tell your friends, family, and strangers about the show! Nothing works better than word of mouth. 

There is also a "share" option at the bottom of this page for Facebook, Twitter, etc. Or copy and paste the link in an email. Or is that too old school?

If you are a business or have a knack with crafts, art, or baking, donations of items can be excepted for fundraising campaigns. Please email us if you're interested. 

Also, if you'd like to volunteer time we might need help with the set-up/take-down, building, and on show nights. 

And, of course, come see the show! Nothing beats an audience to perform to!

Any questions, email us at jazzsquared@hotmail.com. Thank you so much! See you at the Den!

 

***Any perks that involve adding names or advertisements to the program cannot be completed as of Friday, October 5th as the programs have already been printed. We are sorry for the inconvenience.***

story:
Words have no power to impress the mind without the exquisite horror of their reality.

- Edgar Allan Poe


This summer, BROKEN GLASS presents workshop performances of three original one-act plays inspired by the tales of Gothic genius Edgar Allan Poe.

When:   August 8th-12

Where:  The Bridge Theatre

             244 W 54th St, 12th Fl

             New York, NY 10019

What:   ISO by Kate Moran, based on Some Words with a Mummy

             TELL-TALE by Antoinette Nwandu, based on The Tell-Tale Heart

             CHEERS by Nathan Zebedeo, based on The Cask of Amontillado

Why Poe?

Edgar Allan Poe's work spans the range of human emotions - from love, joy, and passion to jealousy, paranoia, rage and, of course, fear. With uncanny perception and unflinching honesty, Poe's writing is able to get at our most primal instincts. When Poe holds up the mirror to society, we at first suspect that we are staring back at a carnival funhouse reflection. With dawning comprehension, we realize with horror that his mirror is perhaps far more realistic than we dare believe. That which we truly fear is not being lost in the dark, but the darkness inside of our own hearts and minds.

We Need Your Help!

These exciting new plays cannot be brought to the stage without your support. There are a few ways to help:

  • Please consider making a donation. Thanks to our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, your financial contribution will be tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Check out the different perks you can take advantage of!
  • Come see our show! Tickets will be on sale soon and we will keep you posted.
  • Share this campaign with your family and friends. It doesn't take much to post us to Twitter or Facebook.

Poe Fun Facts

For The Raven, one of the most famous or Poe’s works, if not the most famous, he was paid $9.

He was born the same year as Abraham Lincoln (with whom he may, or may not, have been a vampire hunter).

For most of his life, the iconic mustache was absent. Only in the much darker, desperate, final years did he grow that romantic, brooding facial hair and begin to go mad.

Poe’s bizarre life didn’t stop just because he died in 1849. He was buried in an unmarked grave, and when gossip finally led to a stone being ordered, it was destroyed in a train accident.

Ever since 1949, someone has left a bottle of cognac and some roses on Poe’s grave. Who is leaving these things? And why?

Who We Are

BROKEN GLASS is a company of collaborative theatre artists. Using classic texts as our inspiration, we seek to create new and original works that address and illuminate today's pressing sociopolitical issues. Our goal is to provide audiences with an extremely relevant theatre experience. We believe that our work is only as good as the conversation it provokes.

story:
We have a tremendous opportunity and we need your help.
We need to move in order to keep the The Drum & Dance Learning Center going.  We have a great opportunity for new space but it requires a bit more financial start up than we currently have.

The Drum & Dance Learning Center/Alexia's Belly Dance & Beyond has been providing high quality multi-cultural dance and percussion programs in central New Jersey since 2005.  The studio is home to Groove Merchant Drum & Dance Ensemble and is where the creative collaboration and original work incubates for this unique and exciting group of drummers & dancers.
Review:
Alexia's Belly Dance and Beyond (aka DDLC) is the perfect place to come and flex your creative muscles in World Music & Dance. The diverse classes and workshops are aimed at educating not just in movement and music but also in cultural and historical understanding. I have been dancing with Kim since 2006 and can truly say that without her guidance, teaching, and support, I would not be half the dancer I am today. All levels of experience and ALL shapes and sizes are welcome to join in the party, and this is rare in today's Photoshop culture. The program is intended to encourage growth, no matter what your current ability is. When I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009, it was the program at this studio that helped me get through my treatment and become whole again during my recovery. I LOVE participating at a studio where the staff is concerned about a student's total well-being, not just her pants size! - DM

Why it's important...
Securing regular rehearsal space for Groove Merchant has been the main goal of operating the studio.  Through our classes and projects we meet so many inspiring people as we provide a creative home for offering culture specific dance & drum classes, dance fitness programs and community events that celebrate and encourage creative and personal growth.  We are grateful for the studio family and all of the talents, friendship and experience they bring.  The studio is a creative home and retreat for so many people.

Our obstacle...
From 2005 through 2011 the studio has operated in retail space, which tends to be rather expensive.  
Expenses keep rising and we are limited in the possibility for creating more income to support the overhead because we are restricted to having room for only one studio.

Two things would allow us to keep providing classes and keep the studio going:
  1. Having two studios
  2. and reduced rent in a non-retail space.

As luck would have it...that opportunity has been presented to us and we need to act now!  The new space is less than a half of a mile from  our current location  and this new space will open up tremendous opportunities for additional  projects and expanded class offerings.

How You Can Help?
We need some help moving...yes, physically and financially.  We know this is going to be a work in progress and we'd love for you to be part of making it all happen.

Our needs are many but these are the most important two:
  • $700 to move our dance studio mirrors (fingers crossed they make it in one piece to the new location)
  • $5200 for a dance floor

This would allow us the opportunity  to continue to provide the quality instruction and programs for which we have become known .

We still need help with cost of paint; decor; new signage; all the added expenses of start up with new utilities; a stereo for the second studio; additional office set up and general advertising to get the word out that we've moved and have more to offer ...the list goes on.  Help us reach our initial goal and maybe a little more to give us leg up.

Start Helping Now
Donate Now! For your support, we offer very usable rewards you can cash in at the studio or download.
Tell 3 friends about our campaign and why it's so important to you.

story:
Our Story

This is Extant Arts' 4th year filling New York City parks with free, accessible Shakespeare.  Extant Arts is a small, hard-working band of theatre artists and professionals who have made it their mission to bring to life classic plays in ways that are fresh, open, and - most of all - fun!!

In previous years the start-up costs of Extant's Summer Shakespeare Series have been funded by the artists themselves (that's right - us), but because of the infamous economic downturn, we need to rely on you - our friends, families, strangers, and audience - to help us make this play!  (And your donations are tax-deductible!)


What We're Doing

This year, in our fourth Summer Shakespeare Series, we are thrilled to present a modern imagining of MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING inspired by contemporary Williamsburg, Brooklyn and the culture clash between the established Italian immigrant community and the influx of hip, wealthy yuppies. 

Best friends Claudio and Benedick find themselves falling for two very different young ladies, the gentle Hero and her saucy cousin Beatrice. But when the spiteful Don John plots to spoil the budding romances and divide their friendship, will love survive?

The Impact

Over the past three summers, Extant has shared six Shakespeare plays with hundreds of park-goers across Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Queens. 

What we love most about our summer shows is the audience: where else can you see The Public's season ticket holders sitting on the grass next to Swedish-speaking tourists, passing dog-walkers sharing strawberries with a group of picnicking 30-somethings? Most of all, we love to cultivate a new generation of theater-goers.  From the five-year-old who accidentally wandered through the opening of THE TEMPEST to the rag-tag team of 12-year olds who, by the end of RICHARD III, were cheering on the War of the Roses as the battle raged on all sides.

Even as we strive for accessibility, we are dedicated to capturing the craft and spirit of the Bard. We perform without mics, in natural light for an audience out to enjoy a sunny afternoon.


What We Need

$15 keeps our full cast hydrated through a performance

$25 pays for one park permit

$50 pays for one day of rehearsal space in case of rain

$100 prints scripts for our team

$150 creates beautiful one-of-a-kind masks for MUCH ADO's masked ball

$250 costumes our cast

$500 pays for all our programs and publicity 

Other Ways You Can Help

1)  Come and see MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING June 17-July 17 in Central Park, Astoria Park, and Prospect Park

2)  Volunteer to help out with marketing, production, fundraising, or ushering

3)  Let others know you donated to our campaign by clicking the share buttons to post to Facebook, Twitter, etc.

For more information on all of these, check out our website: www.extantarts.org


To Claim Your Perks

Email kate.stahl@extantarts.org at least one week in advance of the show you are planning to attend (even more time is better) so we have the chance to prepare something special for you!

More on Who We Are

Since its founding in 2006, Extant Arts Company has presented high-quality productions from the classical canon coupled with exciting and profound new work in venues throughout the New York metropolitan area. Committed to continued engagement with enduring stories, Extant's dedicated artists and staff have explored the works of such luminaries as Euripides, Shakespeare, Chekhov, and Ibsen, as well as contemporary voices like Rebecca Gilman, and Ellen McLaughlin, all while working with schools to foster a passion for theatre in the next generation.

Our Mission: The word 'extant' means 'enduring, not destroyed or lost,' and it is the charge and passion of Extant Arts Company to engage with theatre that has endured, and make sure that such works are not lost to present or future audiences. By reinterpreting classic stories through live performance and fostering the classics of the future through adaptation, new play development, and educational outreach, Extant Arts Company strives to create a diverse community dedicated to sustaining stories.

story:
WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT!

With your generous support we're hoping to raise $500 to help us redevelop and rebuild our set for Crave: A Takeaway Show for the 2012 Festival of Australian Student Theatre (FAST) at La Boite. 

In May this year we had a week-long season in Vena Cava's Fresh Blood and we are delighted to have the opportunity to take this production further. Hopefully, with your support, we will be able to take it to the next level. 

In this second creative development, we hope to extend our design into the entire Roundhouse theatre space and immerse our audiences deep within Our Lloyd's takeaway tabernacle. We want to tantalise your taste buds and bring the power of Our Lloyd right to the tip of your tongue. 

NO CONTRIBUTION IS TOO SMALL!
There is a "menu" of different ways you can help! Every contribution brings us closer to our ultimate desire to give Our Lloyd's takeaway tabernacle new life and, in return, we'd like to satiate some of your own cravings… 

(see Your Perks on the right) 

CRAVE: A TAKEAWAY SHOW 
by Opiate Productions

There is a pervasive hunger amongst us. A craving, throbbing, pulsating urge, an undeniable ache. So hungry. Always hungry.

Come to Our Lloyd’s and he will feed all who are weary and heavy laden. A takeaway tabernacle that takes away the pang and lets you forget. Our Lloyd offers instant amnesia in a single-serving sermon, unlimited denial in just one simple transaction. You just have to confess. Confess and you too can attain eternal salvation. Devour the flesh of the spirit. Depart without waste or want… or at least, until the hunger hits again.

What feeds the mouth, doesn’t always feed the soul. 

Composed scenographically and collaboratively devised, Crave: A Takeaway Show is an original work which utilises a mix of traditional narrative, abstract text, and physical theatre to create an immersive audience experience. Whilst situated in an absurd landscape, this performance reveals an unsettling insight into the world we inhabit. Crave: A Takeaway Show raises some questions about the way we live - questions that, like our characters, we are afraid to answer.

 

OUR TEAM  

Directors | Ruby Donohoe & Sonia Kwek 
Producer | Matthew Higgins 
Stage Manager | Chrissy Mcphee
Designer | Nikiesha Stevenson
Assistant Designer | Thomas Bartsch 
Sound Designer | Liam Howarth
Performers | Jackson Blair-West, Cecile Blackmore, Ryan Currie, Liam Howarth, Luke Stevenson

Opiate Productions is a newly formed Brisbane-based theatre collective, comprised of multi-disciplinary artists who work across performance, visual art, music, marketing and creative writing. Propelled together by the desire to peer into the depths of our hunger, it is desire that has kept us together - a desire to move and be moved. Theatre is our opiate and we create to seek out the fever of dreams.  

Performing on a national scale at the Festival of Australian Student Theatre at La Boite is a huge opportunity we really treasure, and we hope to bring to life our envisioned world to share with wider audiences. Help us start off our blossoming creative collaboration with a bang!

Follow us on Facebook for the latest updates on our journey!
Thank you again for all your help


Yours insatiably

x

Ruby, Sonia, Matt & the Opiate Productions team

CRAVE: A TAKEAWAY SHOW by Opiate Productions

There is a pervasive hunger amongst us. A craving, throbbing, pulsating urge, an undeniable ache. So hungry. Always hungry.Come to Our Lloyd’s and he will feed all who are weary and heavy laden. A takeaway tabernacle that takes away the pang and lets you forget. Our Lloyd offers instant amnesia in a single-serving sermon, unlimited denial in just one simple transaction. You just have to confess. Confess and you too can attain eternal salvation. Devour the flesh of the spirit. Depart without waste or want… or at least, until the hunger hits again.What feeds the mouth, doesn’t always feed the soul. Composed scenographically and collaboratively devised, Crave: A Takeaway Show is an original work which utilises a mix of traditional narrative, abstract text, and physical theatre to create an immersive audience experience. Whilst situated in an absurd landscape, this performance reveals an unsettling insight into the world we inhabit. Crave: A Takeaway Show raises some questions about the way we live - questions that, like our characters, we are afraid to answer.
 
OUR TEAM  
Directors | Ruby Donohoe & Sonia Kwek Producer | Matthew Higgins Stage Manager | Chrissy McpheeDesigner | Nikiesha StevensonAssistant Designer | Thomas Bartsch Sound Designer | Liam HowarthPerformers | Jackson Blair-West, Cecile Blackmore, Ryan Currie, Liam Howarth, Luke Stevenson
Opiate Productions is a newly formed Brisbane-based theatre collective, comprised of multi-disciplinary artists who work across performance, visual art, music, marketing and creative writing. Propelled together by the desire to peer into the depths of our hunger, it is desire that has kept us together - a desire to move and be moved. Theatre is our opiate and we create to seek out the fever of dreams.  
Performing on a national scale at the Festival of Australian Student Theatre at La Boite is a huge opportunity we really treasure, and we hope to bring to life our envisioned world to share with wider audiences. Help us start off our blossoming creative collaboration with a bang!
Follow us on Facebook for the latest updates on our journey!Thank you again for all your help
Yours insatiably
xRuby, Sonia, Matt & the Opiate Productions team

story:
"An Hour Without TV" (Una Hora Sin Television)

My name is Mariana Campos and I'm an actress and theater producer from Venezuela. I recently fell in love and got married to an amazing Bostonian man and moved to the United States. We currently live in Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

I have always been passionate about women's issues. I'm delighted to see all these social movements that are currently happening in the world and I feel very inspired to do my part to contribute artistically to these movements.

As women, we should uplift and unite in order to make changes. Those changes have to start within ourselves and this play intends to do just that with an unexpected ending that will raise questions instead of giving definite answers.

The play talks about a couple (Edward and Patricia) who's "celebrating" their 10th wedding anniversary and Patricia wants one hour to talk without any distractions. Throughout this hour, all hidden (and not so hidden) truths begin to be exposed, all leading up to an unexpected ending.

Our artistic goal with this project is to denounce in a visual manner the physical and psychological abuse that some women can go through with their partners. Women should not feel abused, diminished or threatened in any relationship, but it's more common than not. That's why it's important to denounce these toxic and unhealthy patterns. That is the purpose of this play.

By contributing to this play, you will be part of a movement that aims to help women break free from violence, abuse, mistreatment and feeling psychologically imprisoned in relationships.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $7,000 to make this play a reality. All the money would go to pay for theater rental charges, director, actors, set designer, advertising, graphic design, sound design and lighting design fees, as well as royalties, costumes and props.
  • We tried to cut down costs as much as possible so everyone involved in this project is charging less than their normal fees, and the reason is because they love the project and want to support this cause.
  • What you get is good! As a thank you for your contribution, we would get you free tickets to come watch the play with a guest, you would be mentioned on our thank you notes of each program, and you'll get a signed copy of the play's poster by the actors, producer and director. 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we would still use whatever amount we get to make this play a reality. 

The Impact

This project is valuable to the world because as citizens we need to shed a light on the issues that matter to us. The world right now is paying close attention to women's issues so it's our turn to be heard to make a difference. Each one of us can do it from our own perspective, and my perspective is an artistic one so from the stage I'm taking a stand for this cause.

In 2014, thanks to all my friends and family who believe in me and my work, I was able to produce another play through this IndieGoGo platform called "Aqui No Paga Nadie" and as most of you know, it was a great success thanks to you and your collaboration! At that time, we were able to spread the message of hope and shed a light on injustice by a government that was and still is oppressing their people, and that message thankfully came across by being so well received by the audience in Venezuela.  

Now, I ask for your help again to allow us to cast light on this issue that has caused so many unnecessary deaths and pain within families. With your donation, this play can make someone who suffers from abuse to gain strength to fight for a better life.

Risks & Challenges

Making art is not an easy task because of the economy we live in, but when that's your calling in life you don't stop until you have given it your all in order to make dreams happen. 

Thankfully, we have a team that believes in the power of artistic expression, in this cause, in this story and on the impact we can create if we fight hard to make this a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, I completely understand! There's another way you can help us!

If you can please share this campaign with your friends or loved ones!

Thanks so much for taking the time to review this campaign!

story:
INTRODUCING... REIGNBOW!

QWAM (Queens With A Mission) is so excited to premiere Reignbow! Aligned with our family's values, Reignbow will be an all encompassing premiere showcase of queer/ally talent in the Boston and East Coast Community! Reignbow will be a one of a kind experience; fitting no other previous show mold. The night will showcase talent in the following five categories: Drag Performance, Choreographers, Group Performance, Fashion, and Vocal Performance. Amidst and in-between all of the performances, attendees will be able to dance, party, and celebrate; breaking that fourth wall between audience and performers. Simply put, Reignbow allows ALL to express their royalty. 

JOIN OUR MISSION!

Reingbow is a royal undertaking! Amazing venue, apparel, quality sound and lighting, incredible DJ, videography, and performers for all over the East Coast; we are pulling out all the stops. In order for us to reach the high level production quality we hope to achieve, we need your help! As a newly founded dance family and a non profiting group, all expenses will be hitting our own personal wallets. No matter the size of the donation, we would appreciate all contributions in helping make Reignbow possible!

THE IMPACT

Reignbow will be an amazing celebratory night to remember! But the night goes beyond music and dancing. Reingbow will give a platform to diverse and unique LGBTQ/ally artists to showcase their passions and who they really are. More than just dancing, this showcase will express an amazing variety of talent. 

Our hope is that Reignbow will not only help create and strengthen a community, but help build a more loving and accepting future. Reignbow's impact will hopefully continue each year as we aim to keep hosting and growing this event for years to come.

WHO ARE WE? QUEENS 

Established in 2016, QWAM champions for those who identify as part of the Boston Dance Scene and LGBTQ community. As a diverse all male dance crew, we are a family who want to express and experience dance in all aspects; masculinity, femininity, and reality. Through a collective and collaborative movement, we perform and compete across the East Coast. With Reignbow, we are excited to keep growing our impact and helping to create a more accepting, loving, and celebratory future! 

CONNECT AND SPREAD THE WORD

Even if you can't contribute, there are so many ways to help! One of the easiest ways to support; help us get the word out. Check out our various channels where you can stay connected and share our updates:

  • Facebook Page
  • Facebook Event
  • Instagram: @qwamfam
  • Website
  • Ticket Link (Event is 18+)

Please share, post, and publicize Reignbow to all your friends, family, and peers! Additionally, we are looking for any interested sponsors. Financially, in kind, or any other ways of sponsorship, we are reaching out to any and all organizations, companies, or groups who want to help us make an impact. Reach out to us through our above channels or contact through email: qwamfam@gmail.com

THANK YOU

Just by being on this campaign page and reading about Reignbow and who we are, we thank you. We appreciate the time you gave to learn more. Hopefully you are interested in helping us bring Reignbow to a reality. 

Much love and appreciation,

QWAM <3

story:
This unconventional production examines Shakespeare's Macbeth in a different way. With the freedom and flexibility of an outdoor space and a studio. Movement and voice are woven into the words and actions of the actors, bringing the audience out of the fourth wall and into the timeless storytelling circle. I didn't want to do Macbeth like all the times I had seen it before. So I bravely took the scissors to the script and then went completely crazy and added my own words. 

We need 5,000$ to pay back what we lay out for studio rental, props and costumes, to pay our actors and for all the unexpected expenses that come up.  

This project is valuable to the small theatre industry in NYC. Your making it possible for local artists to live their dream of acting. It is not easy in such an expensive often closed door society. Please spread the word for us! Fallow the Indiegogo share tools and send this to as many people as you can. Even if they don't live in NYC.

story:
Short Summary

Have you ever wanted to dive into the unknown and embark on a path in life you've never taken before?  Gerry Fishman knows how you feel.  It happened to him too!  Up until last year, Gerry was a furniture salesman who dreamed of performing full time.  Now, finally living his dream every day, Gerry is entertaining more than just co-workers, family, relatives and friends.  Join us at the show, premiering at The Hudson Theater, 6539 Santa Monica Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90038 July 19, 20, 26, 27 and Aug 2, 3, 9, 10 at 8pm. Matinees: July 28 and August 11 at 2pm.

YOU can help us make that happen.  Take a look at our video and contribute whatever you can -- $1, $5, $500... it's up to you.  Every dollar helps us defray theater rental costs and expenses.

With our first Indiegogo campaign we were able to raise over $2K!  Thanks so much to all our past donors, we appreciate you!  But we've still got a ways to go to cover all the production costs so we're reaching out to all you folks out there who believe in second chances. 

And if you've already donated and wonder how else you can help, why not invite some friends to see the show with you?  Here's a link to the ticket site to make that a snap https://gerry-coming-of-age-at-65.square.site/s...

Gerry has a dream, let's help make it happen!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute any funds at this time, we totally get it.  But there are a lot of other ways to help. 

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!  Share, share, share this link to friends and on your social media.  It's a grass roots campaign and word of mouth means everything.
  • Volunteer to help at the theater during performances - if you're able, we may need ushers and ticket takers.  Email the producer, Karen Herr at karenofhollywood@gmail.com if you're interested. (Free tickets for volunteers available, first come, first served)
  • And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks so much!  See you at the show!

story:
It's the final quarter of MFA program at UCLA's Department of World Arts and Cultures/Dance, and the date of my final concert approaches. 

This performance culminates three years of grad school. For the past year, I have worked on two dances— Clown's Girlfriend and Made in a Marble Palace— to present as my thesis concert. These projects feature all-female casts, theatrical costumes and props, and live music.

Although my department gives me some money for the concert, it is not enough to pay the dancers and other artistic collaborators. I strongly believe in paying artists for their work, so I will use the money to:

  • Compensate performers for their time and energy (this is where most of the money is going)
  • Reimbursement for parking (parking at UCLA is expensive)
  • A small portion of the funds will go toward costumes (my designer and I are doing this on the cheap, but we still need some cash). 

Any donation, small or great, is much appreciated. Thank you!

story:
Who are we?

We're Micah, Ali and Syd, three students putting up our senior project at Purchase College. We're collaborating with some of our creative colleagues to present Essence, a new play. 

Micah Rabang is a senior Theatre and Performance major. He was born and raised in Oahu, Hawaii, and came to New York to pursue theatre. He is elated to be directing his own work.

Alison Eadie is a senior Theatre/ Performance and Arts Management double major. She will play the role of Mae in Essence, and also serve as a producer for the show, managing marketing and fundraising efforts. She is overjoyed to create something beautiful at Purchase before she graduates in December and heads off into the real world.

Syd Freiberger is a senior Theatre/ Performance and History double major. She will be serving as dramaturg for the production. She's excited to be working on such a meaningful project with such hardworking people.

Cast:

Alison Eadie, Kaché Mumford

Erin Degnan, Raquel Willard, Siobahn Kiernan, Alexus Clemenson, Michael Karlya

Creative Team:

Director/ Playwright: Micah Rabang

Dramaturg: Syd Freiberger

Assistant Director: Megan Stacey

Movement Coordinator: Tyrone Hodges

What is Essence?

Essence is a new play written by Micah Rabang. 

A young woman named Mae moves into a new home. She finds that this place is already occupied by a former resident; the spirit of another young woman. Her home rests upon the ashes of another. In the space between the living and the dead, they learn to understand each other through stories and movement. 

You're Invited!

Essence will premiere at the Humanities Theater at Purchase College, October 19-21, 2017. Admission is FREE.

How you can help

As college students creating our capstone project, this effort is  entirely self funded. We need to raise $1,500 to bring Essence to life.

  • Funds will go directly into the materials we need to build our show- sets, costumes, lights
  • Every dollar counts and we appreciate any donation- we will be able to put it to good use!

The Impact

We are ecstatic to present this project as a culmination of our time at Purchase.

Essence is a play about colonialism and the erasure of indigenous history and culture. We aim to give a voice to those who have been silenced in the past and the present and in doing so empower communities to tell their story.

Can't make a donation but still want to help?

If you aren't able to make a donation at this time, please SHARE our campaign and our story with your friends. Scroll back up to the top of the page to share our campaign on Facebook. You can also follow us on Instagram @essenceplay, and RSVP at https://www.facebook.com/events/182862332411661...

The team at Essence thanks you for your generosity and support!

story:
Short Summary

Are you a supporter of the arts who likes sex, has a love for debauchery, and wishes your fantasies could be reality? If your answer is "yes" then we have something to share with you.
We are the erotic variety show known as Bordello. Working as a small operation we create monthly experiences which are live-streamed for the world to see from Bushwick, Brooklyn. Our shows are carefully curated with the classic and modern acts of burlesque, drag, fire arts, dance and more. With the new year approaching we have decided it's time to raise the bar. This holiday season we are bringing to you our largest production ever, The Nutcracker! On December 19th and 20th at Bizarre Bushwick, the timeless tale of wonderment will be reinterpreted as never before through a the lens of New York nightlife. 

We have the talent and the drive to create a spectacular experience, but we need the monetary support to give it life. Our dream is to expand and become a brand that brings hope and excitement to people around the world. We desire to stoke the fires of the human spirit and give audiences stories worth telling. This production is a step towards that goal. 
Your contributions will not only make this production a reality, they will give us further encouragement to push forward, be greater, and keep our arts alive. 

What We Need & What You Get

We already have the venue reserved and some of the preproduction costs covered but we're seeking $4000 to keep on track.

Your contributions will go towards paying the artists, documenting the work, renting rehearsal space, advertising the show, and hiring administrative and technical staff.

What you can receive by supporting us is priceless. Not only will you be guaranteed the experience of the production (through either live-stream or in person) but the cast themselves will teach you their trades. You too can dance like you're in Cirque du Soleil or spin fire like a daredevil! Our passion is sharing our arts and this will bring them directly into your life. However, if you prefer the view from the audience and learning tricks doesn't tickle your fancy, we have plenty for you as well. Home cooked meals, delicious bakes goods, a night away from the kids; we aim to please.

The Impact

We started as a bunch of friends clowning around on a stage and have grown into a family of dedicated artists who live to inspire. We take people between reality and fantasy and keep them enthralled about life. There is nothing but endless gratitude for our fantastic loyal audience (WE LOVE YOU!), and we welcome all new lovers of the night with open arms. Your support will carry us on our mission and keep our crafts alive.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're strapped for cash but still wish to support what we do simply "like" our Facebook page and share this campaign. Let the world know!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Are you a supporter of the arts who likes sex, has a love for debauchery, and wishes your fantasies could be reality? If your answer is "yes" then we have something to share with you.
We are the erotic variety show known as Bordello. Working as a small operation we create monthly experiences which are live-streamed for the world to see from Bushwick, Brooklyn. Our shows are carefully curated with the classic and modern acts of burlesque, drag, fire arts, dance and more. With the new year approaching we have decided it's time to raise the bar. This holiday season we are bringing to you our largest production ever, The Nutcracker! On December 19th and 20th at Bizarre Bushwick, the timeless tale of wonderment will be reinterpreted as never before through a the lens of New York nightlife. We have the talent and the drive to create a spectacular experience, but we need the monetary support to give it life. Our dream is to expand and become a brand that brings hope and excitement to people around the world. We desire to stoke the fires of the human spirit and give audiences stories worth telling. This production is a step towards that goal. 

Your contributions will not only make this production a reality, they will give us further encouragement to push forward, be greater, and keep our arts alive. 
   What We Need & What You Get We already have the venue reserved and some of the preproduction costs covered but we're seeking $4000 to keep on track.
Your contributions will go towards paying the artists, documenting the work, renting rehearsal space, advertising the show, and hiring administrative and technical staff.

What you can receive by supporting us is priceless. Not only will you be guaranteed the experience of the production (through either live-stream or in person) but the cast themselves will teach you their trades. You too can dance like you're in Cirque du Soleil or spin fire like a daredevil! Our passion is sharing our arts and this will bring them directly into your life. However, if you prefer the view from the audience and learning tricks doesn't tickle your fancy, we have plenty for you as well. Home cooked meals, delicious bakes goods, a night away from the kids; we aim to please.
    The Impact We started as a bunch of friends clowning around on a stage and have grown into a family of dedicated artists who live to inspire. We take people between reality and fantasy and keep them enthralled about life. There is nothing but endless gratitude for our fantastic loyal audience (WE LOVE YOU!), and we welcome all new lovers of the night with open arms. Your support will carry us on our mission and keep our crafts alive.

    Other Ways You Can Help If you're strapped for cash but still wish to support what we do simply "like" our Facebook page and share this campaign. Let the world know!

story:
GENERAL INFO:

Mind the Gap Theatre, a NYC production company has been working with London based production company YouBlinked Productions for the last five years on various small productions. This year, creative directors Paula & Hugo decided to produce a full length, one act play. "Perfecting the kiss" is the perfect choice as it affords the audience a glimpse in the murky corners of the rehearsal room. This comedy is a welcome distraction from the harsh reality we have found ourselves in.

CAST & CREATIVES

PATRICK HARMAN - Jonah "Buck" Jackson

JANETTE JOHNSTON - Edwina O'Halloran

HELEN MCMILLAN - Narrator

GEORGE REDNER - Mike Porter

HUGO TREBELS - Harvest Carruthers

Directed by PAULA D'ALESSANDRIS

Written by SCOTT C SICKLES

Here's a short synopisis of the play:

"Perfecting the Kiss, a mockumentary from the stage, tells the story of one stage manager's struggles to navigate the artistic and romantic tribulations of a bad... bad play. She was enamored of the playwright, Harvest Carruthers, who insists he's "never written a gay play." 

Harvest is drawn to the young, handsome actor Jonah "Buck" Jackson, who is as warm and kind as he is marginally talented. 

Buck develops a growing admiration for the director, Edwina, who is really only doing this play to prove that Buck's co-star, the handsome yet enigmatic Mike, is gay in real life so she doesn't have to take his rejection of her previous romantic overture personally. 

Mike... Mike is a consummate artist who just wants to get this disaster over with. 

Will anyone get what they want? Will the play they're doing ever stop sucking? Will the stage manager's gaping emotional wounds heal by reliving this horror?

Mayhem ensues!"

A short biography of our amazing playwright Scott C Sickles

SCOTT C. SICKLES is an Asian-American, LGBT playwright and scriptwriter. He has received three Writers Guild of America Awards for the daytime drama “General Hospital,” as well as four Emmy Award nominations for that series and “One Life to Live.” His plays have been performed in New York City, his native Pittsburgh, across the United States, and internationally in Canada, Australia, the UK, Hungary, Singapore, and Lebanon.

Plays include Composure (Winner, 2016 New York innovative Theatre Award, Outstanding Original Full-Length Script), Shepherd’s Bush (Winner, 2016 Dayton Playhouse FutureFest), Intellectuals (Smith & Kraus’ New Playwrights: Best Plays of 2007), Moonlight & Love Songs (GayFestNYC 2013), Lightning From Heaven (1999 Beverly Hills Theater Guild/Julie Harris Playwriting Award), Demon Bitch Goddess, From the Top, Perfecting the Kiss. Published Short Plays: Beautiful Noises (S&K's 2009: Best 10-Minute Plays...), murmurs (Samuel French Festival Plays #21). He is a member of the Dramatists Guild of America and registered on the New Play Exchange. www.ScottCSickles.com

WHERE DO YOU COME IN........

Putting on a play comes at a cost and as producers - we need your help! We are fighting to keep live theatre alive, especially in smaller, more intimate spaces where actors have the opportunity to play and perform without the pressure and/or limitations of Broadway and the West End.

WHERE YOUR CASH WILL GO....

The target we have set will cover paying the actors, hiring a venue, rights for the writer and rehearsal room rental. Both producers are not looking to make huge profits - all we want is to produce this wonderful, funny play.

We have some lovely perks - see right. All donations are welcome!

You can further support us by sharing this campaign on all social media AND by joining us in the theatre for our play - we have a fabulous evening planned for you!
