story:
Our Story

Maya Macdonald (Playwright): 


The dedication to LEAVE THE BALCONY OPEN reads:

 

 i thought this play was for the dead

it turns out, it is for the living

 

This is quite literally where I began when I wrote this play. I had lost a great deal of people who were close to me, both emotionally, and in proximity. What became of this is a story of seven characters caught mid-sentence, caught between something that couldn't have possibly happened, and a need to express to someone that, yes, that thing actually did happen. I feel it speaks for this generation in a way stories to young people have not. It comes from the closest place I could find. Skin close. Ripped from the seams, even. It is my closeness to it that gave me the drive to keep pushing to tell the story. I wrote it to save my skin. I wrote it to keep living. I wrote it in case I had to leave it behind.


Jessica Bauman (Director): 


When I met Maya four years ago, I was blown away by the power of her writing. It was like nothing I had ever read before. She finds poetry in the most unexpected corners of contemporary speech; she is telling a story that is smart, theatrical, humane â€“ an extraordinary vision of young people wrestling with the most profound questions of what it means to live. I have been lucky enough to collaborate with Maya as her director throughout the development of LEAVE THE BALCONY OPEN. I am thrilled to now count myself as her producer as well. We have gathered an amazing team of actors, designers and other artists to make our vision for BALCONY a reality.

The Impact

At every reading and workshop presentation, people have come up to us to share their stories: deaths of friends, suicide attempts, loved ones lost way too young. This stuff is hard to talk about, and even harder to talk about in a way that lets you laugh, mourn and really remember. Everyone who has shared their stories remind us how important it is to make this play happen. So many people are hungry to see their experience honored on stage. We feel lucky to be able to tell a story we know can speak to them and for them.    


What We Need & What You Get

New Feet Productions, the company Jessica founded three years ago to tell big, theatrical stories, is producing BALCONY at 3LD Art and Technology Center in February. And LEAVE THE BALCONY OPEN is big in all the best ways. It creates a whole world for the audience to dive into with its own dialect, culture and mythology. Our vision is expansive; our means are not. We have raised more than half of the money we need, but we can only get all the way there with your help.

 

There are brilliant actors, designers and dedicated staff to pay; there is an epic set to build; there is space to rent at 3LD; there are costumes to create â€“ oh, are there costumes! There's the beached whale, the high school student trying to â€œdo college right,â€ the girl who doesnâ€™t talk and might be the campus Shaman, the boy about to graduate on the 8 year plan who can never quite empty his pockets. And they all are going to be beautiful.

 

We are offering some fun perks to get you in the BALCONY spirit while you provide us with vital support. If you prefer to get a tax deduction for your contribution, we can easily arrange that outside of the Indiegogo campaign. Email Jessica â€“ jbauman@pipeline.com - and we will make it happen.


Other Ways You Can Help

Let your friends know! You know the deal: tell the world you support us by posting on Facebook, tweeting, telling the person sitting next to you on the subway. We want to get the word out about the project and the fundraising campaign.

 

Come see it! We will be running at 3LD from Feb 5-26. All the cool kids will be there. Promise.

 

Then tell your friends that you just saw the most amazing play and they should see it too.

story:
Landless Theatre is ALIIIIIVE!!!!

In honor of our 10th anniversary, Landless Theatre Company is producing a World Premiere Prog-Metal Rock Opera: Richard Campbell's Frankenstein! The production will be produced in rep with our 3rd Annual Mashup Festival!

Landless has been pushing the envelope of FUN and OFF-BEAT theatre in Washington, DC since 2003. This face-melting new work we discovered by up-and-coming UK rock composer Richard Campbell is sure to rock your balls off as no theatre production ever before.

The production is directed and produced by Melissa Baughman and the team who brought you DIAMOND DEAD (2008 Best Musical Pick of the Capital Fringe), with music direction by Jack Sossman (Baltimore Rock Opera Society). It features a cast of dynamic local rock vocalists and actors, including:

IRENE JERICHO (Cassandra Syndrome) as Elizabeth

ROBERT BRADLEY (Aries and BROS' Valhella) as Walton

GREG BOWEN (BROS' Valhella) as The Creature

ANDREW BAUGHMAN (Diamond Dead) as Victor Frankenstein

Production Designers included JARED DAVIS (artbyjared.com), CHRIS HOLLAND and ELIZABETH REEVES (The Broken Continent). 

Our 3rd Annual Mash-up Festival will include four new mash-up parody plays by local playwrights:

The Walking Fred by MAURICE MARTIN (R.U.X.), Directed by ERIK MORRISON

True Blood Spatter by KERRI SHEEHAN, Directed by CHRIS GRIFFIN (Tarxxxanadu)

Saving Private Poo by STEVE CUSTER and IAN HOCH, Directed by STEVE CUSTER

Trapped in the Convent by ANDREW LLOYD BAUGHMAN, Directed by KARISSA SWANIGAN-UPCHURCH (Perez Hilton Saves The Universe)

In our first ten years, Landless Theatre company brought you DC premieres of EVIL DEAD THE MUSICAL, DR. HORRIBLE'S SING-ALONG BLOG, HIGH FIDELITY A MUSICAL and many others. We need your help to kick off the next decade with work that is MORE challenging, MORE awesome, MORE Landless-y than ever, and to help propel us into a PERMANENT VENUE!

What We Need & What You Get

Keeping DC theatre zesty and irresistible (not to mention affordable) isn't easy, and producing a show at the historic and beautiful GALA Hispanic Theatre at Tivoli isn't cheap. Here is what your contribution helps to fund:

  • $5500 - Overhead Expenses (Theatre Rental, Insurance)
  • $2000 - Lighting and Sound (Equipment and Labor)
  • $2000 - Set Construction (Materials)
  • $1000 - Costume Materials

Yes, your math is correct, the funding we are hoping to generate only partially offsets our expenses... and we don't even begin to pay the actors, directors and designers who dedicate their blood, sweat and tears to bring the show to LIFE.

That's why we need your help!

And here are a few of the perks we offer in return:

  • Listing as a sponsor in the program
  • An invitation to visit a rehearsal and experience the creative process
  • Backstage tours of the production
  • Be our Guest of Honor at the Frankenstein GALA Reception
  • Signed concept albums
  • An opportunity to BUY OUT THE THEATRE!

Landless Theatre Company is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to cultivating new and diverse audiences for live theatre by producing exciting and accessible alternative theatre. All donations are tax-deductable to the fullest extent of the law.

The show must go on whether we reach our goal or not! So please lend support in any way you can!

The Impact

Your support will help Landless Theatre Company BRIDGE THE GAP between mainstream audiences and live theatre, an art form of ever-decreasing significance with a work that BRIDGES THE GAP between the prog-metal music scene and musical theatre. You will also help develop the work of Richard Campbell, a young UK composer who who is destined to be a force in the prog-rock scene (his work is already featured on Rock Band, for crying out loud).

Your support of the 3rd Annual Mashup Festival will also help support the work of 5 local playwrights, 4 directors and a slew of DC's actors! The 1st Annual Mashup Festival spawned the NY Fringe Festival hit GLEEAM... who knows what will come from this year's Fest?!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the world about the productions and this fundraiser through using the share tools on this page! If you'd prefer to make a small donation ($3-$5), visit us at landlesstheatre.com. Every little bit adds up!

story:
The Project: Bring “Rocks Karma Arrows” back to the stage in Boulder, Colorado!

The Need: Help us match our NEA grant!

The Reason: Because you can’t move into a better future until you acknowledge your past.

Thanks to you we raised the $20,000 we needed to match the NEA funds for Rocks Karma Arrows!!! And 4-days a head of time!! Thank you so much for caring about community conversation on race and class in Boulder.

The campaign officially ends on June 19th -- the day in 1861 when Chief Niwot went to the Rocky Mountain News office to protest how the Arapaho were depicted in its newspaper pages. We align ourselves with Chief Niwot's many strategies for pursing justice. It is also Juneteenth, the oldest known celebration commemorating the end of slavery in the United States.

Additional funds that come in the last days of the campaign will help cover post-production costs on the film on Rocks Karma Arrows (and that will be a relief!) so let’s keep growing that final fundraising number!

Thank you again for passing on info about Rocks Karma Arrows and this fundraiser. We look forward to seeing you at the theater!!  Tickets not already part of your contribution perks can be purchased here: brownpapertickets.com/event/246652

Gratitude!!

Kirsten (Artistic Director)

Details on The Project:


Three years ago, a small audience of people in Boulder, Colorado witnessed a transformative theater piece called “Rocks Karma Arrows”, which explores the history of Boulder through the lens of race and class.

The story begins with the tragic relationship between Chief Niwot of the Arapahoe Indians, who worked tirelessly to maintain peace, and the settlers who flocked to this territory when gold was discovered. It reveals a series of decisions and actions over the next 100 years that have cast their shadow over continuing efforts to wrestle with inequality today.

The play struck a nerve. Those whose experiences here have included struggle and discrimination felt validated. Those whose comfortable lives have shielded them from seeing this side of their community felt shocked into awareness. Everyone wanted to continue the conversation.

And thus One Action-One Boulder was conceived, an arts-based community-wide initiative designed to encourage the Boulder community to explore its past and present in order to inspire reflection and action towards a more inclusive and equitable future.

We believe that engaging our community in an honest and open conversation about our local history – both the good parts and the uncomfortable parts – is an important first step to building a stronger and more equitable Boulder.

To learn more about the organizations and activities that are part of One Action-One Boulder, visit the project website: http://www.one-action.org/

As the inspiration and centerpiece for One Action-One Boulder, Kirsten Wilson’s acclaimed multi-media theater work “Rocks Karma Arrows” will return to the stage at the University of Colorado’s ATLAS Center July 12th-29th, 2012. But we need your support to mount this production, so that as many people as possible can see this inspiring, moving and ground-breaking work.


We Need YOU to Help Meet the Match!

Putting on a multi-media production with a 12-person cast, and then capturing it on video to create an educational curriculum package, is a huge financial challenge. “Rocks Karma Arrows” was recently honored to be awarded a $40,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. In order to mount the production and receive the NEA grant, we need to match those federal funds dollar for dollar. With the very generous support of a small group of community investors, we have already raised $20,000 of the match. Now we are turning to YOU to help us raise the remaining $20,000!

Your tax-deductible gift helps us pay the actors, dancers and musicians you can see on stage, the technical and production staff behind the scenes, as well as marketing and management. It will make it possible for us to offer half-price ticket nights and distribute tickets at highly discounted prices to low-income members of our community. It will help us pay translators and interpreters who will make it possible to present “Rocks Karma Arrows” in Spanish for the large Spanish speaking community in Boulder County. And just as important, your gift will help us shoot a high-quality video recording of the performance and hire education experts to develop curriculum materials so that “Rocks Karma Arrows” can be used as a teaching tool in schools, universities and the community for years to come.


What’s In It For YOU?

In exchange for your contribution, you will receive our promise to bring this extraordinary work to the stage, and eventually to schools and libraries in video form, in a production of the quality it deserves.
 
In addition, please see the sidebar for a list of the cool one-of-a-kind perks you will receive for helping us accomplish our mission! We particularly like the exciting Playback Theatre offers for donors in the Boulder/Denver area. You can bring the power of theatre to your home or workplace to build community and share your stories. In these Playback performances, audience members – YOU and your friends or colleagues – tell your stories, and 3 improv actors and 1 musician reenact them on the spot.

Every gift is deeply appreciated. Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is tax-deductible.  Thank you for helping us deepen the community conversation on racial and economic justice!


What Else Can YOU Do?

Share, share, share! Sharing your enthusiasm for this project via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and word of mouth is a huge gift to us.  Please help us go viral with this project by getting the word out on the streets! Just watching the trailer already seeds a conversation on equity!

And if you’re in the Boulder County area, come see “Rocks Karma Arrows” this summer, or participate in any of the other One Action-One Boulder programs. Then commit to taking action: http://www.one-action.org/take-action/

 
Where Will the Money Go?

Salaries - Artistic, Technical, Production Management: 53%
9 actors, 2 musicians, 1 dancer, artistic director, lighting designer, 3 technical assistants, directorial advisor, stage manager, box office manager, researcher, prop construction, project management, admin assistant, web maintenance

Film Shoot: 17%
film director, 3 camera people, salaries for all actors & tech, lighting design, sound person, video duplication

Curriculum: 13%
2 curriculum writers, 5 advisors, 1 designer, packaging

Spanish Language Performance: 5%
script translation, Spanish interpreters, camera people and equipment for live video of Spanish language performance

Publicity: 5%
designer, poster, postcards, ads, flyer service, photographer, social media

Other: 7%
tech equipment, rental, props, supplies, sign language interpreter, programs, scripts


Our Team

Motus Theater is a new organization built from community momentum around Rocks Karma Arrows, and devoted to inclusive and cohesive community dialogue through the arts. Although Motus is a new organization, its Executive Director, Kirsten Wilson, has been creating multi-disciplinary theater to create community conversation since 1991.  Wilson was the creator and artistic director of Rocks Karma Arrows, for which she was designated an “ATLAS Innovator” by the Center for Media, Arts and Performance at the University of Colorado at Boulder. Rocks Karma Arrows was a featured performance in Boulder’s Sesquicentennial celebration, and was lauded by critics for containing a “diverse set of performance styles and techniques” that was nevertheless “highly accessible and never pretentious” (Boulder Daily Camera). Wendell Beavers, Chair of the MFA Theater: Contemporary Performance program at Naropa University called it “an excellent and effective example of art that changes people’s lives and perspectives, educates and more rare, does so with a high level of artistic rigor and quality.” More on Rocks Karma Arrows: http://www.one-action.org/portfolio/rocks-karma...

One Action-One Boulder/Niwot’s Arrows Community Collaborators Include: Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration Committee, Boulder County Arts Alliance, Boulder History Museum, Native American Rights Fund, Boulder Public Library, Niwot Historical Society, Matrix Center for the Advancement of Social Equity and Inclusion at the University of Colorado-Colorado Springs, University of Colorado at Boulder, All Cultures, One Action - Longmont, Hip Hip Heredia, Boulder Human Relations Commission, Boulder Community United, Kirsten Wilson Productions, Playback Theatre West, Motus Playback, Resonance Women’s Chorus and more...
story_txt:
The Project: Bring “Rocks Karma Arrows” back to the stage in Boulder, Colorado!The Need: Help us match our NEA grant!The Reason: Because you can’t move into a better future until you acknowledge your past.
Thanks to you we raised the $20,000 we needed to match the NEA funds for Rocks Karma Arrows!!! And 4-days a head of time!! Thank you so much for caring about community conversation on race and class in Boulder.
The campaign officially ends on June 19th -- the day in 1861 when Chief Niwot went to the Rocky Mountain News office to protest how the Arapaho were depicted in its newspaper pages. We align ourselves with Chief Niwot's many strategies for pursing justice. It is also Juneteenth, the oldest known celebration commemorating the end of slavery in the United States.
Additional funds that come in the last days of the campaign will help cover post-production costs on the film on Rocks Karma Arrows (and that will be a relief!) so let’s keep growing that final fundraising number!
Thank you again for passing on info about Rocks Karma Arrows and this fundraiser. We look forward to seeing you at the theater!!  Tickets not already part of your contribution perks can be purchased here: brownpapertickets.com/event/246652
Gratitude!!
Kirsten (Artistic Director)
Details on The Project:
Three years ago, a small audience of people in Boulder, Colorado witnessed a transformative theater piece called “Rocks Karma Arrows”, which explores the history of Boulder through the lens of race and class. The story begins with the tragic relationship between Chief Niwot of the Arapahoe Indians, who worked tirelessly to maintain peace, and the settlers who flocked to this territory when gold was discovered. It reveals a series of decisions and actions over the next 100 years that have cast their shadow over continuing efforts to wrestle with inequality today.The play struck a nerve. Those whose experiences here have included struggle and discrimination felt validated. Those whose comfortable lives have shielded them from seeing this side of their community felt shocked into awareness. Everyone wanted to continue the conversation.And thus One Action-One Boulder was conceived, an arts-based community-wide initiative designed to encourage the Boulder community to explore its past and present in order to inspire reflection and action towards a more inclusive and equitable future. We believe that engaging our community in an honest and open conversation about our local history – both the good parts and the uncomfortable parts – is an important first step to building a stronger and more equitable Boulder. To learn more about the organizations and activities that are part of One Action-One Boulder, visit the project website: http://www.one-action.org/As the inspiration and centerpiece for One Action-One Boulder, Kirsten Wilson’s acclaimed multi-media theater work “Rocks Karma Arrows” will return to the stage at the University of Colorado’s ATLAS Center July 12th-29th, 2012. But we need your support to mount this production, so that as many people as possible can see this inspiring, moving and ground-breaking work.We Need YOU to Help Meet the Match!Putting on a multi-media production with a 12-person cast, and then capturing it on video to create an educational curriculum package, is a huge financial challenge. “Rocks Karma Arrows” was recently honored to be awarded a $40,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. In order to mount the production and receive the NEA grant, we need to match those federal funds dollar for dollar. With the very generous support of a small group of community investors, we have already raised $20,000 of the match. Now we are turning to YOU to help us raise the remaining $20,000!Your tax-deductible gift helps us pay the actors, dancers and musicians you can see on stage, the technical and production staff behind the scenes, as well as marketing and management. It will make it possible for us to offer half-price ticket nights and distribute tickets at highly discounted prices to low-income members of our community. It will help us pay translators and interpreters who will make it possible to present “Rocks Karma Arrows” in Spanish for the large Spanish speaking community in Boulder County. And just as important, your gift will help us shoot a high-quality video recording of the performance and hire education experts to develop curriculum materials so that “Rocks Karma Arrows” can be used as a teaching tool in schools, universities and the community for years to come.What’s In It For YOU?In exchange for your contribution, you will receive our promise to bring this extraordinary work to the stage, and eventually to schools and libraries in video form, in a production of the quality it deserves. In addition, please see the sidebar for a list of the cool one-of-a-kind perks you will receive for helping us accomplish our mission! We particularly like the exciting Playback Theatre offers for donors in the Boulder/Denver area. You can bring the power of theatre to your home or workplace to build community and share your stories. In these Playback performances, audience members – YOU and your friends or colleagues – tell your stories, and 3 improv actors and 1 musician reenact them on the spot.Every gift is deeply appreciated. Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is tax-deductible.  Thank you for helping us deepen the community conversation on racial and economic justice!What Else Can YOU Do?Share, share, share! Sharing your enthusiasm for this project via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and word of mouth is a huge gift to us.  Please help us go viral with this project by getting the word out on the streets! Just watching the trailer already seeds a conversation on equity!And if you’re in the Boulder County area, come see “Rocks Karma Arrows” this summer, or participate in any of the other One Action-One Boulder programs.
